description: The Cloud Fundamentals video series is designed to introduce the viewer to cloud computing, which works from providers that can have thousands of servers and have more than enough hardware and CPU resources to support their systems and they rent out the extra capacity to users so the potential is not wasted. Positions like system administrators, developers and CIOs all benefit from implementing cloud technology. Cloud concepts and theory are discussed and then actual deployment examples of practical applications are demonstrated using Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure.
name: Cloud Fundamentals
subtitle: Introduction to cloud computing

episodes.title: What is the Cloud?
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,606
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,606 --> 00:00:11,451
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11,451 --> 00:00:14,930
Greetings, and welcome to another
great episode of IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:14,930 --> 00:00:16,360
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16,360 --> 00:00:18,420
Here with me today is none
other than Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18,420 --> 00:00:19,770
How you doing today Don?

7
00:00:19,770 --> 00:00:20,800
>> I am doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:20,800 --> 00:00:23,900
And you know I'm excited to
kick off a new series here on

9
00:00:23,900 --> 00:00:27,060
ITProTV our Cloud Fundamentals.

10
00:00:27,060 --> 00:00:30,935
This is going to be a series of episodes
all tailored to introducing you

11
00:00:30,935 --> 00:00:35,088
the viewer, to the cloud which is like
the most nebulous term in the world.

12
00:00:35,088 --> 00:00:37,336
Well, I guess nebula's are clouds I
don't know how that works out, or not.

13
00:00:37,336 --> 00:00:38,885
But it's a buzz word that
gets thrown around a lot.

14
00:00:38,885 --> 00:00:41,715
A lot a lot of people don't really
realize what's going on with it.

15
00:00:41,715 --> 00:00:45,005
So we're gonna decipher the mystery and
kind of thin that out.

16
00:00:45,005 --> 00:00:48,295
We're going to start off with a few
episodes that are just going to detail

17
00:00:48,295 --> 00:00:49,530
cloud concepts.

18
00:00:49,530 --> 00:00:51,990
And then we're going to follow off
with some real world examples.

19
00:00:51,990 --> 00:00:55,170
Show you how to implement cloud
technologies, how to make use of them.

20
00:00:55,170 --> 00:00:59,240
We'll get some chances to see, like,
Amazon EC2, and Microsoft Azure, and

21
00:00:59,240 --> 00:01:00,840
those guys in action.

22
00:01:00,840 --> 00:01:05,020
But before we dive into all that,
let's just start with the basics.

23
00:01:05,020 --> 00:01:06,410
What is the cloud?

24
00:01:07,460 --> 00:01:08,790
Now, if somebody comes to you and
says, hey,

25
00:01:08,790 --> 00:01:12,840
I need to get my stuff in the cloud,
they could mean several different things.

26
00:01:12,840 --> 00:01:17,970
So let's back it all the way back up
to where this technology came from,

27
00:01:17,970 --> 00:01:19,100
back in the 1970s.

28
00:01:19,100 --> 00:01:21,280
That's right, we're gonna go,
we're going old school.

29
00:01:21,280 --> 00:01:23,415
So back 40 years ago.

30
00:01:23,415 --> 00:01:26,635
We started to see virtualize
computing infrastructure.

31
00:01:26,635 --> 00:01:30,065
He's on a mainframe mostly like the old
VAC systems and things like that.

32
00:01:30,065 --> 00:01:31,885
They had virtualization in them.

33
00:01:31,885 --> 00:01:36,535
And then the technology kind of died off
in the late 80s and then in the late 90s,

34
00:01:36,535 --> 00:01:38,835
it started to come back again.

35
00:01:38,835 --> 00:01:42,825
And we started seeing this
virtualization movement kick in, and

36
00:01:42,825 --> 00:01:44,880
it's what really led to the cloud.

37
00:01:44,880 --> 00:01:48,550
So virtualization is really the heart of
this and if you don't know what that is.

38
00:01:48,550 --> 00:01:52,570
Well virtualization is probably one of the
coolest technologies to be implemented on

39
00:01:52,570 --> 00:01:54,040
modern networks.

40
00:01:54,040 --> 00:01:58,910
What it is, the way I always describe it,
is it's kind of like car pooling for

41
00:01:58,910 --> 00:02:00,290
computers, right?

42
00:02:00,290 --> 00:02:01,800
If you think about your car.

43
00:02:01,800 --> 00:02:05,858
I drove to the studio this morning
in a car that has five seats in it,

44
00:02:05,858 --> 00:02:07,750
and I was the only person in it.

45
00:02:07,750 --> 00:02:12,390
So that meant I had four seats in my car
that were empty that I could've used,

46
00:02:12,390 --> 00:02:13,320
but I waste it.

47
00:02:13,320 --> 00:02:15,760
So I really only use 20% of
the potential of my vehicle,

48
00:02:15,760 --> 00:02:17,730
as far as moving people
from one place to another.

49
00:02:17,730 --> 00:02:19,830
Well that's where your computer is.

50
00:02:19,830 --> 00:02:21,780
I've got a laptop sitting
here in front of me.

51
00:02:21,780 --> 00:02:23,760
It's got 16 gigs of RAM in it.

52
00:02:23,760 --> 00:02:26,650
I'm probably using two
gigs of ram right now.

53
00:02:26,650 --> 00:02:29,050
The other memory just wasted.

54
00:02:29,050 --> 00:02:31,600
CPU, I don't really know.

55
00:02:31,600 --> 00:02:34,000
I think I've got a quad-core processor.

56
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:35,120
Show's what I know.

57
00:02:35,120 --> 00:02:39,070
So I'm probably using one CPU, and
barely a percent is that right now.

58
00:02:39,070 --> 00:02:40,980
The rest of it is being wasted.

59
00:02:40,980 --> 00:02:42,170
That's how our computers are.

60
00:02:42,170 --> 00:02:45,570
We waste a lot of resources,
but we want them

61
00:02:45,570 --> 00:02:48,670
because there will come a time when
I need it, where I need that memory.

62
00:02:48,670 --> 00:02:50,910
I need that CPU, and I need it to be here.

63
00:02:50,910 --> 00:02:53,130
So, I have it, and
I just waste what's extra.

64
00:02:54,180 --> 00:02:58,633
With virtualization what we do, is we
take more than one operating system and

65
00:02:58,633 --> 00:03:00,420
we run it on the same computer.

66
00:03:00,420 --> 00:03:02,220
We run it on the same hardware.

67
00:03:02,220 --> 00:03:05,690
And now, you know, I might only
be using two gigs of memory, but

68
00:03:05,690 --> 00:03:08,110
I've got another operating system
that's using two more gigs.

69
00:03:08,110 --> 00:03:10,150
And a third operating system
that's using two more.

70
00:03:10,150 --> 00:03:12,930
And between the three of us
we're all using six gigs of RAM.

71
00:03:12,930 --> 00:03:15,830
Now we're actually starting to use
the hardware that's available to us,

72
00:03:15,830 --> 00:03:17,780
we're starting to get our money's worth.

73
00:03:17,780 --> 00:03:20,900
And that's the principle
behind virtualization.

74
00:03:20,900 --> 00:03:23,500
That's where products like VMWare,
vSphere and

75
00:03:23,500 --> 00:03:28,510
Microsoft HyperV, Citrix Zen Server,
KVM, all those other different software

76
00:03:28,510 --> 00:03:31,850
virtualization products that are out
there, and their hardware counterparts.

77
00:03:31,850 --> 00:03:36,480
All of that works on the simple
principle of carpooling for servers.

78
00:03:37,510 --> 00:03:41,150
Well, once that started to catch on,
and remember,

79
00:03:41,150 --> 00:03:43,120
this really came about in the 1970s.

80
00:03:43,120 --> 00:03:47,870
But it wasn't until the late 90s that
VMWare really pushed into businesses.

81
00:03:47,870 --> 00:03:52,430
And we're to a point now in the year 2015,
where If you're a business and

82
00:03:52,430 --> 00:03:55,480
you don't have virtualization of one form
or another, you're behind the curve.

83
00:03:55,480 --> 00:03:59,340
Everybody's pretty much implement
this in one form or another.

84
00:03:59,340 --> 00:04:03,300
Well, providers like Amazon, Microsoft.

85
00:04:03,300 --> 00:04:07,060
These companies that are huge, that tens
of thousands of servers around the world.

86
00:04:07,060 --> 00:04:12,800
Google, Rackspace these guys have tons
of hardware to support their systems.

87
00:04:12,800 --> 00:04:14,570
And it's more than they need.

88
00:04:14,570 --> 00:04:18,100
And so what do they do with
the extra stuff goes to waste?

89
00:04:18,100 --> 00:04:19,570
Well used to,

90
00:04:19,570 --> 00:04:25,030
now thanks to virtualization they can
rent out their extra space to customers.

91
00:04:25,030 --> 00:04:30,190
If you need a server with a certain amount
of memory, instead of building yourself

92
00:04:30,190 --> 00:04:33,825
you can just go rent it from Microsoft's
leftovers, or Amazon's leftovers.

93
00:04:33,825 --> 00:04:35,220
Because they got a ton, right?

94
00:04:35,220 --> 00:04:36,990
Tens of thousands of us around the globe.

95
00:04:36,990 --> 00:04:39,290
Google, they probably
have the most of anybody.

96
00:04:39,290 --> 00:04:43,300
They've got reserves, they've got extra
CPU, extra memory laying around, and

97
00:04:43,300 --> 00:04:45,000
I don't mean like chips laying on a shelf.

98
00:04:45,000 --> 00:04:47,025
Although they they do that too.

99
00:04:47,025 --> 00:04:48,632
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I mean,

100
00:04:48,632 --> 00:04:50,660
active servers that are running,
connected to the Internet.

101
00:04:50,660 --> 00:04:53,470
That just aren't being used to
they're fullest utilization.

102
00:04:53,470 --> 00:04:55,640
And we can take advantage of that.

103
00:04:55,640 --> 00:04:57,820
And that is the cloud.

104
00:04:57,820 --> 00:04:59,470
It's using these servers.

105
00:04:59,470 --> 00:05:01,530
These things that
are connected to the internet.

106
00:05:01,530 --> 00:05:02,600
They just aren't being used right now.

107
00:05:02,600 --> 00:05:05,130
It's just kind of available and
being wasted.

108
00:05:05,130 --> 00:05:09,210
So you can thank technologies
like VMware ESX server.

109
00:05:09,210 --> 00:05:10,500
Or Microsoft's Hyper V.

110
00:05:10,500 --> 00:05:13,510
Or Virtual Box, or any of
the virtualization products out there.

111
00:05:13,510 --> 00:05:16,700
For leading to what we all
think of today as a cloud.

112
00:05:16,700 --> 00:05:18,200
>> And it's very convenient too.

113
00:05:18,200 --> 00:05:22,710
I love virtualization, to be able to run
mobile operating systems on my laptop,

114
00:05:22,710 --> 00:05:24,340
kind of like Don was talking about.

115
00:05:24,340 --> 00:05:29,000
But the cost of it is so
much more economical than me going, well,

116
00:05:29,000 --> 00:05:33,030
I need another server, or
I need another, even a desktop system.

117
00:05:33,030 --> 00:05:35,910
I don't have to actually buy that system.

118
00:05:35,910 --> 00:05:38,730
I can say hey I can use one
of these cloud technologies.

119
00:05:38,730 --> 00:05:39,820
I can go to Amazon.

120
00:05:39,820 --> 00:05:42,350
I can go to Microsoft Azure and
use some of that.

121
00:05:42,350 --> 00:05:45,450
And let them foot the bill, and
take care of all that stuff.

122
00:05:45,450 --> 00:05:47,220
I just need the server to run.

123
00:05:47,220 --> 00:05:49,140
Makes it really simple for me.

124
00:05:49,140 --> 00:05:51,890
>> Now where it gets confusing is,

125
00:05:51,890 --> 00:05:55,170
when you decide to implement
a technology in the cloud.

126
00:05:55,170 --> 00:05:59,050
You have different layers, different
levels that you can kind of buy in.

127
00:05:59,050 --> 00:06:00,440
It's like a poker game.

128
00:06:00,440 --> 00:06:01,780
You can you can bet a little bit, or

129
00:06:01,780 --> 00:06:04,280
you can go all in and
put all your chips into that bet.

130
00:06:04,280 --> 00:06:06,450
Well that's how the cloud is.

131
00:06:06,450 --> 00:06:10,130
So when you reach out and you start
to reserve these cloud resources.

132
00:06:10,130 --> 00:06:12,800
It's up to you how far in you want to go,
all right?

133
00:06:12,800 --> 00:06:15,560
Some people just tab their
toe in a little bit.

134
00:06:15,560 --> 00:06:17,010
They rent that server hardware.

135
00:06:17,010 --> 00:06:20,560
They go to Amazon EC2 or
they go to Microsoft Azure, and

136
00:06:20,560 --> 00:06:22,700
they rent CPU and memory.

137
00:06:22,700 --> 00:06:24,500
And they put their
operating system on there.

138
00:06:24,500 --> 00:06:25,910
They put their software on there.

139
00:06:25,910 --> 00:06:28,660
They manage it just like they would
a server in their own environment.

140
00:06:28,660 --> 00:06:32,140
But the hardware is what's
out there in the cloud.

141
00:06:32,140 --> 00:06:35,360
And they're renting that from that
provider whoever that happens to be,

142
00:06:35,360 --> 00:06:37,120
to get the access to that system.

143
00:06:37,120 --> 00:06:39,670
Now that's one way to go about it.

144
00:06:39,670 --> 00:06:44,260
And the nice part there is the hardware
is completely handled by that vendor.

145
00:06:44,260 --> 00:06:45,630
You don't have to worry about it.

146
00:06:45,630 --> 00:06:47,980
You manage everything
else as far as the OS.

147
00:06:47,980 --> 00:06:49,800
Just like you would a server
sitting right next to you.

148
00:06:49,800 --> 00:06:51,940
So it's easy to implement that way, and

149
00:06:51,940 --> 00:06:55,330
you start to take advantage of some
of what the cloud has to offer.

150
00:06:56,640 --> 00:06:58,280
Then we can go a step further.

151
00:06:58,280 --> 00:07:01,760
And we can say, well you know what,
they're managing our hardware.

152
00:07:01,760 --> 00:07:04,710
Wouldn't it be nice if they
managed the operating system too?

153
00:07:04,710 --> 00:07:07,090
And now they can manage the hardware and
the operating system, and

154
00:07:07,090 --> 00:07:08,810
we just throw our software on top.

155
00:07:08,810 --> 00:07:10,840
And now we just have to
keep track of our software.

156
00:07:10,840 --> 00:07:13,290
That's a little bit further
into the cloud, right?

157
00:07:13,290 --> 00:07:16,810
Now you're starting to kind of eliminate

158
00:07:16,810 --> 00:07:20,360
your ability to control certain
areas as far as hardware and the OS.

159
00:07:20,360 --> 00:07:22,940
And then there's going all in.

160
00:07:22,940 --> 00:07:25,480
And going all in,
that's where you say, you know what?

161
00:07:25,480 --> 00:07:28,010
I want this provider out there on
the cloud to take care of the hardware,

162
00:07:28,010 --> 00:07:30,300
the operating system, the software,
the whole nine yards.

163
00:07:30,300 --> 00:07:32,480
I just wanna use my programs.

164
00:07:32,480 --> 00:07:36,130
And that's really where
most of our consumers are.

165
00:07:36,130 --> 00:07:39,130
And most of you guys who are watching
the show are probably doing this.

166
00:07:39,130 --> 00:07:44,170
If you if you use web based email, like I
use Gmail for some of my personal email.

167
00:07:44,170 --> 00:07:47,586
And with Google, they provide the servers,
they provide the OS,

168
00:07:47,586 --> 00:07:49,052
they provide the software.

169
00:07:49,052 --> 00:07:51,420
I just log into a web page and
there's my email.

170
00:07:51,420 --> 00:07:53,541
I didn't configure anything.

171
00:07:53,541 --> 00:07:58,766
On one hand, I get super easy to use
email that is on world class servers and

172
00:07:58,766 --> 00:08:04,610
world class data centers,
it's really more than I could do myself.

173
00:08:04,610 --> 00:08:07,300
On the other hand,
I have zero control of that server.

174
00:08:07,300 --> 00:08:11,750
If I say, boy,
I really wish they offered S/MIME support.

175
00:08:12,790 --> 00:08:15,868
Well, they don't, and
there's nothing I can do about that.

176
00:08:15,868 --> 00:08:20,110
In fact, there's no real way to contact
Google to even ask them, right.

177
00:08:20,110 --> 00:08:25,140
So you're really leaving it up to
them to control those features and

178
00:08:25,140 --> 00:08:27,980
so on,
we're just not able to deal with that.

179
00:08:27,980 --> 00:08:30,290
So that's one of the challenges
that you bump into.

180
00:08:30,290 --> 00:08:34,640
If you need a lot of control, going
full cloud is not necessarily an option.

181
00:08:34,640 --> 00:08:36,220
You might have to go with
one of the smaller options.

182
00:08:36,220 --> 00:08:37,810
So that's something we
need to be aware of,

183
00:08:37,810 --> 00:08:41,380
is that there are different levels of
buy in when it comes to using the cloud.

184
00:08:41,380 --> 00:08:45,760
>> Now Don, is there necessarily a right
or wrong implementation of the cloud, or

185
00:08:45,760 --> 00:08:50,410
it's just whatever's curtailed to your-
>> According to the trade magazines,

186
00:08:50,410 --> 00:08:51,114
they're all right.

187
00:08:51,114 --> 00:08:54,473
>> [LAUGH]
>> You should be using the cloud!

188
00:08:54,473 --> 00:08:58,880
I think that it's not so much about being
wrong as it is being sub-optimal, right.

189
00:08:58,880 --> 00:09:03,280
That there's some people that have certain
needs, and when you go into the cloud,

190
00:09:03,280 --> 00:09:07,210
you might not be taking advantage
of all that the cloud has to offer.

191
00:09:07,210 --> 00:09:11,350
Or maybe you're taking into too much,
and now you've put yourself at risk.

192
00:09:11,350 --> 00:09:14,420
Like if your company handles
financial records or medical records,

193
00:09:14,420 --> 00:09:18,950
you might put too much data into the cloud
and then the cloud gets compromised.

194
00:09:18,950 --> 00:09:21,190
And now those records are out and
you have a debacle.

195
00:09:21,190 --> 00:09:24,090
You should have maintained more control so
you can encrypt your data and

196
00:09:24,090 --> 00:09:25,180
guarantee security.

197
00:09:25,180 --> 00:09:27,370
So you do have to be careful
about things like that.

198
00:09:27,370 --> 00:09:29,030
But it's not so much about right or

199
00:09:29,030 --> 00:09:33,540
wrong as it is just making sure
that you take proper precautions.

200
00:09:33,540 --> 00:09:38,430
So, all right, now when we go into
the cloud what most people think of

201
00:09:38,430 --> 00:09:42,420
as the cloud is is what's actually
called the public cloud, all right.

202
00:09:42,420 --> 00:09:46,000
Amazon's Web services,
Microsoft Azure, Rackspace,

203
00:09:46,000 --> 00:09:50,540
OpenStack, those guys they're
providing public clouds.

204
00:09:50,540 --> 00:09:53,760
A server infrastructure with
tens of thousands of servers

205
00:09:53,760 --> 00:09:55,520
that are exposed to the Internet.

206
00:09:55,520 --> 00:10:00,150
So if I bring a web server up
in Amazon EC2, well by default

207
00:10:00,150 --> 00:10:03,805
it's got a public IP on the Internet, and
if I open up port 80 on its firewall,

208
00:10:03,805 --> 00:10:07,705
the whole Internet can see that server and
browse and get access to it, all right.

209
00:10:07,705 --> 00:10:11,635
That's a public cloud, and
if you're gonna be running a website,

210
00:10:11,635 --> 00:10:15,195
an email server, or something of that
nature, you want it to be public.

211
00:10:16,465 --> 00:10:19,435
But there's also private clouds.

212
00:10:19,435 --> 00:10:24,630
Private clouds are ones where you set up
the cloud in your own infrastructure.

213
00:10:24,630 --> 00:10:27,420
So for example,
let's say that I needed a cloud.

214
00:10:27,420 --> 00:10:29,370
I want to be able to rapidly
provision servers and

215
00:10:29,370 --> 00:10:31,900
all that good stuff that we
hear about with these clouds.

216
00:10:31,900 --> 00:10:34,650
I could go ahead and go and
buy 100 servers, and

217
00:10:34,650 --> 00:10:36,110
I could set them up right
here behind the set.

218
00:10:36,110 --> 00:10:37,170
I'll stick them behind this wall, right.

219
00:10:37,170 --> 00:10:39,519
I'll just stack 100 servers and
it'll get hot as heck in here.

220
00:10:39,519 --> 00:10:41,960
[LAUGH] So we'll set up those 100 servers.

221
00:10:41,960 --> 00:10:44,550
And now I can set it up with
cloud software to be able to

222
00:10:44,550 --> 00:10:46,930
rapidly provision machines,
get that up and running.

223
00:10:46,930 --> 00:10:47,950
I can do it.

224
00:10:47,950 --> 00:10:50,880
It's private because I control everything.

225
00:10:50,880 --> 00:10:53,400
It's my hardware, it's my operating
system, it's my software,

226
00:10:53,400 --> 00:10:57,630
I'm not really outsourcing anything,
it's a private cloud completely here, but

the operating system and the hardware.

507
00:23:34,970 --> 00:23:38,740
And with infrastructure as a service,
you control the software and

508
00:23:38,740 --> 00:23:39,890
the operating system.

509
00:23:39,890 --> 00:23:41,390
You've given up control of the hardware.

510
00:23:41,390 --> 00:23:44,386
And that means that infrastructure
as a service is the lowest risk.

511
00:23:44,386 --> 00:23:47,860
And that's where people normally kind
of enter into the cloud space, and

512
00:23:47,860 --> 00:23:51,839
then they start moving up to the others as
they leverage the various technologies and

513
00:23:51,839 --> 00:23:54,494
find that they can really be
some big benefits in there.

514
00:23:54,494 --> 00:23:56,355
>> Yeah, and
it seems like that makes sense, you know?

515
00:23:56,355 --> 00:23:57,590
To go ahead and say.

516
00:23:57,590 --> 00:24:01,732
Well, this isn't mission-critical stuff, I
can start just putting some servers here,

517
00:24:01,732 --> 00:24:04,760
maybe some network equipment there,
creating those links.

518
00:24:04,760 --> 00:24:07,510
And then, as you become more
comfortable with that type of service,

519
00:24:07,510 --> 00:24:09,700
then you start moving
other things as well.

520
00:24:09,700 --> 00:24:10,998
>> Yep, absolutely.

521
00:24:10,998 --> 00:24:14,630
So when your CIO comes storming into your
office saying, hey I just read this Forbes

522
00:24:14,630 --> 00:24:18,150
article and we gotta get our stuff in
the cloud, you can say, well, all right.

523
00:24:18,150 --> 00:24:19,740
What is it we're trying to achieve?

524
00:24:19,740 --> 00:24:22,490
Are you tired of having to
deal with the hardware and

525
00:24:22,490 --> 00:24:26,240
the materials cost of running an IT
department and we wanna outsource that?

526
00:24:26,240 --> 00:24:30,170
Or is it that you're tired of
exploits in your host OSs and

527
00:24:30,170 --> 00:24:33,070
you'd rather that be pushed out and
managed by somebody else?

528
00:24:33,070 --> 00:24:36,780
Or are you looking to eliminate a large
portion of your IT staff or just get

529
00:24:36,780 --> 00:24:40,650
a more reliable software deployment and
move to software as a service?

530
00:24:40,650 --> 00:24:43,670
You know, what is it you're trying
to achieve, what's your goal?

531
00:24:43,670 --> 00:24:46,900
And then they can look at you and they
can say, well, you know I hadn't thought

532
00:24:46,900 --> 00:24:49,850
about it but really the biggest problem
that we're facing right now is that we

533
00:24:49,850 --> 00:24:53,530
have hard drive failures and I've only got
so much staff It's hard to get somebody to

534
00:24:53,530 --> 00:24:56,840
come in and replace those drives,
or whatever at 2 AM.

535
00:24:56,840 --> 00:24:58,620
I just need that to go away.

536
00:24:58,620 --> 00:25:01,620
And now we know, we need to look for
infrastructure as a service.

537
00:25:01,620 --> 00:25:04,520
Or they say, look,
we've got this CRM software, and

538
00:25:04,520 --> 00:25:07,860
it works great enough, but
we've had so many outages this year.

539
00:25:07,860 --> 00:25:09,610
I'd rather we didn't
have to worry about it.

540
00:25:09,610 --> 00:25:11,300
Or, SharePoint's a great example.

541
00:25:11,300 --> 00:25:15,280
They say, I've got Microsoft SharePoint,
and the site works, but man, is it slow,

542
00:25:15,280 --> 00:25:17,730
and nobody here knows how
to tune the software right.

543
00:25:17,730 --> 00:25:20,720
I really wish we had somebody who
knew what they were doing running

544
00:25:20,720 --> 00:25:22,360
our SharePoint server.

545
00:25:22,360 --> 00:25:24,150
Just on a personal note,

546
00:25:24,150 --> 00:25:27,060
you do need to know what you're doing if
you set up your own SharePoint server.

547
00:25:27,060 --> 00:25:28,538
They're tough to tune.

548
00:25:28,538 --> 00:25:32,100
So we say, all right, what we really
need there is software as a service.

549
00:25:32,100 --> 00:25:34,790
We need to go to Microsoft and
do Office 365, and

550
00:25:34,790 --> 00:25:37,020
they'll host our SharePoint server for us.

551
00:25:37,020 --> 00:25:40,230
Now we know it's tuned right because the
guys who wrote the software are hosting it

552
00:25:40,230 --> 00:25:43,260
for us and it's up,
it's running, it's smooth.

553
00:25:43,260 --> 00:25:44,850
We don't have to worry about it anymore.

554
00:25:44,850 --> 00:25:49,550
So you find out a little more information
from the CIO, you provide the solution

555
00:25:49,550 --> 00:25:53,370
that they need, and now you move forward
and take advantage of the cloud.

556
00:25:53,370 --> 00:25:56,710
So let's recap those just
real quick before we wrap up.

557
00:25:56,710 --> 00:25:58,490
Infrastructure is the service.

558
00:25:58,490 --> 00:26:00,600
That's where they take the hardware.

559
00:26:00,600 --> 00:26:04,880
They're responsible for the hardware,
you deal with OS in software.

560
00:26:04,880 --> 00:26:07,080
Then platform is a service.

561
00:26:07,080 --> 00:26:09,720
They provide the hardware and the OS.

562
00:26:09,720 --> 00:26:12,400
You're just responsible for
the software, the application.

563
00:26:12,400 --> 00:26:16,230
And then software as a service, they
provide the whole thing, the hardware,

564
00:26:16,230 --> 00:26:17,990
the OS, and the software.

565
00:26:17,990 --> 00:26:18,770
You just consume it.

566
00:26:18,770 --> 00:26:21,160
You just use the software and
be happy, smile,

567
00:26:21,160 --> 00:26:23,655
and fire half your IT staff or whatever.

568
00:26:23,655 --> 00:26:25,365
>> [LAUGH] Layoffs for everyone.

569
00:26:25,365 --> 00:26:27,110
>> [LAUGH] Not necessarily.

570
00:26:27,110 --> 00:26:30,290
It does sound negative sometimes, but with
software as a service it might be that

571
00:26:30,290 --> 00:26:32,880
there's just one particular software
package that you're outsourcing and

572
00:26:32,880 --> 00:26:35,130
you have plenty of other
software you maintain internally.

573
00:26:35,130 --> 00:26:36,910
It's up to you how you
wanna implement that.

574
00:26:36,910 --> 00:26:39,510
Many people do actually use
it though to reduce IT staff.

575
00:26:39,510 --> 00:26:40,100
>> Yes.

576
00:26:40,100 --> 00:26:42,000
It is an option, that is true.

577
00:26:42,000 --> 00:26:45,570
That being said, Don, I think that
we have covered this pretty well.

578
00:26:45,570 --> 00:26:47,820
Very informative stuff,
and thank you for that.

579
00:26:47,820 --> 00:26:50,400
Hope you guys out there watching
this really got a lot out of it,

580
00:26:50,400 --> 00:26:51,550
I know I sure did.

581
00:26:51,550 --> 00:26:54,260
That being said I think we've come
to the end of another episode.

582
00:26:54,260 --> 00:26:57,870
So for ITProTV, signing off,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

583
00:26:57,870 --> 00:26:58,590
And I'm Don Pezet.

584
00:26:58,590 --> 00:26:59,813
>> And we'll see you next time.

585
00:26:59,813 --> 00:27:05,730
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Cloud Strategies
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11,018 --> 00:00:11,979
All right, everyone.

3
00:00:11,979 --> 00:00:15,011
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15,011 --> 00:00:16,710
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:16,710 --> 00:00:18,700
Here with me today is Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18,700 --> 00:00:19,940
How are you doing today, Don?

7
00:00:19,940 --> 00:00:20,880
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:20,880 --> 00:00:22,250
Glad to be back on the show.

9
00:00:22,250 --> 00:00:23,920
And we got a neat show up ahead of us.

10
00:00:23,920 --> 00:00:28,794
Because what we're going to do today is
answer one of the one of the big questions

11
00:00:28,794 --> 00:00:29,832
that I get a lot.

12
00:00:29,832 --> 00:00:32,990
Which is Don, why should I even
bother with this whole cloud mess?

13
00:00:32,990 --> 00:00:34,440
I've got servers at my office,

14
00:00:34,440 --> 00:00:37,560
they run fine,
everything does what I need it to do.

15
00:00:37,560 --> 00:00:39,882
Do I even need to bother with the cloud?

16
00:00:39,882 --> 00:00:44,072
So, in this episode we're not
gonna give you one reason.

17
00:00:44,072 --> 00:00:45,613
We're not gonna give you two reasons.

18
00:00:45,613 --> 00:00:50,140
We're gonna give you ten reasons
why you should be using the cloud.

19
00:00:50,140 --> 00:00:53,360
This'll be like a Dave Waterman
top ten list or whatever.

20
00:00:53,360 --> 00:00:55,506
>> You gonna throw in a set of
Ginsu knives with that, afterwards?

21
00:00:55,506 --> 00:00:58,680
>> [LAUGH] But wait,
there's more, order now.

22
00:00:58,680 --> 00:00:59,804
Offer expires while you wait.

23
00:00:59,804 --> 00:01:00,868
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

24
00:01:00,868 --> 00:01:02,045
>> So, what we're gonna do,

25
00:01:02,045 --> 00:01:04,260
is we're gonna run through
ten cloud strategies.

26
00:01:04,260 --> 00:01:08,079
These are different ways that we can
take advantage of the cloud to really

27
00:01:08,079 --> 00:01:09,152
make it work for us.

28
00:01:09,152 --> 00:01:13,347
There's certain things that the cloud
offers that a lot of us just can't do.

29
00:01:13,347 --> 00:01:17,252
You can't do it because you don't have the
staff, or you don't have the the money,

30
00:01:17,252 --> 00:01:18,080
in a lot of cases.

31
00:01:18,080 --> 00:01:20,798
I mean, these cloud vendors,
they got a ton of money,

32
00:01:20,798 --> 00:01:23,708
so there's things they can do
that we can't possibly do.

33
00:01:23,708 --> 00:01:26,270
And those are the things that
should be take advantage of.

34
00:01:26,270 --> 00:01:28,340
We should be using what
they have to offer.

35
00:01:28,340 --> 00:01:31,580
So, without further ado,
let's start with number one.

36
00:01:31,580 --> 00:01:36,820
My number one reason we should be
using the cloud is simply, redundancy.

37
00:01:36,820 --> 00:01:37,625
Redundancy.

38
00:01:37,625 --> 00:01:40,055
When you talk about a network.

39
00:01:40,055 --> 00:01:43,165
If one device fails,
you've gotta to go and fix it.

40
00:01:43,165 --> 00:01:44,825
You've gotta replace it and
as long as it's down,

41
00:01:44,825 --> 00:01:47,395
you've got users who might
not be able to function.

42
00:01:47,395 --> 00:01:50,715
So, we need redundancy from the cloud and

43
00:01:50,715 --> 00:01:53,355
that's something these cloud
providers do really well.

44
00:01:53,355 --> 00:01:54,295
Let me show you an example.

45
00:01:54,295 --> 00:01:57,105
I've got some slides from a tour
that Microsoft released from one of

46
00:01:57,105 --> 00:01:58,195
the Azure data centers.

47
00:01:58,195 --> 00:01:59,442
So, I've got it right here.

48
00:01:59,442 --> 00:02:02,470
And when I talk about redundancy.

49
00:02:02,470 --> 00:02:05,670
To me I'm like, well, if I have one hard
drive I should have two hard drives.

50
00:02:05,670 --> 00:02:06,770
That's redundancy.

51
00:02:06,770 --> 00:02:10,412
Microsoft says, why have one server,
when you can have a thousand?

52
00:02:10,412 --> 00:02:14,990
[LAUGH] And so you end up with these
data centers with tons of servers.

53
00:02:14,990 --> 00:02:17,050
If one server fails,
you don't even notice,

54
00:02:17,050 --> 00:02:21,300
cuz there's 999 more right there in
that same wall right alongside them.

55
00:02:22,330 --> 00:02:25,460
And what we're looking at here
is inside of a container.

56
00:02:25,460 --> 00:02:28,812
Why deploy one of those containers
when you can deploy 20 of the things?

57
00:02:28,812 --> 00:02:30,340
We're talking about 2400
severs per container.

58
00:02:30,340 --> 00:02:33,450
There's at least 10 containers right here.

59
00:02:33,450 --> 00:02:36,150
There's tens of thousands of servers.

60
00:02:36,150 --> 00:02:39,750
Why have one chiller cooling the air for
your service, when you could have two, or

61
00:02:39,750 --> 00:02:41,060
three, or four?

62
00:02:41,060 --> 00:02:42,950
Why, whoop, that's not what I wanted.

63
00:02:42,950 --> 00:02:44,133
We'll jump around slides.

64
00:02:44,133 --> 00:02:46,256
Why have one generator,
when you could have two?

65
00:02:46,256 --> 00:02:47,395
And this doesn't show it,

66
00:02:47,395 --> 00:02:50,030
but there's actually two more
back off the edge of this slide.

67
00:02:50,030 --> 00:02:51,950
If you take the actual
tour on Microsoft's site,

68
00:02:51,950 --> 00:02:54,360
you'll see the other ones in the picture.

69
00:02:54,360 --> 00:02:58,040
Why have one or two backup batteries
when you could have 1,000?

70
00:02:58,040 --> 00:03:02,600
Why have one main UPS unit
when you can have multiple?

71
00:03:02,600 --> 00:03:03,692
This is what they do.

72
00:03:03,692 --> 00:03:07,590
This is the redundancy that you get
when you go with a cloud provider.

73
00:03:07,590 --> 00:03:13,790
Somebody like Amazon EC2, Rackspace,
Microsoft Azure, these guys.

74
00:03:13,790 --> 00:03:15,322
They handle so many servers.

75
00:03:15,322 --> 00:03:15,850
They have so

76
00:03:15,850 --> 00:03:20,610
much redundancy that's well beyond what
most companies could even fathom doing.

77
00:03:20,610 --> 00:03:23,240
They've already done it cuz they
needed it for themselves anyway.

78
00:03:23,240 --> 00:03:24,510
And now you can take advantage of it.

79
00:03:24,510 --> 00:03:26,790
So, reason number one Redundancy.

80
00:03:26,790 --> 00:03:29,011
>> And this isn't Jimmy's
bargain bin stuff either.

81
00:03:29,011 --> 00:03:32,389
This is, like, top of the line equipment,
best stuff on the market, and

82
00:03:32,389 --> 00:03:33,874
they stay on top of that as well.

83
00:03:33,874 --> 00:03:36,960
>> Yeah absolutely.

84
00:03:36,960 --> 00:03:40,920
Reason number two is going
to be rapid provisioning.

85
00:03:40,920 --> 00:03:42,810
If I need a new server.

86
00:03:42,810 --> 00:03:46,731
Well, I can go to Dell's web site and
I can buy one.

87
00:03:46,731 --> 00:03:48,038
Like if I jump over to.

88
00:03:48,038 --> 00:03:50,310
Let's see,
do I have web browser open here somewhere?

89
00:03:50,310 --> 00:03:51,150
Sure I do.

90
00:03:51,150 --> 00:03:54,930
If I go to Dell's web site and
I go to buy a server, I can do that.

91
00:03:54,930 --> 00:03:56,692
I can go and
pick the components that I need.

92
00:03:56,692 --> 00:04:00,010
And we did this on another show, so
I'm not gonna waste too much time on it.

93
00:04:00,010 --> 00:04:04,120
But picking all the little options and
stuff, it gets a little crazy.

94
00:04:04,120 --> 00:04:07,584
And then when you do finally
pick the server that you want,

95
00:04:07,584 --> 00:04:09,781
it takes five to seven days to get it.

96
00:04:09,781 --> 00:04:12,264
So, if my CIO walks in here today and
says Don,

97
00:04:12,264 --> 00:04:14,710
we need a new web server up right now.

98
00:04:14,710 --> 00:04:16,590
I'm gonna say all right, well,
let me go spec a server out and

99
00:04:16,590 --> 00:04:17,340
find how much it costs.

100
00:04:17,340 --> 00:04:22,480
Let me go and
take that to the accounting division or

101
00:04:22,480 --> 00:04:24,110
whatever and get the funds approved.

102
00:04:24,110 --> 00:04:25,300
Let me get a purchase order.

103
00:04:25,300 --> 00:04:26,710
Let me send it to Dell.

104
00:04:26,710 --> 00:04:30,530
And then once Dell gets all that,
ships in five to seven business days.

105
00:04:30,530 --> 00:04:32,770
Now, that's ships in five
to seven business days.

106
00:04:32,770 --> 00:04:34,820
That's not counting the shipping
time on top of that.

107
00:04:34,820 --> 00:04:38,410
So, it's probably gonna take me about
two weeks to get that new server in.

108
00:04:38,410 --> 00:04:42,100
But with a cloud service, I just just
log-in to my cloud management portal and

109
00:04:42,100 --> 00:04:43,670
I tell it I need a new service.

110
00:04:43,670 --> 00:04:46,030
So, maybe I go into.

111
00:04:46,030 --> 00:04:48,540
Here, we'll jump over to Amazon.

112
00:04:48,540 --> 00:04:52,410
So, I jump over to Amazon, I go to EC2,
I tell it I need a new instance.

113
00:04:52,410 --> 00:04:56,770
I'll launch an instance, I tell it
I want Linux or Windows or Red Hat.

114
00:04:56,770 --> 00:04:59,710
I'll say Linux and
then I pick my hardware.

115
00:04:59,710 --> 00:05:01,930
Well, I need four processors and
15 gigs of RAM.

116
00:05:01,930 --> 00:05:03,340
Hook me up.

117
00:05:03,340 --> 00:05:06,930
And then I hit Review and
Launch, and Launch.

118
00:05:06,930 --> 00:05:07,990
I do have to pick a key pair.

119
00:05:07,990 --> 00:05:10,130
So, at least I guess I have to do that,
but I've already got one so

120
00:05:10,130 --> 00:05:11,870
that makes that nice and fast.

121
00:05:11,870 --> 00:05:12,700
And pow.

122
00:05:12,700 --> 00:05:13,280
Now I got a server.

123
00:05:14,620 --> 00:05:16,960
And now I'm just going to get billed for
that while I use it.

124
00:05:16,960 --> 00:05:19,670
I didn't have to do anything
crazy to get this done.

125
00:05:19,670 --> 00:05:21,950
I didn't have to wait two weeks for
it to ship.

126
00:05:21,950 --> 00:05:25,210
And better yet, I know that it was
deployed on that redundant network we just

127
00:05:25,210 --> 00:05:26,490
saw a minute ago.

128
00:05:26,490 --> 00:05:28,220
This is a pretty sweet implementation.

129
00:05:28,220 --> 00:05:31,051
>> Yeah, that's the way to fly
right there if you have the means.

130
00:05:31,051 --> 00:05:33,668
[LAUGH]
>> If you make use of this stuff,

131
00:05:33,668 --> 00:05:35,920
absolutely that's the way to do it.

132
00:05:35,920 --> 00:05:36,650
It's up in place.

133
00:05:36,650 --> 00:05:38,320
I can see I've got that running instance.

134
00:05:38,320 --> 00:05:40,760
It's booting up right now, and
it says it's initializing, but

135
00:05:40,760 --> 00:05:44,370
within about two minutes, that server's
up, running and ready to rock.

136
00:05:44,370 --> 00:05:46,820
>> Yeah,
normally that would take us hours.

137
00:05:46,820 --> 00:05:49,200
Once that server actually gets here,
then you gotta rack the thing,

138
00:05:49,200 --> 00:05:52,520
you gotta put the operating system on it,
any other software it needs.

139
00:05:52,520 --> 00:05:53,670
Don't forget the updates.

140
00:05:53,670 --> 00:05:54,900
Anti viruses, as well.

141
00:05:54,900 --> 00:05:56,260
And you're off to the races.

142
00:05:56,260 --> 00:05:57,550
That was a whole lot faster.

143
00:05:58,640 --> 00:05:59,875
>> All right, item number three.

144
00:05:59,875 --> 00:06:02,170
Availability.

145
00:06:02,170 --> 00:06:06,610
When you bring up a server, if you buy
the cheapest server on the planet, it's

146
00:06:06,610 --> 00:06:11,100
probably going to fail or have a shorter
mean time between failure, the old MTBF.

147
00:06:11,100 --> 00:06:12,730
And so you'll have an outage.

148
00:06:12,730 --> 00:06:15,620
If you buy really expensive high end
server, it'll probably go longer

149
00:06:15,620 --> 00:06:18,140
without a failure, but
you spent a lot of money for it.

150
00:06:18,140 --> 00:06:20,610
Well, when you sign up
with a cloud provider,

151
00:06:20,610 --> 00:06:23,210
they're offering you
service level agreements.

152
00:06:23,210 --> 00:06:25,760
So, for example, here is Rackspace.

153
00:06:25,760 --> 00:06:29,760
If you go and rent servers from Rackspace,

154
00:06:29,760 --> 00:06:32,840
these are the service level agreements

00:23:20,340 --> 00:23:24,079
They spread across both and it makes sense
because if one of them goes down they need

478
00:23:24,079 --> 00:23:27,112
to stay up and they don't want it
to reflect poorly on them like oh,

479
00:23:27,112 --> 00:23:29,270
Microsoft failed and Apple went down?

480
00:23:29,270 --> 00:23:30,990
Wait a minute,
they don't want people to know.

481
00:23:30,990 --> 00:23:32,110
That should be invisible.

482
00:23:32,110 --> 00:23:34,790
So if Microsoft goes down,
they're still running on Amazon.

483
00:23:34,790 --> 00:23:35,648
They're fine, right?

484
00:23:35,648 --> 00:23:38,220
You hedge your bets,
you run on more than one.

485
00:23:38,220 --> 00:23:42,310
But now you have the challenge of managing
more than one and if you want to do

486
00:23:42,310 --> 00:23:45,280
a solution like that you really need
to get a little more independent.

487
00:23:45,280 --> 00:23:48,310
And a great product for that,
let me show you guys this.

488
00:23:48,310 --> 00:23:51,100
There's a product called the Veeam,
or Veeam,

489
00:23:51,100 --> 00:23:53,730
different people say it different ways.

490
00:23:53,730 --> 00:23:56,960
But the Veeam Availability Suite, right?

491
00:23:56,960 --> 00:24:01,620
It's not inexpensive,
is probably a good way to put it.

492
00:24:01,620 --> 00:24:03,960
But it's worth it, it's worth the money.

493
00:24:03,960 --> 00:24:08,900
What these guys do, is they let you do
a backup strategy to set up hot sites and

494
00:24:08,900 --> 00:24:15,290
cloud recovery and they can support more
than one infrastructure on the backend.

495
00:24:15,290 --> 00:24:18,830
So if you want some of your stuff on
Azure and some of your stuff on S3,

496
00:24:18,830 --> 00:24:22,300
or all of your stuff completely cloned
between the two, they can do it,

497
00:24:22,300 --> 00:24:24,040
you manage it in one place.

498
00:24:24,040 --> 00:24:27,110
And so there's a lot of
solutions that are out there for

499
00:24:27,110 --> 00:24:31,519
people like this that help to provide
that functionality and capability, and

500
00:24:31,519 --> 00:24:33,530
make it a lot easier on you.

501
00:24:33,530 --> 00:24:37,350
But this is how you would get
the highest level of availability.

502
00:24:37,350 --> 00:24:41,615
If Microsoft has an issue, or
if Amazon has an issue, you're okay,

503
00:24:41,615 --> 00:24:43,460
because you're also doing
business with another provider.

504
00:24:43,460 --> 00:24:46,190
You've got Rackspace involved or
Media Temple or somebody else.

505
00:24:46,190 --> 00:24:49,770
So that you can draw in those systems and
flip over to them during an outage.

506
00:24:49,770 --> 00:24:52,210
So now, when you're watching the news and
you see, like, oh,

507
00:24:52,210 --> 00:24:53,050
AWS is having an outage.

508
00:24:53,050 --> 00:24:55,530
It's pretty rare, but it does happen.

509
00:24:55,530 --> 00:24:58,370
You can sit there and
say well all right we'll just

510
00:24:58,370 --> 00:25:01,710
increase capacity over here that's
on this other side and that's that.

511
00:25:01,710 --> 00:25:04,160
That's the joy of using the cloud.

512
00:25:04,160 --> 00:25:08,721
But don't feel like you're completely
safe if all of your servers are in one

513
00:25:08,721 --> 00:25:09,440
provider.

514
00:25:09,440 --> 00:25:13,652
Even though you spread them across regions
or whatever, it's still one provider.

515
00:25:13,652 --> 00:25:15,470
That is still a single point failure.

516
00:25:15,470 --> 00:25:19,300
>> Yeah, I guess the best way to go is
if you can do it have as many points of

517
00:25:19,300 --> 00:25:23,050
failure as possible so-
>> Have as many points of failure.

518
00:25:23,050 --> 00:25:24,060
That sounds really bad.

519
00:25:24,060 --> 00:25:25,728
>> I know it sounds really bad but
it's accurate.

520
00:25:25,728 --> 00:25:26,760
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right.

521
00:25:26,760 --> 00:25:30,450
Well Don, I think you've definitely
got us schooled up at least

522
00:25:30,450 --> 00:25:33,840
a good general understanding of
how we should be using these

523
00:25:33,840 --> 00:25:37,160
cloud services to increase
our business continuity.

524
00:25:37,160 --> 00:25:38,430
And that's what's important, right?

525
00:25:38,430 --> 00:25:40,740
Making sure that our
businesses are running and

526
00:25:40,740 --> 00:25:43,450
that data is available at any given time.

527
00:25:43,450 --> 00:25:46,475
As little downtime as possible is what
we're looking for, very awesome stuff.

528
00:25:46,475 --> 00:25:50,490
>> Yep, and hopefully that takes away some
of the the fear you guys have of using

529
00:25:50,490 --> 00:25:52,610
services like these,
if you have that fear.

530
00:25:52,610 --> 00:25:55,310
Some of you have already embraced it and
moved in.

531
00:25:55,310 --> 00:25:58,800
But even on the small of a home user
can take advantage of Amazon S3 or

532
00:25:58,800 --> 00:26:00,450
take advantage of Azure Storage.

533
00:26:00,450 --> 00:26:02,170
So you know you definitely do that.

534
00:26:02,170 --> 00:26:03,870
Don't lose your data when there are so

535
00:26:03,870 --> 00:26:07,480
many options out here that
are low risk and really low cost.

536
00:26:07,480 --> 00:26:10,590
>> Well Don, I guess that brings us to
the end of another great episode from

537
00:26:10,590 --> 00:26:12,110
ITProTV studios.

538
00:26:12,110 --> 00:26:12,870
Time to sign off.

539
00:26:12,870 --> 00:26:14,100
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

540
00:26:14,100 --> 00:26:15,110
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

541
00:26:15,110 --> 00:26:17,042
>> And we'll see you next time.

542
00:26:17,042 --> 00:26:22,060
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Service Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,526
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,526 --> 00:00:11,283
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11,283 --> 00:00:14,504
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,504 --> 00:00:16,509
I'll be your host today, Daniel Lowery.

5
00:00:16,509 --> 00:00:18,661
And with me as always is Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18,661 --> 00:00:19,660
How are doing today, Don?

7
00:00:19,660 --> 00:00:21,090
>> I am doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:21,090 --> 00:00:25,130
In this episode we're going to be tackling
a pretty important topic which is

9
00:00:25,130 --> 00:00:27,840
monitoring and service management,

10
00:00:27,840 --> 00:00:31,060
I guess is a nice good generic
name to stick on this.

11
00:00:31,060 --> 00:00:35,500
But basically it's when you
implement a solution in the cloud,

12
00:00:35,500 --> 00:00:38,560
how do you know that it's actually
as reliable as you think it is?

13
00:00:38,560 --> 00:00:41,430
We talk about all these great features and

14
00:00:41,430 --> 00:00:44,520
redundancies and availability
improvements that we get with a cloud.

15
00:00:44,520 --> 00:00:47,700
But how do you actually know it's
performing to the level that you think

16
00:00:47,700 --> 00:00:48,650
that it is?

17
00:00:48,650 --> 00:00:51,060
And it comes down to service management,
right?

18
00:00:51,060 --> 00:00:55,140
Managing how our systems are deployed,
how they run,

19
00:00:55,140 --> 00:00:57,640
recognizing when there's issues and
correcting for that, and so

20
00:00:57,640 --> 00:01:00,130
it's just a number of little
techniques we need to apply.

21
00:01:00,130 --> 00:01:05,350
Think of this episode as the follow-up
to finishing your movement to the cloud.

22
00:01:05,350 --> 00:01:08,020
You've just got all your stuff put
in the cloud, now what do you do?

23
00:01:08,020 --> 00:01:11,605
Well, you maintain and
you continue operating, and

24
00:01:11,605 --> 00:01:14,975
that all falls under this kind of
umbrella term of service management.

25
00:01:14,975 --> 00:01:16,085
>> So would you say this is

26
00:01:16,085 --> 00:01:18,365
basically making sure you're
getting what you paid for?

27
00:01:18,365 --> 00:01:19,045
>> Absolutely.

28
00:01:19,045 --> 00:01:20,174
>> Awesome.
>> Absolutely, yeah.

29
00:01:20,174 --> 00:01:22,243
The cloud providers, they make promises.

30
00:01:22,243 --> 00:01:23,502
Make a lot of promises.

31
00:01:23,502 --> 00:01:27,120
[LAUGH] And in their defense,
most of the time they live up to them, but

32
00:01:27,120 --> 00:01:28,250
sometimes they don't.

33
00:01:28,250 --> 00:01:32,320
And so we've got to make sure that we've
got systems that let us recognize that.

34
00:01:32,320 --> 00:01:35,040
All right, so we're going to talk about
a few of those here in this episode, just

35
00:01:35,040 --> 00:01:38,535
talk about a few different things that
we need to be aware of as we implement.

36
00:01:38,535 --> 00:01:41,785
And I wanna start with monitoring and
SLAs.

37
00:01:41,785 --> 00:01:42,745
All right?

38
00:01:42,745 --> 00:01:47,775
SLAs are Service Level Agreements,
and basically when you sign up for

39
00:01:47,775 --> 00:01:55,330
a cloud service like Amazon EC2, inside of
AWS, or Microsoft Azure, you spin up a VM.

40
00:01:55,330 --> 00:01:56,890
They make a guarantee to you.

41
00:01:56,890 --> 00:02:01,820
They tell you that they're gonna provide
a world class infrastructure with a world

42
00:02:01,820 --> 00:02:06,160
class team of IT guys working behind it,
keeping it up and running and that you're

43
00:02:06,160 --> 00:02:10,930
going to get that same level of service
that you'd expect from that kind of thing.

44
00:02:10,930 --> 00:02:13,670
Well at the end of the day,
they do a great job of that, right.

45
00:02:13,670 --> 00:02:16,930
They literally do have world class data
centers, and they literally do have

46
00:02:16,930 --> 00:02:20,770
the best of the best of the network
engineers and sys admins working for them.

47
00:02:20,770 --> 00:02:22,205
But problems still happen.

48
00:02:22,205 --> 00:02:24,255
So we need to be able
to keep an eye on that.

49
00:02:24,255 --> 00:02:26,285
And let me just show you
guys an example here.

50
00:02:26,285 --> 00:02:28,455
I'm pulling up, this is Rackspace.

51
00:02:28,455 --> 00:02:32,145
And the Rackspace guys,
they're are a big data provider out there,

52
00:02:32,145 --> 00:02:34,510
a lot of people host their
servers with Rackspace.

53
00:02:34,510 --> 00:02:37,390
And they publish their SLAs
right on their website.

54
00:02:37,390 --> 00:02:42,190
So I'm just here on Rackspace's web
page under their legal section, and

55
00:02:42,190 --> 00:02:44,200
they have different
service level agreements,

56
00:02:44,200 --> 00:02:47,580
depending on what it is that
you're buying from them, right?

57
00:02:47,580 --> 00:02:51,530
So if I'm doing cloud servers,
I'll just jump here to cloud Servers.

58
00:02:51,530 --> 00:02:53,830
They talk about the network
infrastructure, and

59
00:02:53,830 --> 00:02:57,190
they guarantee that the network
will be available 100% of the time.

60
00:02:57,190 --> 00:03:01,013
In other words, they feel that they've
done enough redundancy in their network

61
00:03:01,013 --> 00:03:02,989
topology, that they'll never go down.

62
00:03:02,989 --> 00:03:06,060
And then, their data center
infrastructure, their air conditioning,

63
00:03:06,060 --> 00:03:08,941
and other resources there,
will be available 100 % of the time.

64
00:03:08,941 --> 00:03:12,120
Their cloud server hosts,
the physical servers.

65
00:03:12,120 --> 00:03:13,970
If there's a failure there they'll fix it.

66
00:03:13,970 --> 00:03:16,320
Failures will happen,
that's what they're saying here, right?

67
00:03:16,320 --> 00:03:17,650
There's no 100% on this one.

68
00:03:17,650 --> 00:03:20,180
Failures will happen, but
they'll resolve it, and

69
00:03:20,180 --> 00:03:21,840
you won't have to get involved, right?

70
00:03:21,840 --> 00:03:23,400
Same thing with migrations.

71
00:03:23,400 --> 00:03:25,010
And they talk about credits.

72
00:03:25,010 --> 00:03:26,400
If they don't live up to that.

73
00:03:26,400 --> 00:03:28,700
If there is some kind of a failure.

74
00:03:28,700 --> 00:03:32,130
Let me see if I can zoom
in on that a little bit.

75
00:03:32,130 --> 00:03:36,560
If there is some kind of a failure, right,
for data center infrastructure 5% of

76
00:03:36,560 --> 00:03:40,350
the cloud server fees for each 30 minutes
of infrastructure downtime up to 100% of

77
00:03:40,350 --> 00:03:44,190
the cloud server fees will be
credited to your account, right?

78
00:03:44,190 --> 00:03:46,922
So they know that
a problem could happen and

79
00:03:46,922 --> 00:03:48,710
they're gonna offer you credits for it.

80
00:03:48,710 --> 00:03:50,930
Well, they'll monitor for that, right?

81
00:03:50,930 --> 00:03:53,140
And they'll tell you,
and they'll credit you.

82
00:03:53,140 --> 00:03:55,830
But don't you need to be sure?

83
00:03:55,830 --> 00:03:57,300
I have this happen with my cable company.

84
00:03:57,300 --> 00:04:00,330
My cable company, they say, oh, yeah,
we'll credit you if there's an outage.

85
00:04:00,330 --> 00:04:01,380
Outages happen all the time.

86
00:04:01,380 --> 00:04:03,707
I mean, once a week my cable, it stinks.

87
00:04:03,707 --> 00:04:06,740
[LAUGH] So it happens all the time,
and they never credit me.

88
00:04:06,740 --> 00:04:07,370
And so I call them.

89
00:04:07,370 --> 00:04:09,120
I say, hey guys, I had this outage,
and they go, oh yeah, here,

90
00:04:09,120 --> 00:04:10,160
we'll credit your account.

91
00:04:10,160 --> 00:04:10,790
I've always gotta ask them.

92
00:04:10,790 --> 00:04:14,470
It's cuz they're a terrible company,
right, and that's how it is.

93
00:04:14,470 --> 00:04:16,100
Rackspace, on the other hand,
they're a great company.

94
00:04:16,100 --> 00:04:18,090
They're very proactive about it.

95
00:04:18,090 --> 00:04:19,620
Amazon, Microsoft.

96
00:04:19,620 --> 00:04:20,870
But we need to monitor it too.

97
00:04:20,870 --> 00:04:21,860
All right?

98
00:04:21,860 --> 00:04:23,520
I need to know if my server's down.

99
00:04:23,520 --> 00:04:26,880
If I have a server failure,
Rackspace is gonna take care of it for me.

100
00:04:26,880 --> 00:04:31,080
But I need to know that it happened, cuz
there might be downtime involved in that.

101
00:04:31,080 --> 00:04:32,980
So we need to have ways to watch for that.

102
00:04:32,980 --> 00:04:35,310
And there's several different ways.

103
00:04:35,310 --> 00:04:36,640
You can go about this
a few different ways.

104
00:04:36,640 --> 00:04:39,100
Now, there's monitoring solutions

105
00:04:39,100 --> 00:04:42,090
built into a lot of these
providers that you could use.

106
00:04:42,090 --> 00:04:45,710
So, if I wanted to monitor
my Amazon EC2 stuff, right?

107
00:04:45,710 --> 00:04:48,710
So like here I've got two
instances running in Amazon EC2.

108
00:04:48,710 --> 00:04:51,820
There's itprotv-web01 and web02.

109
00:04:51,820 --> 00:04:52,970
I want to monitor them.

110
00:04:52,970 --> 00:04:56,050
I want to know when they're up and
healthy and when they're not healthy.

111
00:04:56,050 --> 00:04:57,370
Well Amazon monitors that.

112
00:04:57,370 --> 00:05:01,230
I've got my little instance state
right there, it's running, great.

113
00:05:01,230 --> 00:05:05,020
But just being on isn't enough, right.

114
00:05:05,020 --> 00:05:09,420
Just having a server running isn't
necessarily exactly what I need.

115
00:05:09,420 --> 00:05:10,920
I need to know more about it.

116
00:05:10,920 --> 00:05:13,710
I need to know performance metrics and
other things.

117
00:05:13,710 --> 00:05:17,700
So for that, we can enable their
service called CloudWatch, and

118
00:05:17,700 --> 00:05:21,890
CloudWatch gives us detailed metrics
of how that server's operating and

119
00:05:21,890 --> 00:05:23,420
it records them historically.

120
00:05:23,420 --> 00:05:26,350
This is just a screen that I see,
it's running great.

121
00:05:26,350 --> 00:05:27,290
I need a history.

122
00:05:27,290 --> 00:05:29,390
I need to know how that's been doing.

123
00:05:29,390 --> 00:05:34,260
Not just for service level agreements,
but also for my own planning, right.

124
00:05:34,260 --> 00:05:37,940
There's a life cycle that all of our
solutions go through it and as more and

125
00:05:37,940 --> 00:05:42,230
more customers start to use your software,
the resources need to increase too.

126
00:05:42,230 --> 00:05:43,280
It's part of the life cycles.

127
00:05:43,280 --> 00:05:48,240
We have to increase the resources,
but how do I know when the increase?

128
00:05:48,240 --> 00:05:49,110
I don't, I need to monitor that.

129
00:05:49,110 --> 00:05:53,050
Now there's certain things that
are monitored by Amazon by default and

130
00:05:53,050 --> 00:05:54,340
it's things they bill for.

131
00:05:54,340 --> 00:05:56,570
Right.
They monitor disk IO.

132
00:05:56,570 --> 00:06:01,710
They monitor bandwidth and they monitor
how many CPU cores you're using.

133
00:06:01,710 --> 00:06:05,320
But they don't monitor things like what
processes are eating up your CPU or

134
00:06:05,320 --> 00:06:08,750
how much RAM you're using, because they
just give you a fixed amount of RAM.

135
00:06:08,750 --> 00:06:12,390
They don't monitor details like that,
it's up to us to monitor them.

136
00:06:12,390 --> 00:06:13,960
And so we have two choices.

137
00:06:13,960 --> 00:06:16,850
One, we can use advanced
tools from the vendor.

138
00:06:16,850 --> 00:06:19,525
If you trust the vendor,
you can use their tools, and that's great.

139
00:06:19,525 --> 00:06:23,010
Or two,
you can use Use third party tools, and

140
00:06:23,010 --> 00:06:26,060
there's no end to the amount of
third party solutions out there

141
00:06:26,060 --> 00:06:30,320
that allow you to be able to monitor and
see what's going on in your systems.

142
00:06:30,320 --> 00:06:33,750
Companies like RightScale,
Veeam, SolarWinds, these guys,

143
00:06:33,750 --> 00:06:35,700
they all make great monitoring solutions.

144
00:06:35,700 --> 00:06:37,040
They'll let you see how
your servers are doing.

145
00:06:38,250 --> 00:06:41,160
So in this show, I want to start
by showing us the monitoring,

146
00:06:41,160 --> 00:06:44,030
we'll do it from within Amazon, so we'll
get a chance to check out how they do it.

147
00:06:44,030 --> 00:06:46,640
And then I'll show you a third
party monitoring solution also.

148
00:06:46,640 --> 00:06:49,320
And then we'll double back and
kinda touch on that whole

149
00:06:49,320 --> 00:06:52,550
lifecycle thing cuz That's pretty
important inside of our cloud environment.

150
00:06:54,060 --> 00:06:55,770
All right, so, these instances.

151
00:06:55,770 --> 00:06:58,290
I wanna learn more about these instances.

152
00:06:58,290 --> 00:07:01,500
Well, Amazon's only gonna monitor
what it requires for billing.

153
00:07:01,500 --> 00:07:03,090
If I want more, I've gotta tell them that.

154
00:07:03,090 --> 00:07:04,830
So let me show you how that's done.

155
00:07:04,830 --> 00:07:07,730
I've got this second instance here,
itprotv-web02.

156
00:07:07,730 --> 00:07:12,380
And if I select it, and I look down
in this information here in the bar,

157
00:07:12,380 --> 00:07:16,230
I can see its ID,
information about it as far as its name.

158
00:07:16,230 --> 00:07:19,210
And then under Alarm Status,
see how I've got this None.

159
00:07:19,210 --> 00:07:22,070
There's no alarm attached to it,
there's no

160
00:07:22,070 --> 00:07:26,010
detailed tracking of this system if
a problem occurs, there's nothing.

161
00:07:26,010 --> 00:07:29,220
Amazon's gonna take care of problems and
I may or

162
00:07:29,220 --> 00:07:32,900
may not even know about it, depending on
how quickly they resolve the problem.

163
00:07:32,900 --> 00:07:36,010
Well, down here as I look at
the details for that system,

164
00:07:36,010 --> 00:07:40,690
you can see all sorts of information about
it and what we're monitoring and so on.

165

00:29:58,270 --> 00:30:01,100
making sure we're keeping an eye on
the things that we're trying to watch.

623
00:30:01,100 --> 00:30:02,750
And to make sure that
it's running correctly.

624
00:30:02,750 --> 00:30:08,410
Because, it is real easy for us to kind
of sit back and let the show run itself.

625
00:30:08,410 --> 00:30:09,460
Not really what you wanna do.

626
00:30:09,460 --> 00:30:11,520
And it's great that the cloud services,

627
00:30:11,520 --> 00:30:14,550
they do provide us at least
some type of monitoring.

628
00:30:14,550 --> 00:30:16,370
And there are third-party apps as well.

629
00:30:16,370 --> 00:30:20,040
So, we can even do like a hybrid
type of deal if you need to do that.

630
00:30:20,040 --> 00:30:21,180
Very great stuff.

631
00:30:21,180 --> 00:30:23,520
Have we covered the basics on this?

632
00:30:23,520 --> 00:30:24,310
>> Yeah.
That's basically it.

633
00:30:24,310 --> 00:30:26,053
I mean,
obviously there's a lot more details for

634
00:30:26,053 --> 00:30:27,690
monitoring particular services and stuff.

635
00:30:27,690 --> 00:30:30,160
But for this episode,
we're trying to stay general.

636
00:30:30,160 --> 00:30:31,041
That's a pretty good [CROSSTALK].

637
00:30:31,041 --> 00:30:31,700
>> Awesome.

638
00:30:31,700 --> 00:30:32,980
Well I guess, that being said,

639
00:30:32,980 --> 00:30:36,670
we've come to the end of another great
episode signing off for ITProTV.

640
00:30:36,670 --> 00:30:38,480
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

641
00:30:38,480 --> 00:30:39,440
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

642
00:30:39,440 --> 00:30:41,138
>> We'll see you next time.

643
00:30:41,138 --> 00:30:46,172
