episodes.title: Introduction to AWS
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:01,060 --> 00:00:10,661
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,661 --> 00:00:11,920
>> All right, everyone.

3
00:00:11,920 --> 00:00:14,540
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,540 --> 00:00:16,140
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowery.

5
00:00:16,140 --> 00:00:17,602
Here with me today is Don Pazet.

6
00:00:17,602 --> 00:00:18,540
How you doing today, Don?

7
00:00:18,540 --> 00:00:19,660
>> I am doing great.

8
00:00:19,660 --> 00:00:21,744
I'm excited to launch
into this episode and

9
00:00:21,744 --> 00:00:24,400
we're gonna start talking
about Amazon Web Services.

10
00:00:24,400 --> 00:00:27,840
Great services available out there
as a cloud hosting provider and

11
00:00:27,840 --> 00:00:30,801
something that people really
need to get introduced to.

12
00:00:30,801 --> 00:00:33,660
>> Yeah.

13
00:00:33,660 --> 00:00:34,700
AWS Amazon, they handle some
pretty heavy hitters out there.

14
00:00:34,700 --> 00:00:37,600
So don't just think that oh,
I'm too little, I don't need AWS.

15
00:00:37,600 --> 00:00:40,701
They'll go from just as small as you
wanna be to as large as you wanna be.

16
00:00:40,701 --> 00:00:45,020
I know Netflix is one of their
their users and stuff like that.

17
00:00:45,020 --> 00:00:46,380
Very, very scalable.

18
00:00:46,380 --> 00:00:51,146
>> Yeah, it's funny when when you think
about a cloud data center provider,

19
00:00:51,146 --> 00:00:56,381
you wouldn't think of an online e-retailer
as the person who would head that up.

20
00:00:56,381 --> 00:01:00,222
You'd think of companies,
like Microsoft or Dell, HP.

21
00:01:00,222 --> 00:01:06,120
Those are companies that have supported
data centers for years and years.

22
00:01:06,120 --> 00:01:07,537
Why aren't they at the head of that curve?

23
00:01:07,537 --> 00:01:11,758
And the reason is that curve didn't
really exist before what Amazon did and

24
00:01:11,758 --> 00:01:14,042
what happened at Amazon is pretty neat.

25
00:01:14,042 --> 00:01:17,381
Amazon is the largest online
retailer in the world.

26
00:01:17,381 --> 00:01:19,657
They handle more transactions
than anybody else and

27
00:01:19,657 --> 00:01:23,180
they have customers all over the globe,
that requires a lot of infrastructure.

28
00:01:23,180 --> 00:01:27,528
So they have to have a lot of servers and
databases and high redundancy,

29
00:01:27,528 --> 00:01:32,540
high availability, all over the globe to
support just their online store front.

30
00:01:32,540 --> 00:01:34,140
Amazon has no physical stores.

31
00:01:34,140 --> 00:01:38,500
So if their website goes down,
they stop making money.

32
00:01:38,500 --> 00:01:40,320
It's real important for
that to be up and stable.

33
00:01:40,320 --> 00:01:44,038
So as they built that out for
themselves, they built out a lot of

34
00:01:44,038 --> 00:01:47,055
great infrastructure and
a lot of it was overkill,

35
00:01:47,055 --> 00:01:51,640
cuz they had to be able to handle all
the peaks of customer activity and stuff.

36
00:01:51,640 --> 00:01:56,130
So they looked at it, they said,
we build out this great infrastructure.

37
00:01:56,130 --> 00:02:00,492
We don't use all of it, we could recoup
some of that cost by renting it out to

38
00:02:00,492 --> 00:02:05,139
other people and that's kind of how Amazon
Web Services started was renting out

39
00:02:05,139 --> 00:02:07,110
excess resources that they had.

40
00:02:07,110 --> 00:02:10,987
And in the early, early days,
you just got what were called spot,

41
00:02:10,987 --> 00:02:14,811
which was if Amazon wasn't using
their server, then you could.

42
00:02:14,811 --> 00:02:16,550
But if Amazon was using it,
you didn't get it.

43
00:02:16,550 --> 00:02:21,139
But as time went on, this became its
own self-sustaining business unit and

44
00:02:21,139 --> 00:02:25,729
they started adding servers dedicated
just for AWS, resources that Amazon

45
00:02:25,729 --> 00:02:29,674
themselves didn't use that they
made available to the public and

46
00:02:29,674 --> 00:02:33,530
it turned into a multibillion
dollar operation for them.

47
00:02:33,530 --> 00:02:37,180
And now they handle clients big and
small, large, small.

48
00:02:37,180 --> 00:02:40,280
Tons of information moves
through Amazon every single day.

49
00:02:40,280 --> 00:02:43,590
They are the single largest
online data center provider now.

50
00:02:43,590 --> 00:02:46,390
>> Yeah, they've definitely
got a great thing going.

51
00:02:46,390 --> 00:02:49,912
You wouldn't think these book sellers
would have such an infrastructure

52
00:02:49,912 --> 00:02:53,034
built up, but it really makes sense
when you start thinking about

53
00:02:53,034 --> 00:02:56,440
like what Don was just saying,
that they needed that online presence,

54
00:02:56,440 --> 00:02:59,310
they needed to have that presence
that would never go down.

55
00:02:59,310 --> 00:03:02,931
Or at least if it ever did,
very, very, minimal time.

56
00:03:02,931 --> 00:03:05,810
So having that leftover and
we all know about that.

57
00:03:05,810 --> 00:03:09,114
If you've worked in any data center,
even a small one, you say, hey,

58
00:03:09,114 --> 00:03:12,050
I've actually got to buy a server and
I'm not not using it all.

59
00:03:12,050 --> 00:03:15,167
Maybe we're running a website and
I need two servers,

60
00:03:15,167 --> 00:03:17,411
because one won't do it at peak times.

61
00:03:17,411 --> 00:03:21,215
So I have one server basically sitting
around all day instead of being used until

62
00:03:21,215 --> 00:03:22,804
those peak times come around, so

63
00:03:22,804 --> 00:03:26,290
that's when it's things like
Amazon Web Services comes in real handy.

64
00:03:26,290 --> 00:03:27,050
>> Yeah and even beyond just the servers.

65
00:03:27,050 --> 00:03:32,711
When you build your own data center,
you've gotta have UPSs, battery backups.

66
00:03:32,711 --> 00:03:35,483
Maybe even generators in case
your building loses power,

67
00:03:35,483 --> 00:03:37,130
redundant network connections.

68
00:03:37,130 --> 00:03:40,038
You might only have one
internet service provider,

69
00:03:40,038 --> 00:03:43,950
you really need two or maybe more to
make sure that you get redundancy.

70
00:03:43,950 --> 00:03:45,951
If one Internet link goes down,
you got another one.

71
00:03:45,951 --> 00:03:49,512
You need bandwidth and
that bandwidth might be variable too.

72
00:03:49,512 --> 00:03:52,211
All these different things that
you need that add to a cost.

73
00:03:52,211 --> 00:03:53,470
Well, Amazon already has all that stuff.

74
00:03:53,470 --> 00:03:55,370
They've already got it,
because they need it.

75
00:03:55,370 --> 00:03:58,670
They've got redundant power connections
coming from multiple power companies.

76
00:03:58,670 --> 00:04:02,831
They've got not just one or two, but like
five different ISPs that are feeding each

77
00:04:02,831 --> 00:04:06,110
of their data centers and
we can just piggyback right off of that.

78
00:04:06,110 --> 00:04:10,450
That's the real benefit of using AWS
is moving our resources at the bare

79
00:04:10,450 --> 00:04:15,442
infrastructure and taking advantage of
things that either we couldn't afford or

80
00:04:15,442 --> 00:04:18,790
that we could afford, but
we don't want to maintain.

81
00:04:18,790 --> 00:04:23,250
And we want somebody else to maintain that
for us and that's exactly what AWS does.

82
00:04:23,250 --> 00:04:26,569
>> Yeah, now one of the biggest benefits
I've seen from them is the fact that they

83
00:04:26,569 --> 00:04:27,890
have these regions and zones.

84
00:04:27,890 --> 00:04:31,951
I don't have to have just one
spot where I have my data.

85
00:04:31,951 --> 00:04:33,372
I can say well, you know what?

86
00:04:33,372 --> 00:04:36,031
The East Coast might get hit by
a hurricane, we live in Florida.

87
00:04:36,031 --> 00:04:39,671
A very good possibility, something
could happen and my data could be lost.

88
00:04:39,671 --> 00:04:42,502
Well, if I use multiple zones
somewhere geographically,

89
00:04:42,502 --> 00:04:44,551
completely different from where I'm at.

90
00:04:44,551 --> 00:04:47,570
That's gonna give that
availability a whole lot better.

91
00:04:47,570 --> 00:04:49,730
>> Yeah,
let's talk about those terms a little bit.

92
00:04:49,730 --> 00:04:54,664
So when you start working with Amazon Web
Services, you're gonna see regions and

93
00:04:54,664 --> 00:04:56,032
availability zones.

94
00:04:56,032 --> 00:04:58,911
Those two terms or
people usually just call them zones.

95
00:04:58,911 --> 00:05:01,231
So regions and zones what does that mean?

96
00:05:01,231 --> 00:05:05,250
Well, a region is referring
to a geographic region.

97
00:05:05,250 --> 00:05:09,265
Amazon tries to have data centers in
all the major areas in the world,

98
00:05:09,265 --> 00:05:11,900
where we have high degrees of traffic.

99
00:05:11,900 --> 00:05:12,760
So they show them all on their web page.

100
00:05:12,760 --> 00:05:14,201
I've got that,
let's take a look at this page.

101
00:05:14,201 --> 00:05:17,329
This is the global infrastructure for
Amazon Web Services and

102
00:05:17,329 --> 00:05:18,961
they divide it up by continent.

103
00:05:18,961 --> 00:05:21,847
So here's the North American continent and

104
00:05:21,847 --> 00:05:26,840
each of these yellow circles that are on
here, which they are kind of small.

105
00:05:26,840 --> 00:05:28,427
There we go.
Each of the yellow circles

106
00:05:28,427 --> 00:05:29,701
represent the data center.

107
00:05:29,701 --> 00:05:32,861
So here in North America,
we actually have four data centers.

108
00:05:32,861 --> 00:05:36,162
One over here in Virginia,
one in California,

109
00:05:36,162 --> 00:05:39,721
one up in Oregon and
one in Washington, I believe.

110
00:05:39,721 --> 00:05:42,481
So you've got these four data,
well, I don't have to guess.

111
00:05:42,481 --> 00:05:44,353
They actually got them written right here.

112
00:05:44,353 --> 00:05:49,735
[LAUGH] Virginia, North Carolina,
Oregon and oh, the Government Cloud one,

113
00:05:49,735 --> 00:05:53,578
which is also kind of tucked
away up there in Northwest.

114
00:05:53,578 --> 00:05:54,141
So those are the four
that are here in the US.

115
00:05:54,141 --> 00:05:58,641
In other continents,
they have more data centers.

116
00:05:58,641 --> 00:06:02,816
And so if I scroll down here and get past
through a little advertisement blurbs,

117
00:06:02,816 --> 00:06:07,304
here's South America, where they've got
just one data center right down there in,

118
00:06:07,304 --> 00:06:08,761
I believe it's San Paolo.

119
00:06:08,761 --> 00:06:11,979
And if we take a look at other continents,
like here's Europe,

120
00:06:11,979 --> 00:06:13,241
Middle East and Africa.

121
00:06:13,241 --> 00:06:18,440
They've got data centers that are [LAUGH]
as I jump around my continents.

122
00:06:18,440 --> 00:06:23,500
There we go.
In England and in, where is that?

123
00:06:23,500 --> 00:06:25,861
France maybe or?

124
00:06:25,861 --> 00:06:26,761
>> Spain?
>> Yeah, something.

125
00:06:26,761 --> 00:06:30,341
So you've got these data centers that
are spread out and then in Asia.

126
00:06:30,341 --> 00:06:36,080
So for the Asia Pacific region, we've
got Australia, Singapore, China, Japan.

127
00:06:36,080 --> 00:06:38,050
So these data centers that are out there.

128
00:06:38,050 --> 00:06:43,860
Now when you spin up a server in AWS,
you can pick any one of those regions.

129
00:06:43,860 --> 00:06:46,790
So using Daniel's example,
we're in Florida,

130
00:06:46,790 --> 00:06:48,821
we're on the East Coast of the US.

131
00:06:48,821 --> 00:06:52,394
So when you take a look at
that North American layout, so

132
00:06:52,394 --> 00:06:54,761
if I go backup here to North America.

133
00:06:54,761 --> 00:06:58,270
Well, they have a data center
that's there in Virginia and

134
00:06:58,270 --> 00:06:59,961
I might want to use that one.

135
00:06:59,961 --> 00:07:01,890
Virginia, that's not too far away.

136
00:07:03,000 --> 00:07:06,890
But if a hurricane hits Florida,
it could hit Virginia also.

137
00:07:06,890 --> 00:07:09,991
So if a hurricane hits Florida,
it might hit Virginia also.

138
00:07:09,991 --> 00:07:12,350
So when I go to deploy servers,
I might put some in Virginia,

139
00:07:12,350 --> 00:07:13,291
cuz they're close by.

140
00:07:13,291 --> 00:07:15,437
Maybe I get better
performance out of that, but

141
00:07:15,437 --> 00:07:17,592
I might choose to put on
over in California too.

142
00:07:17,592 --> 00:07:19,919
So, I've spread them out
across those data centers or

143
00:07:19,919 --> 00:07:22,611
if I've got a lot of customers
that are in Europe or Australia.

144
00:07:22,611 --> 00:07:27,145
I might want to put some of my
servers in those regions to get them

145
00:07:27,145 --> 00:07:30,151
closer to my customer geolocating them.

146
00:07:30,151 --> 00:07:32,571
I don't have to go and
build a data center there.

147
00:07:32,571 --> 00:07:35,435
If all of a sudden I have a lot
of new customers in Australia,

148
00:07:35,435 --> 00:07:38,951
I don't want to build a data center
in Australia, it's a long way away.

149
00:07:38,951 --> 00:07:41,751
I don't even, I've never been there.

150
00:07:41,751 --> 00:07:45,451
But I don't have to,
cuz I can just use Amazon's Web Services.

151
00:07:45,451 --> 00:07:47,851
I can just throw services out there,
and now, they're close to the customer.

152
00:07:47,851 --> 00:07:50,812
That's a big benefit.

153
00:07:50,812 --> 00:07:55,412
Now, each of these data centers
has a little bit more to it.

154
00:07:55,412 --> 00:07:58,696
Notice how we've got these yellow circles
and then there's these blue circles also.

155
00:07:58,696 --> 00:08:03,342
Right, those are called edge locations,
and when you have a data center,

156
00:08:03,342 --> 00:08:08,092
that's a big investment for Amazon to
make one of these giant data centers.

157
00:08:08,092 --> 00:08:10,983
What if you're in a city that's not
big enough to have a data center but

158
00:08:10,983 --> 00:08:13,560
you still have a lot of
customer activity there.

159
00:08:13,560 --> 00:08:18,040
Well, what Amazon does is they
build these edge locations.

160
00:08:18,040 --> 00:08:23,930
And what it means is there's direct fiber
connections between these locations and

161
00:08:23,930 --> 00:08:25,280
one of their data centers.

162
00:08:25,280 --> 00:08:29,870
So if you're in that area, you can hit
that edge and it will jump you right over

163
00:08:29,870 --> 00:08:33,230
to one of the data centers like a fast
track speed lane to get to a data center.

164
00:08:33,230 --> 00:08:36,990
So sure you don't have a region defined
right there like this one in Texas.

165
00:08:36,990 --> 00:08:38,730
You don't have one right there in Texas.

166
00:08:38,730 --> 00:08:40,800
There's a ton of tech companies there.

167
00:08:40,800 --> 00:08:43,550
They can hit that edge location, and
they'll jump on right over to that

168
00:08:43,550 --> 00:08:46,580
California location, and
it's as if the data center were nearby.

169
00:08:46,580 --> 00:08:48,400
So really kind of cuts that path and

170
00:08:48,400 --> 00:08:52,210
that's what you'll see in some of the
various continents where there's a lot of

171
00:08:52,210 --> 00:08:55,260
edge locations to get you to
a smaller amount of data centers.

172
00:08:55,260 --> 00:08:57,930
>> Yeah, what's interesting about what
you're saying about your customers,

173
00:08:57,930 --> 00:09:00,200
you never know where your product or

174
00:09:00,200 --> 00:09:04,200
your website might start getting
a lot of popularity, and I've never

175
00:09:04,200 --> 00:09:08,400
been Australia either, and I'm sure that
it would cost me quite a bit of money to

176
00:09:08,400 --> 00:09:12,240
actually have to set up a data center
there for my own website if I wanted

177
00:09:12,240 --> 00:09:16,240
to increase that traffic connectivity
when I can just go, hey Amazon,

178
00:09:16,240 --> 00:09:20,225
why don't you throw another server on
there for me, on the barbie as it were.

179
00:09:20,225 --> 00:09:21,878
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right, so

180
00:09:21,878 --> 00:09:23,770
now those are regions, right?

181
00:09:23,770 --> 00:09:26,490
And regions are effectively data centers,
right?

182
00:09:26,490 --> 00:09:29,990
And so just looking at North America here
we've got the US East region, right,

183
00:09:29,990 --> 00:09:31,412
that's in northern Virginia.

184
00:09:31,412 --> 00:09:35,130
We have the US West Region in California,
the other US West region,

185
00:09:35,130 --> 00:09:36,540
which is in Oregon.

186
00:09:36,540 --> 00:09:38,980
So, few different choices there.

187
00:09:38,980 --> 00:09:44,580
Inside of each region, you then
have availability zones, or zones.

188
00:09:44,580 --> 00:09:49,620
Notice how in the US East region,
there are five availability zones.

189
00:09:49,620 --> 00:09:51,148
Now, what's an availability zone?

190
00:09:51,148 --> 00:09:56,040
Well, a zone is actually a data center,
and so what they're saying here is that in

191
00:09:56,040 --> 00:09:59,080
northern Virginia there's
actually five data centers.

192
00:09:59,080 --> 00:10:04,070
Five completely independent data
centers that have separate power,

193
00:10:04,070 --> 00:10:06,850
separate networks,
separate infrastructure, so

194
00:10:06,850 --> 00:10:11,050
that if an entire data center fails, well,
there's four more of the things, right?

195
00:10:11,050 --> 00:10:12,940
Then they've got a little asterisk here.

196
00:10:12,940 --> 00:10:13,883
Some of them are full.

197
00:10:13,883 --> 00:10:17,843
So if you're a new customer in northern
Virginia, there's actually only three that

198
00:10:17,843 --> 00:10:20,713
are available for you to use right
now cuz the others are full.

199
00:10:20,713 --> 00:10:23,003
So you don't always have access
to all five of them, but

200
00:10:23,003 --> 00:10:25,580
there are technically five
in Northern Virginia.

201
00:10:25,580 --> 00:10:29,180
In the US West Region, California,
there's only three and

202
00:10:29,180 --> 00:10:30,510
you'll see some of these other ones.

203
00:10:30,510 --> 00:10:31,550
In Oregon there's three,

204
00:10:31,550 --> 00:10:35,200
and as we jump into these other
countries you get that same type thing.

205
00:10:35,200 --> 00:10:40,330
So down here in Sao Paulo, Brazil we
actually have three zones that are two,

00:21:39,710 --> 00:21:45,140
a whole year, I can save 39%,
if I go ahead and do the year reservation.

437
00:21:45,140 --> 00:21:47,500
But I have to know I'm gonna
use that server all year.

438
00:21:47,500 --> 00:21:50,100
If I'm not gonna use it all year,
an on-demand might be even better.

439
00:21:50,100 --> 00:21:52,620
If I need a thousand servers just for
tomorrow,

440
00:21:52,620 --> 00:21:54,840
then I just need to do that on demand.

441
00:21:54,840 --> 00:21:58,850
If I try and do one year reservations on
the stuff, it's gonna be kind of a waste.

442
00:21:58,850 --> 00:22:03,850
But you can really kind of cut that price
down a good bit by reserving the instance.

443
00:22:03,850 --> 00:22:06,530
And that's how most of
the Amazon services work.

444
00:22:06,530 --> 00:22:11,250
You pay for the resource that you're
using, but you also pay for bandwidth.

445
00:22:11,250 --> 00:22:13,051
And I'm sure that's here
on this page somewhere.

446
00:22:13,051 --> 00:22:15,073
Let me just search and find it,
cuz that'll be faster.

447
00:22:15,073 --> 00:22:17,992
You know,
actually they're not showing it here.

448
00:22:17,992 --> 00:22:20,073
But data consumption, you pay for

449
00:22:20,073 --> 00:22:23,210
a certain amount of bandwidth on each one,
and.

450
00:22:23,210 --> 00:22:24,660
Here we go, Data Transfer.

451
00:22:24,660 --> 00:22:27,850
With data transfer, you pay for
data in and data out.

452
00:22:27,850 --> 00:22:31,240
Data in is data going to the service,
and data out is data coming out of it.

453
00:22:31,240 --> 00:22:32,430
You know, downloads.

454
00:22:32,430 --> 00:22:34,300
The uploads are normally free.

455
00:22:34,300 --> 00:22:36,940
So see here this data transfer into EC2.

456
00:22:36,940 --> 00:22:39,710
and it's all listed at like
zero dollars per gigabyte.

457
00:22:39,710 --> 00:22:43,720
They don't charge you putting data in EC2
or charge you for data putting into S3 or

458
00:22:43,720 --> 00:22:45,150
RDS or whatever.

459
00:22:45,150 --> 00:22:47,000
They don't charge you for that.

460
00:22:47,000 --> 00:22:48,120
It's when you get the data back out.

461
00:22:48,120 --> 00:22:52,380
And when you get the data back out,
we'll see here, data transfer out.

462
00:22:52,380 --> 00:22:55,300
To a certain level it's free,
but then they start charging, and

463
00:22:55,300 --> 00:22:58,000
here it looks like we've got
about one cent per gigabyte,

464
00:22:58,000 --> 00:23:00,350
two cents per gigabyte in other regions.

465
00:23:00,350 --> 00:23:03,000
So, not a huge amount of money there,
right?

466
00:23:03,000 --> 00:23:07,060
Now, if you're pushing terabytes of
data it can add up, but this is really,

467
00:23:07,060 --> 00:23:08,480
really inexpensive.

468
00:23:08,480 --> 00:23:11,310
And when we talk about S3 and
other services like that,

469
00:23:11,310 --> 00:23:15,290
each one of them,
they have their own pricing structure.

470
00:23:15,290 --> 00:23:17,790
And so you go in, and
you pull up the pricing for

471
00:23:17,790 --> 00:23:22,900
each of those to be able to find
the appropriate cost and all of that.

472
00:23:22,900 --> 00:23:25,630
So definitely something that
you wanna pay attention to.

473
00:23:25,630 --> 00:23:27,570
You are paying for what you use.

474
00:23:27,570 --> 00:23:30,330
And if you're using it and that usually
means like if you're a business,

475
00:23:30,330 --> 00:23:33,090
that you're making money on it,
and so it kind of pays for itself.

476
00:23:33,090 --> 00:23:37,455
But if you're a non-profit or whatever it
can be a little difficult to estimate what

477
00:23:37,455 --> 00:23:40,971
your costs are gonna be because
it's based on your end users usage.

478
00:23:40,971 --> 00:23:43,293
All right, but it is all very clear.

479
00:23:43,293 --> 00:23:48,970
When you go to Amazon's website, all the
pricing is spelled out in certain terms.

480
00:23:48,970 --> 00:23:51,180
They tell you exactly
what you're gonna pay.

481
00:23:51,180 --> 00:23:55,590
So like here with S3, the first terabyte
that I send out is gonna cost me

482
00:23:55,590 --> 00:23:59,600
three cents per gigabyte, but
as I start pushing more and more and more,

483
00:23:59,600 --> 00:24:04,340
it gets cheaper and cheaper, until we get
down to like 2.75 cents per gigabyte.

484
00:24:04,340 --> 00:24:06,330
It starts to get less expensive, and

485
00:24:06,330 --> 00:24:08,520
other types of storage might
be less expensive, too.

486
00:24:08,520 --> 00:24:10,550
You basically pick and
choose based on that.

487
00:24:10,550 --> 00:24:11,630
It's pretty neat stuff.

488
00:24:11,630 --> 00:24:14,600
>> Yeah, it sounds like you're
really compounding your savings to

489
00:24:14,600 --> 00:24:15,160
be honest with you.

490
00:24:15,160 --> 00:24:16,790
I'm not trying to pitch Amazon.

491
00:24:16,790 --> 00:24:17,920
I don't work for them.

492
00:24:17,920 --> 00:24:21,000
But the fact that you're
reducing your waste, right?

493
00:24:21,000 --> 00:24:24,190
You're not having to have all these
extra services sitting around and only

494
00:24:24,190 --> 00:24:28,180
use them when you need them, and plus the
infrastructure to support that business.

495
00:24:28,180 --> 00:24:31,960
And then also it's really cheap,
it's not that expensive.

496
00:24:31,960 --> 00:24:35,265
I mean, those prices right there,
I could live with that.

497
00:24:35,265 --> 00:24:39,320
[LAUGH]
>> So that's kind of an overview of AWS.

498
00:24:39,320 --> 00:24:41,790
What they're providing to you,
how they can benefit you,

499
00:24:41,790 --> 00:24:45,510
and what we're gonna do is over
the next series of episodes

500
00:24:45,510 --> 00:24:48,370
we're gonna start seeing each
of these individual services.

501
00:24:48,370 --> 00:24:49,800
So how do I use EC2.

502
00:24:49,800 --> 00:24:50,670
How do I use S3.

503
00:24:50,670 --> 00:24:52,130
How do I use RDS?

504
00:24:52,130 --> 00:24:54,550
And we'll get a chance to
see each of those in play.

505
00:24:54,550 --> 00:24:58,060
But we wanted to do an introduction to
this just so you can kind of understand

506
00:24:58,060 --> 00:25:01,520
what AWS was in the first place,
and why you'd want to use them.

507
00:25:01,520 --> 00:25:03,900
And they're not the only player
that's out there in this field.

508
00:25:03,900 --> 00:25:05,100
They're one of the first, right?

509
00:25:05,100 --> 00:25:06,300
They are the biggest.

510
00:25:06,300 --> 00:25:10,360
But there's Microsoft with Azure,
there's Rackspace, there's MediaTemple,

511
00:25:10,360 --> 00:25:14,000
there's all sorts of other vendors out
there that do the same basic thing.

512
00:25:14,000 --> 00:25:16,720
And those services work fairly similar.

513
00:25:16,720 --> 00:25:19,350
The difference is gonna be how
many data centers they have,

514
00:25:19,350 --> 00:25:21,850
how big those data centers are, and
the resources that are available.

515
00:25:21,850 --> 00:25:22,720
>> Awesome!

516
00:25:22,720 --> 00:25:27,600
Well, I guess that about wraps it up for
us today on Amazon.

517
00:25:27,600 --> 00:25:29,760
Hopefully you guys have
learned a lot from this.

518
00:25:29,760 --> 00:25:30,510
I know I sure have.

519
00:25:30,510 --> 00:25:31,790
I've really enjoyed it.

520
00:25:31,790 --> 00:25:34,160
So that being said it's time
to sign off for ITProTV.

521
00:25:34,160 --> 00:25:36,590
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

522
00:25:36,590 --> 00:25:37,110
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:25:37,110 --> 00:25:39,595
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:00:14,470 --> 00:00:15,870

5
00:00:15,870 --> 00:00:17,390

00:00:17,390 --> 00:00:18,430

00:00:18,430 --> 00:00:19,250
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:19,250 --> 00:00:23,080

00:00:23,080 --> 00:00:26,510

00:00:30,245 --> 00:00:36,770
The EC2 is just one aspect of the very

12
00:00:36,770 --> 00:00:42,130

even though it's only a small part of it.

14
00:00:44,930 --> 00:00:47,810
EC2 allows us to host
servers in the cloud.

15
00:00:47,810 --> 00:00:50,550
We can bring up these servers
on Amazon's infrastructure

00:00:50,550 --> 00:00:51,930

00:00:51,930 --> 00:00:53,800
And there are a ton of advantages to that.

So if you have any kind of

00:01:06,490 --> 00:01:07,290
Very similar to that.

23
00:01:07,290 --> 00:01:10,750
Other than that,
it's just all on Amazon's actual website.

24
00:01:10,750 --> 00:01:12,870
>> Yeah, and we get to take
advantage of all the benefits there.

25
00:01:12,870 --> 00:01:14,360
That they take care of the power.

26
00:01:14,360 --> 00:01:15,660
They take care of the network.

27
00:01:15,660 --> 00:01:17,870
They take care of redundancy.

28
00:01:17,870 --> 00:01:19,760
We spring up our operating systems and go.

29
00:01:19,760 --> 00:01:22,310
And what makes it really
nice is how easy it is.

30
00:01:22,310 --> 00:01:23,850
So, that's what we're gonna
walk through right here.

31
00:01:23,850 --> 00:01:26,890
Let's jump on in to our AWS,

32
00:01:26,890 --> 00:01:29,465
So, I'm logged into my AWS console.

33
00:01:29,465 --> 00:01:32,180

you see all your different services, and

34
00:01:32,180 --> 00:01:34,210
they divide them up into categories.

35
00:01:34,210 --> 00:01:36,900
Usually, the first one in the category
is the most popular service.

36
00:01:36,900 --> 00:01:39,690
And under Compute,
you got EC2 right there at the top.

37
00:01:39,690 --> 00:01:41,700
This is the one that we're shooting for.

38
00:01:41,700 --> 00:01:45,160
And it lets us create those
virtual servers in the cloud.

39
00:01:45,160 --> 00:01:50,510
And when you jump in, getting started
is really not a hard thing to do.

40
00:01:50,510 --> 00:01:54,300
Now do be aware of some of the terminology
that we're gonna see in here.

41
00:01:54,300 --> 00:01:58,060
In E.C. two, they don't call
virtual servers, virtual servers.

42
00:01:58,060 --> 00:02:01,150
They don't call them virtual machines,
they call them instances.

43
00:02:01,150 --> 00:02:06,070
And the reason is, you may actually
have one particular type of virtual

44
00:02:06,070 --> 00:02:08,680
machine that you spawned 10,
100, 1,000 copies of.

45
00:02:08,680 --> 00:02:11,670
And so it's one virtual machine
that's been cloned 1,000 and

46
00:02:11,670 --> 00:02:15,680
so you have instances of that
virtual machine that exist.

47
00:02:15,680 --> 00:02:19,330
So when we go in here,
you'll see a number of running instances,

48
00:02:19,330 --> 00:02:20,920
that's how many servers you already have.

49
00:02:20,920 --> 00:02:21,680
I've got two, so

50
00:02:21,680 --> 00:02:25,768
I get two running instances, If you don't
have any, you get a welcome screen which

51
00:02:25,768 --> 00:02:29,560
is this Launch Instance button right
here to go ahead and get started.

52
00:02:29,560 --> 00:02:31,890
Now getting started is super simple.

53
00:02:31,890 --> 00:02:34,810
It walks you through a basic
wizard where we can pick and

54
00:02:34,810 --> 00:02:37,410
choose what it is that we want.

55
00:02:37,410 --> 00:02:40,690
On Amazon's system,
they support two primary OSs.

56
00:02:40,690 --> 00:02:42,940
They support Linux based
operating systems, and

57
00:02:42,940 --> 00:02:45,710
they support Microsoft Windows
based operating systems.

58
00:02:45,710 --> 00:02:46,940
Now they do support others.

59
00:02:46,940 --> 00:02:49,775
There are some custom images that you'll
see that you can use, things like

60
00:02:49,775 --> 00:02:54,310
BSD-based OS's, but for the most part
you're gonna see Linux and Windows.

61
00:02:54,310 --> 00:02:59,400
But provisioning them is really the same,
regardless of which one your choosing.

62
00:02:59,400 --> 00:03:02,060
So right here on my quick start, it's
asking me what operating system I want.

63
00:03:02,060 --> 00:03:04,790
And you'll see Amazon Linux AMI.

64
00:03:04,790 --> 00:03:07,520
AMI as in Amazon machine image.

65
00:03:07,520 --> 00:03:10,030
That means they've created
an image of this operating system

66
00:03:10,030 --> 00:03:11,930
ready to deploy at a moment's notice.

67
00:03:11,930 --> 00:03:13,930
I just have to tell it to do it.

68
00:03:13,930 --> 00:03:18,250
Amazon Linux is actually based on CentOS,
which in turn is based on Red Hat.

69
00:03:18,250 --> 00:03:19,780
It's an open sourced OS,

70
00:03:19,780 --> 00:03:23,080
and so there's no real licensing
that we have to worry about here.

71
00:03:23,080 --> 00:03:25,610
It's a great way to get
a Linux box deployed.

72
00:03:25,610 --> 00:03:29,040
I really like it, and
the main reason I like it is because

73
00:03:29,040 --> 00:03:31,780
Amazon maintains their
own update repositories.

74
00:03:31,780 --> 00:03:34,060
So when you do updates,
it's super fast, and

75
00:03:34,060 --> 00:03:37,090
Amazon has actually kind of curated
some of those updates for you.

76
00:03:37,090 --> 00:03:38,320
So it's a great one.

77
00:03:38,320 --> 00:03:41,340
This is typically the go-to image for me.

78
00:03:41,340 --> 00:03:45,150
But maybe you want some of the closed
source technologies found in Red Hat.

79
00:03:45,150 --> 00:03:45,920
You can do that too.

80
00:03:45,920 --> 00:03:47,800
Right, so
we can do Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

81
00:03:47,800 --> 00:03:49,540
You'll see Suse Linux, Ubuntu.

82
00:03:49,540 --> 00:03:52,360
And then right down here we've
got Microsoft Windows Server,

83
00:03:52,360 --> 00:03:54,250
right, all ready to go.

84
00:03:54,250 --> 00:03:56,770
Amazon's already made an image,
we can deploy them, and

85
00:03:56,770 --> 00:03:58,360
we don't worry about licensing.

86
00:03:58,360 --> 00:03:59,440
That's kind of the cool part,

87
00:03:59,440 --> 00:04:03,290
is Microsoft Windows is kind of
a little bit closed doors, right?

88
00:04:03,290 --> 00:04:05,560
And normally we gotta buy that and
pay for licenses.

89
00:04:05,560 --> 00:04:07,340
But here if I choose this one,

90
00:04:07,340 --> 00:04:11,690
the price is rolled into the hourly
rate that's assigned to that VM.

91
00:04:11,690 --> 00:04:14,940
So as I'm running that instance, it's
just factoring in that license for me.

92
00:04:14,940 --> 00:04:17,890
I'm gonna go ahead and
start off with a Linux one, though.

93
00:04:17,890 --> 00:04:19,910
So I'm just gonna go ahead and
choose this guy.

94
00:04:19,910 --> 00:04:24,730
Now on this screen, I'm only seeing a
selection of instances, about 22 of them.

95
00:04:24,730 --> 00:04:26,730
You'll see this quite a bit,
Windows Server 2012, 2008.

96
00:04:26,730 --> 00:04:30,160
We got more Amazon Linux ones.

97
00:04:30,160 --> 00:04:31,520
But there's even more.

98
00:04:31,520 --> 00:04:36,420
This is just 22 of the most popular ones
that Amazon recommends and supports.

99
00:04:36,420 --> 00:04:42,116
But over here you'll see things like
the AWS marketplace and community AMIs.

100
00:04:42,116 --> 00:04:44,360
These are where you can find,
like with the market place,

101
00:04:44,360 --> 00:04:49,020
you can find where private companies have
built machine appliances or instances that

102
00:04:49,020 --> 00:04:52,260
you can launch that already have their
software installed and configured.

103
00:04:52,260 --> 00:04:55,580
And there's community ones where other
people in the community have done it.

104
00:04:55,580 --> 00:04:58,430
So if you're gonna be deploying
something like a WordPress server,

105
00:04:58,430 --> 00:05:01,530
well I could deploy the Amazon Linux AMI.

00:05:01,530 --> 00:05:03,760
I could install Apache and MySQL.

107
00:05:03,760 --> 00:05:07,080
I could load WordPress on there,
get it configured and go.

108
00:05:07,080 --> 00:05:11,580
Or I could just go find a community
AMI that already had WordPress set up.

109
00:05:11,580 --> 00:05:16,160
And now, all I have to do is spawn that
instance, login, change the password.

110
00:05:16,160 --> 00:05:16,830
That's it.

111
00:05:16,830 --> 00:05:21,500
>> Are the community AMIs free or paid
for, or is there, like, a jumble of both?

112
00:05:21,500 --> 00:05:23,700
>> Generally, what you see is
that the community ones are free.

113
00:05:23,700 --> 00:05:25,670
And those are ones that
are kinda being given out.

114
00:05:25,670 --> 00:05:28,550
And the marketplace ones,
those are the ones that you pay for.

115
00:05:28,550 --> 00:05:34,090
So a great example, we use a Barracuda
spam and virus firewall here.

116
00:05:34,090 --> 00:05:39,490
And we actually have the hardware box that
you stick in a server rack and you run it.

117
00:05:39,490 --> 00:05:42,180
And we have to keep that under
maintenance, in case the hardware fails.

118
00:05:42,180 --> 00:05:45,660
Well another option is that Barracuda
has in the Amazon Web Services'

119
00:05:45,660 --> 00:05:48,280
marketplace where you can go and
get it as a virtual machine.

120
00:05:48,280 --> 00:05:49,790
Now you don't have to worry
about hardware anymore.

121
00:05:49,790 --> 00:05:52,720
You still have to pay for your virus
updates, but you just get it from there.

122
00:05:52,720 --> 00:05:56,410
So it's a paid virtual machine cuz
it's got their software on it.

123
00:05:56,410 --> 00:05:58,070
Yeah, if you're ever bored,
browse around in here.

124
00:05:58,070 --> 00:05:59,410
I'll kinda jump in.

00:05:59,410 --> 00:06:03,250
If we go to that marketplace,
you'll see a ton of stuff in there

00:06:03,250 --> 00:06:07,140
from open source OSs,

127
00:06:07,140 --> 00:06:10,480
WordPress, mongoDB, Ruby and LAMP stacks.

00:06:10,480 --> 00:06:14,400
Tons and tons of stuff, and if I search,
let's see if we can find that Barracuda

00:06:14,400 --> 00:06:19,382
one, if I can remember

00:06:19,382 --> 00:06:21,440
>> [CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]
>> This is gonna be our big challenge,

00:06:21,440 --> 00:06:23,360
how to spell Barracuda.

00:06:23,360 --> 00:06:26,560
So, there's Barracuda load balancer,

133
00:06:26,560 --> 00:06:27,500
Spam firewall.

00:06:27,500 --> 00:06:30,270
That's the one I'm talking about,

00:06:30,270 --> 00:06:31,590
We pay a lot of money for that.

00:06:31,590 --> 00:06:33,620
But we can deploy a virtual machine, and

00:06:33,620 --> 00:06:37,080
when you look at this you got
Barracuda spam firewall free trial.

00:06:37,080 --> 00:06:39,550
Barracuda spam firewall
bring your own licence.

00:27:39,180 --> 00:27:43,290
The redundancy that you can do,
the geo-locating, it's just amazing,

598
00:27:43,290 --> 00:27:44,240
it blows your mind.

599
00:27:44,240 --> 00:27:47,410
So definitely stay tuned for
our other episodes on that.

600
00:27:47,410 --> 00:27:50,310
But as far as a basic primer of
getting instances fired up in EC2,

601
00:27:50,310 --> 00:27:52,200
I think we pretty much covered that.

602
00:27:52,200 --> 00:27:53,110
>> Yeah, good job.

603
00:27:53,110 --> 00:27:55,380
Well, hopefully you guys
have enjoyed this episode.

604
00:27:55,380 --> 00:27:59,090
That being said, it's about time for
us to sign off for ITProTV.

605
00:27:59,090 --> 00:28:00,540
I've been you're host, Daniel Lowry.

606
00:28:00,540 --> 00:28:01,070
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

607
00:28:01,070 --> 00:28:03,589
>> And we'll see you next time.

608
00:28:03,589 --> 00:28:08,410
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: EC2 Security Groups
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,474
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03,474 --> 00:00:11,241
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11,241 --> 00:00:12,617
>> All right, everyone, greetings.

4
00:00:12,617 --> 00:00:15,216
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15,216 --> 00:00:17,025
I'll be your host, Daniel Laury.

6
00:00:17,025 --> 00:00:18,785
Here with me today,
is my good friend, Don Pezet.

7
00:00:18,785 --> 00:00:19,825
How are you doing today, Don?

8
00:00:19,825 --> 00:00:20,835
>> I'm doing great, Daniel.

9
00:00:20,835 --> 00:00:21,595
I'm excited because today,

10
00:00:21,595 --> 00:00:25,315
we're going to be jumping into
security groups inside of Amazon EC2.

11
00:00:25,315 --> 00:00:27,835
And if you're not familiar
with security groups,

12
00:00:27,835 --> 00:00:30,265
it's kind of like a Software Firewall or

13
00:00:30,265 --> 00:00:33,975
a filtering service that Amazon
provides for all of your EC2 services.

14
00:00:33,975 --> 00:00:38,280
And it's pretty important because
believe it or not, it's not so

15
00:00:38,280 --> 00:00:39,660
nice people out there on the Internet.

16
00:00:39,660 --> 00:00:40,830
>> Say it ain't so, Don.

17
00:00:40,830 --> 00:00:46,281
>> I know it's shocking, and when you host
your servers up in Amazon's EC2 Cloud,

18
00:00:46,281 --> 00:00:48,186
it's visible to the world.

19
00:00:48,186 --> 00:00:49,926
We need to be able to partition them off.

20
00:00:49,926 --> 00:00:52,670
Separate it and
only allow the traffic that we want.

21
00:00:52,670 --> 00:00:55,650
And this is something we traditionally
do with, like Hardware Firewalls.

22
00:00:55,650 --> 00:00:59,444
But Amazon makes it super easy
with a Web Managed Interface.

23
00:00:59,444 --> 00:01:02,195
To be able to just add ports,
remove ports.

24
00:01:02,195 --> 00:01:03,450
Kind of set-up that configuration.

25
00:01:03,450 --> 00:01:07,480
We just need to know to do it and know
some basic practices to secure our system.

26
00:01:07,480 --> 00:01:11,060
>> Now, Don is the level of security
that this firewall entails that,

27
00:01:11,060 --> 00:01:17,180
at the same level something like
a Cisco ASA, or on that kind of ability.

28
00:01:17,180 --> 00:01:18,200
>> Yeah, for the most part.

29
00:01:18,200 --> 00:01:22,190
A lot of the firewall vendors out
there have kind of started to deviate.

30
00:01:22,190 --> 00:01:25,540
And if you take a Cisco ASA,
it's not just a firewall anymore.

31
00:01:25,540 --> 00:01:28,240
It does VPN service,
it does all this other crazy stuff.

32
00:01:28,240 --> 00:01:31,530
The security groups,
they're just a true native firewall.

33
00:01:31,530 --> 00:01:33,580
You put in your ports and that's it.

34
00:01:33,580 --> 00:01:35,800
So it's not going to do things
like Network Address Translation.

35
00:01:35,800 --> 00:01:40,410
What you certainly can do that, inside of
AWS, it's got support for NAT, and VPN,

36
00:01:40,410 --> 00:01:41,460
and all that.

37
00:01:41,460 --> 00:01:43,410
But the security groups, just a firewall.

38
00:01:43,410 --> 00:01:45,920
And honestly, I prefer that better,
because I know,

39
00:01:45,920 --> 00:01:46,950
I'm going to this one service.

40
00:01:46,950 --> 00:01:47,630
It does one thing.

41
00:01:47,630 --> 00:01:50,915
I configure it, And that's it, doesn't get
muddied with all the other technology.

42
00:01:50,915 --> 00:01:51,775
>> Yeah, keep it simple, right?

43
00:01:52,805 --> 00:01:55,835
>> So whenever we spin up
a new instance inside of EC2,

44
00:01:55,835 --> 00:01:59,613
we need to be thinking about,
what that instance is going to do, right?

45
00:01:59,613 --> 00:02:03,175
If I'm bring-up a web server,
what's that web server going to do?

46
00:02:03,175 --> 00:02:04,515
Well, it's gonna serve up a web page.

47
00:02:05,515 --> 00:02:07,565
So, I want people to be
able to get that web page.

48
00:02:07,565 --> 00:02:11,240
And they're gonna use HTTP,
the Hypertext Transfer Protocol.

49
00:02:11,240 --> 00:02:13,800
And that's going to use TCP [INAUDIBLE].

50
00:02:13,800 --> 00:02:16,810
Right, that's the port that
web traffic goes over.

51
00:02:16,810 --> 00:02:18,350
That's really the only thing,

52
00:02:18,350 --> 00:02:20,760
people on the Internet would
need to get to that server on.

53
00:02:20,760 --> 00:02:22,960
So, I need to restrict that access down.

54
00:02:22,960 --> 00:02:25,660
Now, you can do that in
your Operating System.

55
00:02:25,660 --> 00:02:28,430
If you got a Windows Server, you got
the Windows Firewall that can do it.

56
00:02:28,430 --> 00:02:30,570
In Linux, you've got IP Tables,
they can do it.

57
00:02:30,570 --> 00:02:32,670
There's a ton of other
ways to go about it.

58
00:02:32,670 --> 00:02:36,960
But the problem there, is the traffic
has already made it to your server.

59
00:02:36,960 --> 00:02:38,570
And if you're server that's blocking it,

60
00:02:38,570 --> 00:02:42,060
wouldn't it be nice if we could block it
before it even made it to the server?

61
00:02:42,060 --> 00:02:45,170
And that's what security groups are all
about, is taking care of that for us.

62
00:02:45,170 --> 00:02:47,340
So, let me give you a little
tour of how that works, and

63
00:02:47,340 --> 00:02:49,840
we'll get a chance to see it in action.

64
00:02:49,840 --> 00:02:55,470
Now, when you create a Virtual Machine in
EC2, so when I spin up a new instance.

65
00:02:55,470 --> 00:02:58,290
It asks me, if I want to use
an existing security group or

66
00:02:58,290 --> 00:03:00,430
if I want to create a new one.

67
00:03:00,430 --> 00:03:02,420
And, we normally just
let it create a new one.

68
00:03:02,420 --> 00:03:06,680
So as you set up instances,
you're probably creating many, many,

69
00:03:06,680 --> 00:03:09,710
many of these resources.

70
00:03:09,710 --> 00:03:13,580
So for example, if I launch an instance
here, I'll just launch a quick Linux AMI.

71
00:03:13,580 --> 00:03:14,940
So, I'll go ahead and pick one.

72
00:03:14,940 --> 00:03:16,230
I'll do a micro.

73
00:03:16,230 --> 00:03:18,070
And, I'm not really gonna change much.

74
00:03:18,070 --> 00:03:21,080
I'm just gonna move through this
wizard and as I go through.

75
00:03:21,080 --> 00:03:26,100
And I see various settings about it,
shutdown behavior, all that storage, tags.

76
00:03:26,100 --> 00:03:28,540
I'll give it a name,
this'll be ITProTV-web03.

77
00:03:28,540 --> 00:03:34,280
So, this'll be my third web server and
then, it asks about that security group.

78
00:03:34,280 --> 00:03:38,090
I can pick an existing security group if
I've got one or I can create a new one.

79
00:03:38,090 --> 00:03:40,800
A Security Group is basically a Firewall.

80
00:03:40,800 --> 00:03:44,690
And you can have more than one
instance share the same Firewall.

81
00:03:44,690 --> 00:03:48,890
If I have five web servers and
they all need port 80 to get to them,

82
00:03:48,890 --> 00:03:50,930
why have five separate firewalls for that?

83
00:03:50,930 --> 00:03:52,550
I can just have one.

84
00:03:52,550 --> 00:03:55,820
But if I have two servers that
provide completely different roles.

85
00:03:55,820 --> 00:03:58,310
I have a Database Server and a Web Server.

86
00:03:58,310 --> 00:03:59,460
The Web Server needs port 80.

87
00:03:59,460 --> 00:04:02,430
The Database Server needs 3306.

88
00:04:02,430 --> 00:04:04,680
If I put them behind the same firewall,

89
00:04:04,680 --> 00:04:06,280
I'm gonna have to open
up both those ports.

90
00:04:06,280 --> 00:04:09,070
And that means, I'm opening up web
access to the Database Server.

91
00:04:09,070 --> 00:04:10,990
And that's not what I want.

92
00:04:10,990 --> 00:04:13,160
So there,
I'd need to do Multiple Firewalls.

93
00:04:13,160 --> 00:04:14,640
Multiple Security Groups to protect that.

94
00:04:16,090 --> 00:04:20,110
Notice what it's allowing by default,
on a Windows machine.

95
00:04:20,110 --> 00:04:21,360
If you choose a Windows instance,

96
00:04:21,360 --> 00:04:25,760
it's going to allow Remote Desktop
Protocol, which is TCP port 3389.

97
00:04:25,760 --> 00:04:29,830
That's allowing Remote Desktop for you to
log into the machine and configure it.

98
00:04:29,830 --> 00:04:33,890
For a Linux box,
it's SSA which is TCP port 22.

99
00:04:33,890 --> 00:04:40,080
In either case, SSH or RDP,
it allows it from anywhere.

100
00:04:40,080 --> 00:04:42,660
And that's the first thing
that we need to change.

101
00:04:42,660 --> 00:04:47,780
If I leave it set to anywhere, that means
anyone in the world could fire-up SSH.

102
00:04:47,780 --> 00:04:50,970
Or in Windows fire-up RDP,
and connect to my server.

103
00:04:50,970 --> 00:04:52,610
And they're going to get
a certificate message.

104
00:04:52,610 --> 00:04:53,430
They can just say, yes to that.

105
00:04:53,430 --> 00:04:56,210
And then they're going to Logon Prompt.

106
00:04:56,210 --> 00:04:59,190
And so, they can now attempt to brute
force their way into that server.

107
00:04:59,190 --> 00:05:02,190
They can try to guess Username and
the Password.

108
00:05:02,190 --> 00:05:04,520
That's not good, so
we want to protect ourselves from that.

109
00:05:04,520 --> 00:05:07,510
And the easiest way to do
that is to restrict it.

110
00:05:07,510 --> 00:05:10,650
To say, I don't want to allow
that connection from anywhere.

111
00:05:10,650 --> 00:05:13,740
I want to allow it from
somewhere specific.

112
00:05:13,740 --> 00:05:15,320
And Amazon is a really cool service here.

113
00:05:15,320 --> 00:05:19,410
You can choose my IP and it's going to
set it to whatever the IP address is,

114
00:05:19,410 --> 00:05:21,860
that your browsing
the Internet from right now.

115
00:05:21,860 --> 00:05:22,460
Okay, so

116
00:05:22,460 --> 00:05:26,530
if I choose that, there is I put in my
public IP, that's the one I'm coming from.

117
00:05:26,530 --> 00:05:29,810
Now, only I will be able
SSH into the system.

118
00:05:31,180 --> 00:05:33,850
But, what if I'm at home when
I'm setting this up and I know,

119
00:05:33,850 --> 00:05:35,430
I'm gonna be at the office later.

120
00:05:35,430 --> 00:05:39,510
Well, I can come in and
add another rule for SSH.

121
00:05:39,510 --> 00:05:41,910
And this time, I can put in a custom IP.

122
00:05:41,910 --> 00:05:45,220
And in the custom IP field,
I can come in here, and

123
00:05:45,220 --> 00:05:48,550
I can specify something
a little bit bigger.

124
00:05:48,550 --> 00:05:53,170
Maybe another network and
let me zoom in a little bit on this,

125
00:05:53,170 --> 00:05:55,190
because now it's ultimately small.

126
00:05:55,190 --> 00:05:57,330
So that didn't quite scale very well,
did it?

127
00:05:57,330 --> 00:06:01,827
But we can punch in an IP range,
like I'll punch in a bigger office range.

128
00:06:01,827 --> 00:06:05,394
So 209.251.159 and then,

129
00:06:05,394 --> 00:06:09,507
here I can come in and say like 179/32.

130
00:06:09,507 --> 00:06:11,760
That's my individual IP.

131
00:06:11,760 --> 00:06:15,410
But this is actually part of a bigger
subnet that if I remember right,

132
00:06:15,410 --> 00:06:19,750
starts at 177 and
is like a slash, what is it?

133
00:06:19,750 --> 00:06:22,900
A /26 I believe is what we have.

134
00:06:22,900 --> 00:06:26,100
So I can specify something like this,
as a bigger network.

135
00:06:26,100 --> 00:06:27,450
And now it's getting more than one IP.

136
00:06:27,450 --> 00:06:31,900
And now all the IP addresses here at
my office would be able to connect in.

137
00:06:31,900 --> 00:06:34,710
And use SSH to access this server.

138
00:06:34,710 --> 00:06:38,440
So it's up to you specify those ranges,
get them put in there.

139
00:06:38,440 --> 00:06:41,700
Now, I'm just doing SSH right here,
Secure Shell.

140
00:06:41,700 --> 00:06:45,540
But if this is gonna be a web server,
I need to add a little more to it.

141
00:06:45,540 --> 00:06:47,910
I need to add HTTP.

142
00:06:47,910 --> 00:06:51,580
I'm gonna leave that off, right now, cuz
I want to show you guys this in action.

143
00:06:51,580 --> 00:06:55,540
So I'm just going to enable SSH,
and I'll go, and hit review.

144
00:06:55,540 --> 00:06:57,260
And watch.
So that's going to go and

145
00:06:57,260 --> 00:06:58,710
create that instance.

146
00:06:58,710 --> 00:07:00,010
And I'll need to pick a key pair.

147
00:07:00,010 --> 00:07:00,980
I've already got a key.

148
00:07:00,980 --> 00:07:02,760
I'll just use that one.

149
00:07:02,760 --> 00:07:04,470
And it's going to spin
up that instance for me.

150
00:07:04,470 --> 00:07:05,430
And I'll have it.

151
00:07:05,430 --> 00:07:07,390
Now, the security group that I created.

152
00:07:08,470 --> 00:07:13,300
If I go back into my easy to service,
on the left side here,

153
00:07:13,300 --> 00:07:15,920
I can go to instances and
I see my instances.

154
00:07:15,920 --> 00:07:17,000
And I can find web03.

155
00:07:18,260 --> 00:07:21,140
And in web03's settings
down here at the bottom,

156
00:07:21,140 --> 00:07:22,830
you'll see what security group it's in.

157
00:07:22,830 --> 00:07:26,340
So we created one called launch-wizard-3,
great name.

158
00:07:26,340 --> 00:07:28,020
It was just a generic name.

159
00:07:28,020 --> 00:07:28,930
But I can see it.

160
00:07:28,930 --> 00:07:29,990
I can click on that.

161
00:07:29,990 --> 00:07:32,160
And here's where I can
see that security group.

162
00:07:32,160 --> 00:07:34,730
And if I don't like that name,
I can rename it right here.

163
00:07:34,730 --> 00:07:35,440
And I'm gonna do that.

164
00:07:35,440 --> 00:07:38,380
I'm gonna call it, itprotv-web03.

165
00:07:38,380 --> 00:07:41,030
So I can remember, what this is tied to.

166
00:07:41,030 --> 00:07:43,950
So, I'm just gonna give that
little group a name right there.

167
00:07:43,950 --> 00:07:46,020
So that I can kind of recognize that.

168
00:07:46,020 --> 00:07:46,780
And I can come through.

169
00:07:46,780 --> 00:07:50,077
And I can edit those rules inbound,
and outbound.

170
00:07:50,077 --> 00:07:51,516
It does both directions.

171
00:07:51,516 --> 00:07:56,251
The default is, only that SSH traffic is
being allowed to come into the server.

172
00:07:56,251 --> 00:07:59,206
And everything is being allowed
to come out of the server.

173
00:07:59,206 --> 00:08:00,529
We might want to limit that.

174
00:08:00,529 --> 00:08:02,656
We might wanna block or
allow certain access for

175
00:08:02,656 --> 00:08:05,860
the server to be able to get to, and
we can certainly do that right here.

176
00:08:07,210 --> 00:08:10,680
All right, now once that instance spins
up I should be able to SSH into it.

177
00:08:10,680 --> 00:08:14,220
Let me go check my instance status and
see where it's at.

178
00:08:14,220 --> 00:08:16,450
And it looks like it is running.

179
00:08:16,450 --> 00:08:19,340
It's still initializing but I'll probably
be able to get into it at this point.

180
00:08:19,340 --> 00:08:22,350
When you first put up an instance it's
gotta load some additional software which

181
00:08:22,350 --> 00:08:23,090
can take a moment.

182
00:08:23,090 --> 00:08:25,810
But it should be far enough along for
me to connect.

183
00:08:25,810 --> 00:08:29,220
So I'm going to copy that host name and
jump over to a terminal window.

184
00:08:29,220 --> 00:08:31,860
Looks like I'm still on
one of my other servers.

185
00:08:31,860 --> 00:08:35,720
So I'm going to SSH over
to that guy real quick.

186
00:08:35,720 --> 00:08:38,480
And we should be able to get in now.

187
00:08:38,480 --> 00:08:42,840
I'm using SSH, so
it's going to connect on TCP port 22.

188
00:08:42,840 --> 00:08:44,705
And when I go.

189
00:08:44,705 --> 00:08:48,610
Oh, I got some bad permissions on my key,
let me just fix that real quick.

190
00:08:49,730 --> 00:08:52,570
And there we go.

191
00:08:52,570 --> 00:08:54,300
And now I'm in.

192
00:08:54,300 --> 00:08:58,000
So I'm able to SSH into that server and
access it.

193
00:08:58,000 --> 00:09:00,180
All right,
well I want it to be a web server.

194
00:09:00,180 --> 00:09:04,660
So let me just real quick
install a web server on it.

195
00:09:04,660 --> 00:09:11,460
All right, so now it's got Apache,
and we can fire that up.

196
00:09:11,460 --> 00:09:13,590
We'll fire up the HTTP service.

197
00:09:15,790 --> 00:09:17,510
Oops, HTTP, if I spell it right.

198
00:09:17,510 --> 00:09:22,950
So we'll start that service up and
let me make sure that it starts on boot.

199
00:09:24,270 --> 00:09:26,710
And we'll set that, there we go.

200
00:09:26,710 --> 00:09:27,550
So now I'm a web server.

201
00:09:28,580 --> 00:09:33,020
I should be able to browse to this server
and get the Apache test page, right?

202
00:09:33,020 --> 00:09:36,040
Not anything fancy, just a simple
little test page that I should see.

203
00:09:36,040 --> 00:09:41,280
If I jump over to a web browser though,
and I browse to that host.

204
00:09:41,280 --> 00:09:43,507
And I'll make sure to just do HTTP://.

205
00:09:43,507 --> 00:09:45,830
So I'm gonna browse to it.

206
00:09:45,830 --> 00:09:47,050
It's just sitting here.

207
00:09:47,050 --> 00:09:48,730
I can't get to it, right?

208
00:09:48,730 --> 00:09:52,330
And the reason is,
I only allowed SSH just from my machine.

209
00:09:52,330 --> 00:09:55,280
This traffic has been blocked,
I can't even get to the server.

210
00:09:55,280 --> 00:09:57,050
Better yet,
trying to exploit it using HTTP.

211
00:09:58,390 --> 00:10:01,800
And that's really what we want to see,
we want that to be blocked.

212
00:10:01,800 --> 00:10:04,370
And if I go back to my security group.

213
00:10:04,370 --> 00:10:07,220
So I'm gonna go back to
the security group for this guy.

214
00:10:07,220 --> 00:10:12,470
I'll go to security groups, and I'll
find that ITProTV web03 security group.

215
00:10:12,470 --> 00:10:15,390
And on inbound I'm just
gonna edit those rules.

216
00:10:15,390 --> 00:10:16,970
I'm gonna add a new rule.

217
00:10:16,970 --> 00:10:22,000
I'll add a rule for HTTP, and most of the
protocols that we use on a regular basis,

218
00:10:22,000 --> 00:10:23,230
right here on the list.

219
00:10:23,230 --> 00:10:26,840
But you certainly can do a custom rule,

a Linux machine, or

448
00:22:14,080 --> 00:22:17,910
I might have five different Linux distros,
the security group is the same.

449
00:22:17,910 --> 00:22:20,400
I'm configuring security the same way, and

450
00:22:20,400 --> 00:22:22,940
that lessens the chance
of me making a mistake.

451
00:22:22,940 --> 00:22:27,190
Because maybe I'm a Linux guy, and
so I know IP tables inside and out.

452
00:22:27,190 --> 00:22:28,750
But I don't use Windows that much.

453
00:22:28,750 --> 00:22:30,237
And so I go that Windows firewall rule and

454
00:22:30,237 --> 00:22:32,190
I configure it wrong cuz
I don't use it that much.

455
00:22:32,190 --> 00:22:33,870
And now my server's vulnerable.

456
00:22:33,870 --> 00:22:36,640
But here I just have security groups,
I use them for everything.

457
00:22:36,640 --> 00:22:40,400
And it doesn't matter what OS is behind
it, I've got a security group and

458
00:22:40,400 --> 00:22:41,460
it's configured and in place.

459
00:22:41,460 --> 00:22:43,130
>> Yeah.
Plus you have the added advantage of

460
00:22:43,130 --> 00:22:48,100
saying I could even have an appliance,
a firewall appliance for

461
00:22:48,100 --> 00:22:51,990
every server if I wanted to get that
fine grain or do the security groups.

462
00:22:51,990 --> 00:22:53,420
Obviously that's the way to go.

463
00:22:53,420 --> 00:22:55,860
>> And
you know you mention the appliances,

464
00:22:55,860 --> 00:23:00,620
I do know people who if you really
want special rules or special control.

465
00:23:00,620 --> 00:23:02,910
The security groups can be
a little limited, right?

466
00:23:02,910 --> 00:23:06,280
Especially when it comes to
protocols that jump ports, like FTP.

467
00:23:06,280 --> 00:23:11,530
FTP, you connect on 21, and then it'll
jump to 20 to do file transfers,

468
00:23:11,530 --> 00:23:13,290
and so it kinda bounces back and forth.

469
00:23:13,290 --> 00:23:17,700
Or protocols that switch from TCP
to UDP midstream, those things

470
00:23:17,700 --> 00:23:20,660
can cause problems in security groups,
the rules can be a little complex.

471
00:23:20,660 --> 00:23:24,300
So you could put a security group
rule in that said allow traffic,

472
00:23:24,300 --> 00:23:25,740
allow all traffic, just anything.

473
00:23:25,740 --> 00:23:28,080
And then you can bring up an appliance,

474
00:23:28,080 --> 00:23:33,610
like you bring up pfSense in a virtual
machine, and use that as your firewall.

475
00:23:33,610 --> 00:23:38,990
And then have it in a security group where
all traffic is allowed to pfSense and

476
00:23:38,990 --> 00:23:42,890
then have a security group rule that
allows just pfSense to be able to get to

477
00:23:42,890 --> 00:23:45,720
your machines that are behind it and
you can control access that way.

478
00:23:45,720 --> 00:23:49,850
So you can use dedicated appliances or

479
00:23:49,850 --> 00:23:53,440
firewall appliances software, whatever,
to be able to provide that functionality.

480
00:23:53,440 --> 00:23:56,380
But the security groups,
you guys saw it was, and

481
00:23:56,380 --> 00:23:58,370
I don't have to pay for an extra instance.

482
00:23:58,370 --> 00:24:00,830
The security groups are just a part
of what I've already spun up right.

483
00:24:00,830 --> 00:24:03,460
>> Right, and
every added piece of security we have is

484
00:24:03,460 --> 00:24:04,995
a benefit to you, right?

485
00:24:04,995 --> 00:24:08,225
Every piece of security saying that's
another fence that the bad guys have to

486
00:24:08,225 --> 00:24:11,285
jump to get to your data or
cause some havoc.

487
00:24:11,285 --> 00:24:12,595
>> Very cool stuff.

488
00:24:12,595 --> 00:24:15,485
Now one little piece of advice
I do want to give you guys is,

489
00:24:15,485 --> 00:24:19,235
as you spin up more and more instances,
a lot of times people is automatically

490
00:24:19,235 --> 00:24:23,175
choose to create new security groups and
it can get really confusing.

491
00:24:23,175 --> 00:24:25,323
You can end up with hundreds
of security groups and

492
00:24:25,323 --> 00:24:28,450
a lot of them will have names
like Launch Wizard Seven.

493
00:24:28,450 --> 00:24:32,050
And so it's easy to lose sight
of who something is tied to.

494
00:24:32,050 --> 00:24:34,300
So just be aware when you're
on the instance list,

495
00:24:34,300 --> 00:24:36,160
let me get back to my instance list here.

496
00:24:36,160 --> 00:24:39,450
When we're looking at the list
of instances in our account,

497
00:24:39,450 --> 00:24:42,870
you can scroll over on that screen, and

498
00:24:42,870 --> 00:24:46,200
it'll show you which security group
each of your instances are in.

499
00:24:46,200 --> 00:24:47,560
And these are hotlinks.

500
00:24:47,560 --> 00:24:51,330
So if you click on these, it'll go right
to that security group to make sure you're

501
00:24:51,330 --> 00:24:55,610
configuring the right one, the one that's
actually assigned to that instance.

502
00:24:55,610 --> 00:24:58,710
And when you go to the security group
list over here, if I go to networking and

503
00:24:58,710 --> 00:25:04,610
security, and security groups I see all my
security groups listed right here, right?

504
00:25:04,610 --> 00:25:07,170
With their descriptions if
we chose to provide one.

505
00:25:07,170 --> 00:25:10,360
And when you choose one of these
security groups, down at the bottom

506
00:25:10,360 --> 00:25:13,490
you get the description,
you get some basic information.

507
00:25:13,490 --> 00:25:17,330
And it'll actually tell you some basic
things that you set during the install,

508
00:25:17,330 --> 00:25:18,600
if you set them.

509
00:25:18,600 --> 00:25:20,340
But if you choose one
of these generic ones,

510
00:25:20,340 --> 00:25:22,860
let me find one that is just
Launch Instance whatever.

511
00:25:22,860 --> 00:25:25,330
Here, Launch Wizard One, right?

512
00:25:25,330 --> 00:25:28,360
When I look down here I
don't necessarily see which

513
00:25:28,360 --> 00:25:30,600
virtual machines are tied to this.

514
00:25:30,600 --> 00:25:32,210
I can see the rules and

515
00:25:32,210 --> 00:25:35,380
the tags but I don't really know
where this one's being utilized.

516
00:25:35,380 --> 00:25:38,460
So it's a good idea to come in here and
clean these things up.

517
00:25:38,460 --> 00:25:41,870
If you're not using them, if you've
moved your instances out of there,

518
00:25:41,870 --> 00:25:45,870
just clean them up, delete them,
otherwise they do build up over time.

519
00:25:45,870 --> 00:25:48,580
>> Well, Don, have we thoroughly
covered these security groups?

520
00:25:48,580 --> 00:25:51,010
I know I learned a lot on this,
it's very good stuff.

521
00:25:51,010 --> 00:25:52,640
>> Yeah.
You know, definitely tune back in.

522
00:25:52,640 --> 00:25:54,800
We'll do an episode on VPCs later on.

523
00:25:54,800 --> 00:25:57,950
There's a different type of security
group, called a VPC security group,

524
00:25:57,950 --> 00:26:01,640
that let's you provide protection
between subnets, between IP subnets.

525
00:26:01,640 --> 00:26:02,660
>> Wow.

526
00:26:02,660 --> 00:26:04,030
>> Small environment,
your not gonna use that.

527
00:26:04,030 --> 00:26:05,350
But large environments, you may.

528
00:26:05,350 --> 00:26:06,420
So we'll see some more on that.

529
00:26:06,420 --> 00:26:09,240
But as far as basic security groups,
that's basically it.

530
00:26:09,240 --> 00:26:10,600
>> All right, that's very awesome.

531
00:26:10,600 --> 00:26:14,650
Well I guess we've wrapped up another
show here at ITProTV studios.

532
00:26:14,650 --> 00:26:15,480
Signing off.

533
00:26:15,480 --> 00:26:16,820
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

534
00:26:16,820 --> 00:26:17,760
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

535
00:26:17,760 --> 00:26:19,955
>> We'll see you next time.

536
00:26:19,955 --> 00:26:24,920
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Additional Server Options
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,437
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,437 --> 00:00:11,200
All right.

3
00:00:11,200 --> 00:00:11,912
Greetings, everyone.
And

4
00:00:11,912 --> 00:00:14,755
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:14,755 --> 00:00:16,520
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:16,520 --> 00:00:19,330
Here with me today is my good friend and
colleague, Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:19,330 --> 00:00:20,480
How're you doing today, Don?

8
00:00:20,480 --> 00:00:21,400
>> I am doing great, Daniel.

9
00:00:21,400 --> 00:00:25,125
We've got a good show lined up because
we're gonna be taking our servers,

10
00:00:25,125 --> 00:00:27,400
our instances that we brought
up in the previous episode.

11
00:00:27,400 --> 00:00:29,562
And doing some little bit
of advance configurations.

12
00:00:29,562 --> 00:00:32,290
Some follow-up tasks that will normally
perform on an instance that we

13
00:00:32,290 --> 00:00:33,390
brought up in EC2.

14
00:00:33,390 --> 00:00:34,160
>> Yeah, very cool.

15
00:00:34,160 --> 00:00:37,410
So, we're talking about actually,
not just doing one server but

16
00:00:37,410 --> 00:00:38,570
doing multiple servers.

17
00:00:38,570 --> 00:00:41,090
And then, doing maybe even a little
bit of backup of those services.

18
00:00:41,090 --> 00:00:42,000
Stuff like that.

19
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:45,468
>> Yeah, so in the previous episode,
if you didn't catch it,

20
00:00:45,468 --> 00:00:49,146
we showed how to create an instance or
a virtual machine in EC2.

21
00:00:49,146 --> 00:00:53,500
Once you get it up and running, you remote
into it, you configure it, and off you go.

22
00:00:53,500 --> 00:00:56,780
But there's a few other things that we
might need to do to get that machine ready

23
00:00:56,780 --> 00:00:57,620
for prime time.

24
00:00:57,620 --> 00:01:01,120
And one of the big ones Is backing it up.

25
00:01:01,120 --> 00:01:04,870
Now, Amazon's official stance is the best
way to back-up your virtual machine,

26
00:01:04,870 --> 00:01:08,300
is through the operating system
inside of that instance.

27
00:01:08,300 --> 00:01:11,510
So, if you're running Linux or Windows or
whatever, they've all got various systems

28
00:01:11,510 --> 00:01:14,090
for backing them up,
you can certainly use those.

29
00:01:14,090 --> 00:01:16,230
But, if you don't have anything,

30
00:01:16,230 --> 00:01:18,540
Amazon does provide what's
called the Snapshot Service.

31
00:01:18,540 --> 00:01:21,320
Now, the Snapshot Service
has its limitations.

32
00:01:21,320 --> 00:01:24,830
And so, there's a reason why most people
don't necessarily want to use it, but

33
00:01:24,830 --> 00:01:28,040
it is there, it's a great option,
if you just don't have anything else.

34
00:01:28,040 --> 00:01:31,580
The way the Snapshot Service works,
is it takes a, well a snapshot.

35
00:01:31,580 --> 00:01:37,580
It takes an image of the hard drives for a
virtual machine, and freezes them in time.

36
00:01:37,580 --> 00:01:39,150
And then your virtual
machine keeps running.

37
00:01:39,150 --> 00:01:40,730
You can make changes to it,
do whatever you want.

38
00:01:40,730 --> 00:01:45,420
And if anything ever goes wrong, you can
restore that snapshot of the hard drive.

39
00:01:45,420 --> 00:01:48,180
You can put the hard drive back to
the way it was before the problem.

40
00:01:48,180 --> 00:01:49,560
And now you're up and running again.

41
00:01:49,560 --> 00:01:51,010
So if you have a bad software update.

42
00:01:51,010 --> 00:01:53,000
You get infected with a virus.

43
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:54,630
Your server gets compromised.

44
00:01:54,630 --> 00:01:58,340
You can roll it back to the way
that it was before that happened.

45
00:01:58,340 --> 00:02:03,135
Now, key thing to remember here,
the snapshots are just of the hard drive.

46
00:02:03,135 --> 00:02:05,895
Just a storage device, it doesn't do RAM.

47
00:02:05,895 --> 00:02:10,165
So, if your server is running
when you take this backup,

48
00:02:10,165 --> 00:02:11,265
it doesn't get what's in RAM.

49
00:02:11,265 --> 00:02:12,995
So, it doesn't get that running operation.

50
00:02:12,995 --> 00:02:15,975
It's just what saved to the hard drive and
that's it.

51
00:02:15,975 --> 00:02:18,655
So, that's the first thing
that we need to think about.

52
00:02:18,655 --> 00:02:21,475
The other thing is,
since it's just imaging the hard drive,

53
00:02:21,475 --> 00:02:24,350
there is the possibility that
you can create a bad backup.

54
00:02:24,350 --> 00:02:26,420
If your server is running.

55
00:02:26,420 --> 00:02:29,040
If the instance is actually up and
operational and

56
00:02:29,040 --> 00:02:31,420
it's partially written
data to the hard drive.

57
00:02:31,420 --> 00:02:35,910
And we take a snapshot, our snapshot
now includes partially written data.

58
00:02:35,910 --> 00:02:39,370
The other part of the data is in
RAM still waiting to be written.

59
00:02:39,370 --> 00:02:44,290
That doesn't make it into the snapshot and
now I might have a bad backup.

60
00:02:44,290 --> 00:02:49,320
So, with snapshots, what we really
need to do is shut the instance down.

61
00:02:49,320 --> 00:02:53,440
Turn it off so that you know it's not
writing to its hard drives anymore, and

62
00:02:53,440 --> 00:02:54,390
then take the snapshot.

63
00:02:54,390 --> 00:02:57,960
And that's one of the reasons why
snapshots are not right for everybody.

64
00:02:57,960 --> 00:03:00,460
If you need your server to be up,
mission critical, 24-7, well,

65
00:03:00,460 --> 00:03:03,870
you don't want to shut it down.

66
00:03:03,870 --> 00:03:07,240
And Amazon's response to that is,
well, if it's mission critical and

67
00:03:07,240 --> 00:03:10,450
you need it 24-7, shouldn't you
have more than one of that server?

68
00:03:10,450 --> 00:03:12,570
And that way,
you could shut one node down and

69
00:03:12,570 --> 00:03:14,788
back it up while the others
are running in carrying the load.

70
00:03:14,788 --> 00:03:16,080
And that's sbsolutely true.

71
00:03:16,080 --> 00:03:17,490
That's what you should do.

72
00:03:17,490 --> 00:03:21,350
And that's why snapshots are useful but,
if you've got a single server instance

73
00:03:21,350 --> 00:03:24,200
then you really need to use whatever
backup solution your operating system has.

74
00:03:24,200 --> 00:03:26,650
Cuz they'll likely run while
the server is up and running.

75
00:03:26,650 --> 00:03:29,940
>> Yeah, I used to use snapshots a lot
when I was upgrading software on servers.

76
00:03:29,940 --> 00:03:34,810
This made my life infinitely more easy
than it did before we had snapshots.

77
00:03:34,810 --> 00:03:38,520
I could shut that server down,
take a snapshot of it and

78
00:03:38,520 --> 00:03:43,045
I knew if anything went wrong,
which things like that tend to happen,

79
00:03:43,045 --> 00:03:45,140
[LAUGH] I could just roll
back to that snapshot.

80
00:03:45,140 --> 00:03:46,680
Everything would be the way it was.

81
00:03:46,680 --> 00:03:50,160
Try to figure out what went wrong with
that software installation or upgrade or

82
00:03:50,160 --> 00:03:52,490
whatever the case may be and
then move from there.

83
00:03:52,490 --> 00:03:54,840
And then again, take another snapshot.

84
00:03:54,840 --> 00:03:58,360
And try to reinstall work from there or
maybe have to call a vendor at that point.

85
00:03:58,360 --> 00:04:02,740
But it made my life so much easier cuz
I didn't have to worry about messing up

86
00:04:02,740 --> 00:04:06,310
the server and having to roll back or
restore from tape or anything like that.

87
00:04:07,490 --> 00:04:09,920
>> Now the snapshot process
itself is really simple.

88
00:04:09,920 --> 00:04:11,230
So it is super easy to use.

89
00:04:11,230 --> 00:04:13,187
Let me show you here on
some instances that I have.

90
00:04:13,187 --> 00:04:14,957
So, here are my instances, I've got two.

91
00:04:14,957 --> 00:04:18,270
Now I do have a web server that's up and
running right now.

92
00:04:18,270 --> 00:04:20,190
And I've got a web
server that's shut down.

93
00:04:20,190 --> 00:04:23,910
That they're actually the same image, so
that they are configured the same way.

94
00:04:23,910 --> 00:04:27,360
I can take a snapshot of either one,
now you might think, hey,

95
00:04:27,360 --> 00:04:28,730
I'm gonna take a snapshot of the server.

96
00:04:28,730 --> 00:04:31,220
I need to come right here
under instances and do it.

97
00:04:31,220 --> 00:04:33,860
But one of the things you'll notices is
that, when you start going in here and

98
00:04:33,860 --> 00:04:35,390
looking through your options.

99
00:04:35,390 --> 00:04:39,090
That there's not really
an option to take a snapshot.

100
00:04:39,090 --> 00:04:42,790
And that's because the snapshot
is not a snapshot of the running

101
00:04:42,790 --> 00:04:46,330
configuration of that instance,
it's a snapshot of the volumes.

102
00:04:46,330 --> 00:04:50,040
So I really need to go to the drives,
down here, to Volumes.

103
00:04:50,040 --> 00:04:52,200
And I can create the snapshot
one of two ways.

104
00:04:52,200 --> 00:04:55,790
I can go to Volumes,
pick the drive here, and

105
00:04:55,790 --> 00:04:57,970
then under Actions,
we have Create a Snapshot.

106
00:04:57,970 --> 00:04:59,680
I can snapshot the drive.

107
00:04:59,680 --> 00:05:03,630
Or I can go to the Snapshots menu,
and right from here, I can hit

108
00:05:03,630 --> 00:05:08,480
Create Snapshot, and I can come in and I
can pick the volume there too, all right?

109
00:05:08,480 --> 00:05:10,280
Either way, it's the same thing.

110
00:05:10,280 --> 00:05:12,570
You're just taking
a snapshot of that drive.

111
00:05:12,570 --> 00:05:14,370
The challenge though,
are the volume names.

112
00:05:15,540 --> 00:05:18,190
Which one belongs to which server?

113
00:05:18,190 --> 00:05:20,390
It's hard to tell here.

114
00:05:20,390 --> 00:05:23,280
And that's where we need to make sure
that we label things, and that way,

115
00:05:23,280 --> 00:05:25,080
we're able to track what they belong to.

116
00:05:25,080 --> 00:05:27,870
So when I go up here to Volumes,
I see these two volumes.

117
00:05:27,870 --> 00:05:30,120
I know they belong to my two web servers.

118
00:05:30,120 --> 00:05:35,140
And if you click on them, you'll see
down here information about that system,

119
00:05:35,140 --> 00:05:37,250
including what server they're attached to.

120
00:05:37,250 --> 00:05:41,650
So I can see that this volume,
the top one, is attached to ITProTVweb01.

121
00:05:41,650 --> 00:05:44,430
So I might add that to the name, just so

122
00:05:44,430 --> 00:05:46,130
that I can remember that's
who it's attached to.

123
00:05:46,130 --> 00:05:48,420
And I just know by process of elimination.

124
00:05:48,420 --> 00:05:54,640
This guy's ITProTVweb00, where I can see
that right down here in the information.

125
00:05:54,640 --> 00:05:58,580
So now, I've labelled my volumes and
I know which one belongs to which.

126
00:05:58,580 --> 00:06:00,570
So if I want to take
a snapshot of one server or

127
00:06:00,570 --> 00:06:03,970
the other, I can pick the correct volume,
all right?

128
00:06:03,970 --> 00:06:06,170
So I'll start here with ITProTVweb01.

129
00:06:06,170 --> 00:06:07,720
That's the one that's running right now.

130
00:06:07,720 --> 00:06:09,200
So it is running.

131
00:06:09,200 --> 00:06:11,940
And you'll see, I can create a snapshot.

132
00:06:11,940 --> 00:06:14,050
It'll let me create a snapshot
of that running machine.

133
00:06:14,050 --> 00:06:17,100
It will create a micro-outage.

134
00:06:17,100 --> 00:06:19,610
So for a couple of seconds,
that machine will freeze for

135
00:06:19,610 --> 00:06:22,240
a moment while it goes to grab that drive.

136
00:06:22,240 --> 00:06:24,550
So if this is a mission critical system,

137
00:06:24,550 --> 00:06:28,490
if I have to have this thing,
that micro-outage might be a problem.

138
00:06:28,490 --> 00:06:31,340
So again, snapshots,
we've got to be careful with it but

139
00:06:31,340 --> 00:06:32,850
if it's not super critical.
