All right, now because I chose SSL,

596
00:28:29,820 --> 00:28:32,760
here it's asking me to
upload my SSL certificate.

597
00:28:32,760 --> 00:28:36,230
I've gotta upload it because they're
gonna terminate the encryption

598
00:28:36,230 --> 00:28:39,440
on the load balancer and
not on the end units.

599
00:28:39,440 --> 00:28:41,480
The end units won't even see
the encryption which is kind of nice,

600
00:28:41,480 --> 00:28:44,780
takes a load off of them and
shifts the load over to Amazon.

601
00:28:44,780 --> 00:28:47,630
So I'd need to provide that
certificate information right here.

602
00:28:48,840 --> 00:28:51,540
Now if I have it already uploaded for
something else,

603
00:28:51,540 --> 00:28:52,810
I'd be able to choose that.

604
00:28:52,810 --> 00:28:53,530
I don't have one.

605
00:28:53,530 --> 00:28:55,380
So I'm actually gonna back
up just a little bit,

606
00:28:55,380 --> 00:28:59,123
and I'm gonna remove HTTPS from this list,
just to keep it simple.

607
00:29:00,840 --> 00:29:03,910
All right, so now you're gonna see it
doesn't ask about the certificate, so

608
00:29:03,910 --> 00:29:04,920
I just move right past that.

609
00:29:06,280 --> 00:29:07,460
Now a health check.

610
00:29:07,460 --> 00:29:10,750
When you have a load balancer, you've got
one or more servers behind it, right?

611
00:29:10,750 --> 00:29:12,820
And if one of those servers were to fail,

612
00:29:12,820 --> 00:29:14,810
you don't want to keep
sending traffic to it, right?

613
00:29:14,810 --> 00:29:18,100
Going back to my diagram,
we'll say this server right here failed.

614
00:29:18,100 --> 00:29:21,200
Well, I don't want to keep sending traffic
to a server that's dead in the water, so

615
00:29:21,200 --> 00:29:23,960
we can configure a basic health
check to say, look at the server and

616
00:29:23,960 --> 00:29:25,240
see if it's working.

617
00:29:25,240 --> 00:29:26,800
And if it is, keep sending traffic to it.

618
00:29:26,800 --> 00:29:28,800
But if it isn't, take it out of the pool.

619
00:29:28,800 --> 00:29:29,870
Don't send traffic to it anymore.

620
00:29:31,520 --> 00:29:35,050
Now, the default health check is HTTP,
HTTPS, and SSL.

621
00:29:35,050 --> 00:29:37,240
You can also do TCP, right?

622
00:29:37,240 --> 00:29:39,120
Which means you can check on any port.

623
00:29:39,120 --> 00:29:43,390
But when you do this, like TCP port 21,
it just sees that it connects.

624
00:29:43,390 --> 00:29:45,100
It doesn't actually see if it works.

625
00:29:45,100 --> 00:29:47,722
So maybe that's like a MySQL
server on the back end.

626
00:29:47,722 --> 00:29:51,570
So it'll verify that the server
is able to be connected to, but

627
00:29:51,570 --> 00:29:54,710
it won't make sure that it actually
is able to respond to a query.

628
00:29:54,710 --> 00:29:56,960
So it is somewhat limited
with the health check here.

629
00:29:58,480 --> 00:30:00,380
Fortunately I did HTTP,
so it's easy enough.

630
00:30:00,380 --> 00:30:02,810
You can specify a page for it to request.

631
00:30:02,810 --> 00:30:05,190
And a port number, all right?

632
00:30:05,190 --> 00:30:07,540
You can also set your intervals down here.

633
00:30:07,540 --> 00:30:10,500
When it's doing a health check,
how often do you want it to check, and

634
00:30:10,500 --> 00:30:12,471
how long do you want it to
wait before it responds?

635
00:30:12,471 --> 00:30:15,490
You can see my response
timeout is five seconds.

636
00:30:15,490 --> 00:30:19,660
So I'm gonna send a request and
I expect a response within five seconds.

637
00:30:19,660 --> 00:30:23,034
If I don't get a response in five seconds,
I'll assume that node's down.

638
00:30:23,034 --> 00:30:26,050
I'm gonna check it every thirty seconds.

639
00:30:26,050 --> 00:30:28,250
So twice a minute I'm a little server and

640
00:30:28,250 --> 00:30:30,990
I expect to get a response
within five seconds.

641
00:30:30,990 --> 00:30:34,930
If I get two failures in a row,
then I'll assume the node is down.

642
00:30:36,100 --> 00:30:42,030
And I won't bring the node back up
until it passes ten consecutive checks.

643
00:30:42,030 --> 00:30:45,350
So, two failures, checking every
thirty seconds, that's one minute.

644
00:30:45,350 --> 00:30:48,830
If the server goes down for
a minute I'll take it out of the pool.

645
00:30:48,830 --> 00:30:52,230
But the server will have to be up for five
minutes before I put it back in the pool.

646
00:30:52,230 --> 00:30:53,850
That's the guaranteed stability, right?

647
00:30:53,850 --> 00:30:55,859
You don't want that server just
coming up and then disappearing.

648
00:30:57,600 --> 00:31:00,120
You can tweak all these numbers
to be appropriate for you.

649
00:31:00,120 --> 00:31:01,940
Maybe 30 seconds is too long.

650
00:31:01,940 --> 00:31:06,270
Maybe you wanna go ten seconds and
set your own healthy threshold of three.

651
00:31:06,270 --> 00:31:10,840
So now if 3 ten-second checks fail
that's 30 seconds before we respond.

652
00:31:10,840 --> 00:31:14,200
It just kind of speeds up
that response time, and

653
00:31:14,200 --> 00:31:19,050
then you can set what that healthy
threshold is to whatever you want.

654
00:31:19,050 --> 00:31:21,210
Now, we tell who's going to
be in this load balancer.

655
00:31:21,210 --> 00:31:22,550
That's what I said a minute ago.

656
00:31:22,550 --> 00:31:24,665
So.
>> You just love this part.

657
00:31:24,665 --> 00:31:26,670
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I'm kinda used to doing this

658
00:31:26,670 --> 00:31:29,320
with an auto scaling group,
which if you haven't checked it out,

659
00:31:29,320 --> 00:31:32,560
our auto scaling group is how we
can dynamically add servers that

660
00:31:32,560 --> 00:31:34,380
create new instances on the fly.

661
00:31:34,380 --> 00:31:37,180
Because with that it automatically
adds in the load balancer, and

662
00:31:37,180 --> 00:31:39,180
I don't have to go and specify this.

663
00:31:39,180 --> 00:31:40,480
But we're doing a manual load balancer,

664
00:31:40,480 --> 00:31:42,550
we do, we just have to check
off the servers that we want.

665
00:31:42,550 --> 00:31:46,060
So I'll come in here and I'll say,
I want this guy and this guy.

666
00:31:46,060 --> 00:31:46,880
I'll pick these two servers.

667
00:31:46,880 --> 00:31:48,100
Now one of them is already down.

668
00:31:48,100 --> 00:31:50,720
So it's gonna fail the health check,
but the other guy should be happy.

669
00:31:52,530 --> 00:31:53,620
And so I hit next.

670
00:31:53,620 --> 00:31:55,740
I can assign any tags I want,
and then I'm done.

671
00:31:55,740 --> 00:31:57,120
Right?
We can go in and

672
00:31:57,120 --> 00:32:00,530
review our changes, and create that pool.

673
00:32:00,530 --> 00:32:02,980
So now it's gonna create
the load balancer.

674
00:32:02,980 --> 00:32:04,570
It's got two servers in it.

675
00:32:04,570 --> 00:32:07,600
And any connections coming in that load
balancer are gonna get distributed across

676
00:32:07,600 --> 00:32:09,229
those two nodes, and we're in business.

677
00:32:10,900 --> 00:32:14,140
Now technically,
the load balancer is done.

678
00:32:14,140 --> 00:32:20,100
Any traffic sent to the itprotv-demofile
load balancer is gonna be distributed

679
00:32:20,100 --> 00:32:23,430
across the servers that are in it, and
I've got two instances right there.

680
00:32:23,430 --> 00:32:26,090
But there's usually one
more thing we have to do.

681
00:32:26,090 --> 00:32:28,990
This load balancer has a name, a DNS name.

682
00:32:28,990 --> 00:32:31,090
And here's my DNS name, right?

683
00:32:31,090 --> 00:32:35,840
So if I were to give that to my customers,
oh you want to browse through our website?

684
00:32:35,840 --> 00:32:37,040
Here's the address right here.

685
00:32:37,040 --> 00:32:38,215
Just browse through that.

686
00:32:38,215 --> 00:32:39,605
It rolls right off the tongue, right?

687
00:32:39,605 --> 00:32:40,947
>> I've got it memorized.

688
00:32:40,947 --> 00:32:44,485
[LAUGH]
>> itprotv-demofile-whatever.

689
00:32:44,485 --> 00:32:46,715
The server must not be up yet.

690
00:32:46,715 --> 00:32:49,025
So we provide that, and you can get to it.

691
00:32:49,025 --> 00:32:52,095
Well, that's not really a name
we want to give out to people.

692
00:32:52,095 --> 00:32:54,580
So what you're normally going
to do is go to your DNS zone.

693
00:32:54,580 --> 00:32:55,180
Right?

694
00:32:55,180 --> 00:32:57,000
And you'll create what's called a CNAME,
or

695
00:32:57,000 --> 00:33:01,610
a Canonical Name Record,
that says file.itpro.tv, or

696
00:33:01,610 --> 00:33:06,470
whatever name it is that you want,
file.donshouse.com.

697
00:33:06,470 --> 00:33:09,659
And you'll point that CNAME at
this nice big long name here.

698
00:33:10,860 --> 00:33:15,320
And that's how it's gonna know to
redirect your name to this load balancer.

699
00:33:15,320 --> 00:33:17,700
And because it's a C name,
your end users won't see it.

700
00:33:17,700 --> 00:33:18,880
Your end users will see what they type.

701
00:33:18,880 --> 00:33:21,150
They'll see file.itpro.tv.

702
00:33:21,150 --> 00:33:23,140
And that'll point over to it.

703
00:33:23,140 --> 00:33:27,520
So, if you're using
Amazon's Route 53 service for

704
00:33:27,520 --> 00:33:29,490
DNS, check out our Route 53 episode.

705
00:33:29,490 --> 00:33:32,350
We'll show how to do that,
how to create those CNAMES.

706
00:33:32,350 --> 00:33:36,880
If you're using your own provider though,
like Go Daddy, or Hover, Register.com,

707
00:33:36,880 --> 00:33:39,530
any of those guys, then you'll
have to go to that provider and

708
00:33:39,530 --> 00:33:40,638
create a scene in record there.

709
00:33:40,638 --> 00:33:43,250
And they all do it a little different, so
you might have to contact their support.

710
00:33:44,960 --> 00:33:47,370
But otherwise, that's basically
a load balancer and it's in place.

711
00:33:47,370 --> 00:33:52,260
So, those were three additional steps
that we take on instances that we create

712
00:33:52,260 --> 00:33:56,910
snapshots for backup, Static IPs, so that
we always know where that nodes gonna be,

713
00:33:56,910 --> 00:34:01,060
and then load balancing to distribute
traffic across more than one node.

714
00:34:01,060 --> 00:34:02,190
>> Very awesome stuff, Don.

715
00:34:02,190 --> 00:34:02,750
Really good.

716
00:34:02,750 --> 00:34:05,290
I hope you guys out there
have learned a lot from this.

717
00:34:05,290 --> 00:34:06,580
I know I sure have.

718
00:34:06,580 --> 00:34:08,490
So, have we missed anything?

719
00:34:08,490 --> 00:34:09,640
We got any other thing to cover?

720
00:34:09,640 --> 00:34:10,310
>> I think that's it.

721
00:34:10,310 --> 00:34:13,090
>> All right, well that being said,
I guess that's all we have for

722
00:34:13,090 --> 00:34:15,280
this episode by ITProTV.

723
00:34:15,280 --> 00:34:16,140
Signing off.

724
00:34:16,140 --> 00:34:17,680
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

725
00:34:17,680 --> 00:34:18,350
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

726
00:34:18,350 --> 00:34:20,595
>> And we'll see you next time.

727
00:34:20,595 --> 00:34:25,219

episodes.title: Storing Data in S3
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,990
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,990 --> 00:00:15,550
All right everyone, greetings and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15,550 --> 00:00:19,430
I'll be your host today, Daniel Lowrie,
and here with me today is Don Pezet.

4
00:00:19,430 --> 00:00:20,350
How you doing today Don?

5
00:00:20,350 --> 00:00:21,170
>> I'm doing great.

6
00:00:21,170 --> 00:00:25,260
Today, Daniel, we're gonna be
jumping into the world of Amazon S3

7
00:00:25,260 --> 00:00:27,170
which is their hosted storage solution.

8
00:00:27,170 --> 00:00:30,120
And really we're gonna talk a little
bit about hosted storage in general.

9
00:00:30,120 --> 00:00:31,398
But it's a great technology.

10
00:00:31,398 --> 00:00:34,810
I call it the gateway technology into

11
00:00:34,810 --> 00:00:37,630
AWS cuz it's where a lot
of people get started.

12
00:00:37,630 --> 00:00:40,129
It's one of the easier ones to deploy and
it's super efficient so

13
00:00:40,129 --> 00:00:41,319
it's a great one to work with.

14
00:00:41,319 --> 00:00:42,220
>> Yeah.

15
00:00:42,220 --> 00:00:44,790
Nothing like saying, hey I got some data.

16
00:00:44,790 --> 00:00:45,515
Won't you hold this for me?

17
00:00:45,515 --> 00:00:49,560
[LAUGH]
>> So a lot of companies are faced with

18
00:00:49,560 --> 00:00:52,610
an issue where they've got some
data that they wanna hand out and

19
00:00:52,610 --> 00:00:54,330
they need a way to
distribute that information.

20
00:00:54,330 --> 00:00:57,840
So if I have, let's say I have a PDF,
right, just a document.

21
00:00:57,840 --> 00:01:00,030
And I wanna distribute
that all my viewers.

22
00:01:00,030 --> 00:01:03,120
Well, if I have a server that's connected
to the Internet I can put the file on

23
00:01:03,120 --> 00:01:05,190
there and then people could go and
download it.

24
00:01:05,190 --> 00:01:07,043
But there's two things
I have to worry about.

25
00:01:07,043 --> 00:01:08,620
One, maintaining that server.

26
00:01:08,620 --> 00:01:11,574
Right, so somebody could break into
that server get my data or whatever.

27
00:01:11,574 --> 00:01:13,850
And two, bandwidth.

28
00:01:13,850 --> 00:01:15,870
I've only got so much bandwidth.

29
00:01:15,870 --> 00:01:19,690
But there's this little old company called
Amazon, and boy, do they have bandwidth.

30
00:01:19,690 --> 00:01:24,410
They have tons and tons of bandwidth,
and the best part is you just pay for

31
00:01:24,410 --> 00:01:25,750
what you use.

32
00:01:25,750 --> 00:01:29,370
So I can put files up in
Amazon's Web Services.

33
00:01:29,370 --> 00:01:32,792
They can serve it out to the world and
I just pay for what I actually use,

34
00:01:32,792 --> 00:01:35,699
using their infrastructure
that's what it's all about.

35
00:01:35,699 --> 00:01:39,316
So, S3 is their primary
storage product and

36
00:01:39,316 --> 00:01:44,268
with S3 it's just a scalable
storage solution from them that

37
00:01:44,268 --> 00:01:49,520
lets you put files up in the cloud and
then people can download it.

38
00:01:49,520 --> 00:01:50,946
Now it's a little bit
more complex than that.

39
00:01:50,946 --> 00:01:53,060
I mean, at it's basis that's what it is.

40
00:01:53,060 --> 00:01:54,660
You go to the files there and
people can download.

41
00:01:54,660 --> 00:01:56,010
But it's got a lot of power,

42
00:01:56,010 --> 00:02:00,670
in that you can control who is allowed to
access the files, how they get downloaded.

43
00:02:00,670 --> 00:02:03,500
You can even host a static
website out of this thing,

44
00:02:03,500 --> 00:02:05,450
you can do all sorts of
crazy stuff with S3.

45
00:02:05,450 --> 00:02:07,410
So let's dive into it, take a look at it.

46
00:02:07,410 --> 00:02:09,240
We'll get a chance to see
that technology in action.

47
00:02:10,380 --> 00:02:13,700
All right so, I'm logged into
my web services console here and

48
00:02:13,700 --> 00:02:16,880
right down under storage and content
delivery, we'll see S3 right there.

49
00:02:16,880 --> 00:02:19,760
You can always recognize which
ones are the most popular

50
00:02:19,760 --> 00:02:22,850
products from Amazon because they're
always the first in their category, right?

51
00:02:22,850 --> 00:02:24,330
So under Compute, it's EC2.

52
00:02:24,330 --> 00:02:26,290
Under Database, it's RDS.

53
00:02:26,290 --> 00:02:28,990
Under Storage Content Delivery, it's S3.

54
00:02:28,990 --> 00:02:31,470
Now, there are several
other services in here.

55
00:02:31,470 --> 00:02:33,830
Let me just mention those
briefly before we dive into S3.

56
00:02:33,830 --> 00:02:37,600
Some of these are kind of datas or
specialized,

57
00:02:37,600 --> 00:02:41,400
but Glacier is another one
that's gaining in popularity.

58
00:02:41,400 --> 00:02:45,119
When we store our files on S3 it's
stored on redundant storage, and

59
00:02:45,119 --> 00:02:48,772
that means if there's a failure at
Amazon site our data stays safe,

60
00:02:48,772 --> 00:02:53,538
it's up, and it's good fast storage too,
so you'll get great performance out of it.

61
00:02:53,538 --> 00:02:58,171
But maybe you have data that you want to
store up in the Amazon that you don't need

62
00:02:58,171 --> 00:03:00,332
fast storage you just need storage.

63
00:03:00,332 --> 00:03:02,860
Maybe putting backups up there, right?

64
00:03:02,860 --> 00:03:05,000
So, I don't need my backup
storage to be fast,

65
00:03:05,000 --> 00:03:07,900
cuz I'm only gonna go to that
storage if I have a failure, right?

66
00:03:07,900 --> 00:03:10,900
So you can use Glacier, instead.

67
00:03:10,900 --> 00:03:12,900
It's not as good of a storage.

68
00:03:12,900 --> 00:03:14,020
Amazon does back it up.

69
00:03:14,020 --> 00:03:16,070
If there's a failure it may
actually go offline, but

70
00:03:16,070 --> 00:03:17,390
they'll bring it back online again.

71
00:03:17,390 --> 00:03:18,920
It doesn't have the same
level of redundancy.

72
00:03:18,920 --> 00:03:21,410
It doesn't have the same
level of performance.

73
00:03:21,410 --> 00:03:24,580
And the tradeoff for that,
for giving up performance and

74
00:03:24,580 --> 00:03:27,030
stability, is that it's a lot cheaper.

75
00:03:27,030 --> 00:03:27,960
So if you're just looking for

76
00:03:27,960 --> 00:03:32,040
something to sit up there and wait
until you need it, you can use Glacier.

77
00:03:32,040 --> 00:03:34,610
It's a lot less expensive, and
it's archive storage in the cloud.

78
00:03:35,710 --> 00:03:37,590
Another option is CloudFront.

79
00:03:37,590 --> 00:03:41,410
When we use S3, we're putting our
files into Amazon's cloud, and

80
00:03:41,410 --> 00:03:44,060
it's going to one of
their availability zones.

81
00:03:44,060 --> 00:03:48,140
So let's say I pick the US East,
the Virginia, data center.

82
00:03:48,140 --> 00:03:49,510
So my files are there.

83
00:03:49,510 --> 00:03:51,840
Well, for my users that are in
the Eastern United States,

84
00:03:51,840 --> 00:03:54,920
they go to download those files and
they get them, it's great, right?

85
00:03:54,920 --> 00:04:00,080
But if you're in China, Australia,
Singapore, you're somewhere like that,

86
00:04:00,080 --> 00:04:03,530
you gotta come all the way over to
the Eastern US to download this file, and

87
00:04:03,530 --> 00:04:04,290
it's going to be slower.

88
00:04:04,290 --> 00:04:06,080
They're gonna have a worse experience.

89
00:04:06,080 --> 00:04:09,170
Well if you only do business within
the eastern region of the US,

90
00:04:09,170 --> 00:04:10,810
then you don't care about that, right?

91
00:04:10,810 --> 00:04:13,070
But if you're a global
company that's a problem.

92
00:04:13,070 --> 00:04:17,610
What CloudFront does is it says if
you upload a file into CloudFront,

93
00:04:17,610 --> 00:04:21,850
it will replicate it across Amazon's
data centers all over the world.

94
00:04:21,850 --> 00:04:24,620
And so if you're in the Eastern US and
you go to download that file,

95
00:04:24,620 --> 00:04:26,940
it'll come from the Virginia data, but

96
00:04:26,940 --> 00:04:30,890
if you're in Singapore it'll come
from the East Asian data center.

97
00:04:30,890 --> 00:04:33,690
It'll come from a data center that's
geographically close to you which

98
00:04:33,690 --> 00:04:35,980
means you get better

At least officially for a general?

558
00:26:22,530 --> 00:26:25,030
>> For an introductory level S3,
I think we've covered the bases.

559
00:26:25,030 --> 00:26:25,660
>> Excellent.

560
00:26:25,660 --> 00:26:29,160
Well, I guess that being said, we've come
to the end of another great episode.

561
00:26:29,160 --> 00:26:31,960
So for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

562
00:26:31,960 --> 00:26:32,711
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

563
00:26:32,711 --> 00:26:33,931
>> And we'll see you next time.

564
00:26:33,931 --> 00:26:40,000

episodes.title: Databases in AWS
episodes.transcript:
1

2
00:00:10,321 --> 00:00:11,262
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11,262 --> 00:00:14,301
Greetings, and welcome to another
great episode if ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,301 --> 00:00:16,060
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:16,060 --> 00:00:17,350
Here with me today is Don Pezet.

6
00:00:17,350 --> 00:00:18,400
How are you doing today Don?

7
00:00:18,400 --> 00:00:19,330
>> I'm doing great Dan.

8
00:00:19,330 --> 00:00:22,860
You know today we're gonna be jumping
back into Amazon Web Services,

9
00:00:22,860 --> 00:00:27,540
and we're gonna be looking at
building a relational database

10
00:00:27,540 --> 00:00:30,940
completely hosted an Amazon Web Services
cloud which is a pretty awesome thing.

11
00:00:30,940 --> 00:00:34,305
>> Yeah, I'm not related to any databases,
but I guess we can build one, right?

12
00:00:34,305 --> 00:00:36,390
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

13
00:00:36,390 --> 00:00:39,905
in business today,
databases have become extremely important.

14
00:00:39,905 --> 00:00:42,215
People need to be able to store data and

15
00:00:42,215 --> 00:00:44,515
return it when they need
to gather information.

16
00:00:44,515 --> 00:00:45,625
There's a lot of web sites,

17
00:00:45,625 --> 00:00:50,585
like WordPress backed websites, where all
the content is coming out of a database.

18
00:00:50,585 --> 00:00:53,085
Or if you've got an e-commerce site,
all your sales and

19
00:00:53,085 --> 00:00:54,355
inventory is in that database.

20
00:00:54,355 --> 00:00:56,560
These are really important things.

21
00:00:56,560 --> 00:00:59,580
>> Well the traditional model
is that if you need a database,

22
00:00:59,580 --> 00:01:02,750
you build it up in your own data center
you know right in your own office.

23
00:01:02,750 --> 00:01:05,980
But there's shortcomings that come into
that when you decide to host your own

24
00:01:05,980 --> 00:01:09,870
database, and
they center mostly around the hardware and

25
00:01:09,870 --> 00:01:12,590
expertise needed to run database servers.

26
00:01:12,590 --> 00:01:14,440
>> Yeah.
The great thing about databases is that

27
00:01:14,440 --> 00:01:17,480
they require very little hardware and
very little expertise.

28
00:01:17,480 --> 00:01:19,500
And by that I mean the opposite of that.

29
00:01:19,500 --> 00:01:23,090
They require tons of hardware and
tons of expertise.

30
00:01:23,090 --> 00:01:27,320
I know I tried to build a few myself, and
just the resources necessary to keep those

31
00:01:27,320 --> 00:01:31,640
guys up and running, a lot of input output
kinda stuff, read writes and all that.

32
00:01:31,640 --> 00:01:33,580
It gets quite overwhelming.

33
00:01:33,580 --> 00:01:36,990
>> And the people who suffer from
this the most are developers,

34
00:01:36,990 --> 00:01:42,570
where you might be a top notch developer
able or just write anything you need in C,

35
00:01:42,570 --> 00:01:46,350
or whatever programming language you use,
but you don't know databases.

36
00:01:46,350 --> 00:01:50,370
That, sure you know how to do Transact-SQL
to store data in a database, but

37
00:01:50,370 --> 00:01:53,210
you don't know how to build
that database server itself.

38
00:01:53,210 --> 00:01:56,030
And so maybe you follow some tutorial on
the web, and you do a quick install, and

39
00:01:56,030 --> 00:01:58,140
you get it up and running,
but it's not secure.

40
00:01:58,140 --> 00:01:59,620
It's not scalable.

41
00:01:59,620 --> 00:02:03,950
The storage isn't tuned right, and
all of that has a significant impact.

42
00:02:03,950 --> 00:02:06,470
Maybe not when you have two
people in your database server.

43
00:02:06,470 --> 00:02:10,990
But when you have 200,000 people in that
database server, it makes a huge impact.

44
00:02:10,990 --> 00:02:14,020
So with the hosted database on AWS,

45
00:02:14,020 --> 00:02:17,270
what we're doing is we're we're
outsourcing that expertise.

46
00:02:17,270 --> 00:02:20,870
Amazon has some of the largest databases
in the world and that means they

47
00:02:20,870 --> 00:02:24,670
have some of the best database
administrator staff that you can ask for.

48
00:02:24,670 --> 00:02:28,810
And with a hosted relational database,
we're using their resources,

49
00:02:28,810 --> 00:02:29,730
their experts.

50
00:02:29,730 --> 00:02:34,300
They tune the databases, or they tune the
underlying infrastructure, the storage,

51
00:02:34,300 --> 00:02:38,170
the operating system they take care of
all of that, and what we end up with

52
00:02:38,170 --> 00:02:41,340
is really just a series of menu events
that we fill out that tells them what kind

53
00:02:41,340 --> 00:02:44,520
of database we want, and
then they help support it on the back end.

54
00:02:44,520 --> 00:02:45,970
It's a great solution.

55
00:02:45,970 --> 00:02:48,800
>> Nice to get that A-Team from Amazon,

56
00:02:48,800 --> 00:02:52,490
plus that awesome hardware that they
use to get all of this stuff running.

57
00:02:52,490 --> 00:02:56,429
>> And if you want full and
total control of your database than

58
00:02:56,429 --> 00:02:59,320
the Amazon's RDS service is not for
you, right?

59
00:02:59,320 --> 00:03:02,880
If you want full and total control
then the best bet to host in the cloud

60
00:03:02,880 --> 00:03:04,110
is to simply bring up an EC2 instance.

61
00:03:04,110 --> 00:03:08,630
And you can bring up a regular EC2 server,
and you can throw MySQL or

62
00:03:08,630 --> 00:03:12,130
Microsoft Sequel on there and
now you have full control over, all right?

63
00:03:12,130 --> 00:03:15,800
But if you wanna replicate between
availability zones and things like that,

64
00:03:15,800 --> 00:03:19,010
you've gotta set it up on your own, and
that requires knowledge of the database.

65
00:03:19,010 --> 00:03:22,180
And I know many DBAs out there
where that's exactly what they do.

66
00:03:22,180 --> 00:03:25,730
They say, no, I know how to run my
database, I know better than Amazon, so

67
00:03:25,730 --> 00:03:28,300
I wanna control it,
I'll do an EC2 instance.

68
00:03:28,300 --> 00:03:31,613
But if we wanna really take advantage
of the good stuff on Amazon,

69
00:03:31,613 --> 00:03:33,251
we wanna use their RDS service.

70
00:03:33,251 --> 00:03:36,087
So let's take a look at that service,
will spin up some databases, and

71
00:03:36,087 --> 00:03:37,760
get a chance can see
how all of that works.

72
00:03:38,920 --> 00:03:41,320
All right,
well I'm logged into my AWS console here,

73
00:03:41,320 --> 00:03:44,320
and buried away in the console here you've
got the database section down here.

74
00:03:44,320 --> 00:03:47,142
And there's a few different types
of databases that are available for

75
00:03:47,142 --> 00:03:48,930
different purposes.

76
00:03:48,930 --> 00:03:52,200
The RDS one, that's the relational
database service, and

77
00:03:52,200 --> 00:03:54,590
it's the most popular.

78
00:03:54,590 --> 00:03:56,930
Relational databases are pretty
much the standard for

79
00:03:56,930 --> 00:04:00,720
any kind of business analytics or
business intelligence.

80
00:04:00,720 --> 00:04:05,220
So we see where they support MySQL,
PostgreSQL, Oracle,

81
00:04:05,220 --> 00:04:09,200
Microsoft SQL, and Amazon Aurora,
their own internal build.

82
00:04:09,200 --> 00:04:13,390
So a couple of different database choices
to pick from there, and they add to that.

83
00:04:13,390 --> 00:04:15,210
When it first launched,
they only supported MySQL,

84
00:04:15,210 --> 00:04:19,820
and then they added Microsoft, and
they kind of continued to add to that.

85
00:04:19,820 --> 00:04:23,720
The other databases are a little
more specialized, like DynamoDB.

86
00:04:23,720 --> 00:04:26,810
That's not a relational database,
that's an object oriented database.

87
00:04:26,810 --> 00:04:29,940
So it doesn't have a schema,
it handles huge amounts of data.

88
00:04:29,940 --> 00:04:31,820
It's a NoSQL database.

89
00:04:31,820 --> 00:04:33,850
Right?
It's a Not Only SQL.

90
00:04:33,850 --> 00:04:36,680
You got Elasticache,
which is just designed for

91
00:04:36,680 --> 00:04:40,150
caching between servers if you're trying
to do, like, distributed authentication.

92
00:04:40,150 --> 00:04:44,940
And we've got Redshift which is
designed for massive scales of data.

93
00:04:44,940 --> 00:04:48,230
See how it says managed
petabyte scale data warehouses?

94
00:04:48,230 --> 00:04:51,760
So if you're sequencing the human genome
or something, and you've got tons and

95
00:04:51,760 --> 00:04:54,560
tons of data,
that's what redshift is designed for.

96
00:04:54,560 --> 00:04:57,440
But the most popular service is RDS,
and that's we're normally gonna go for.

97
00:04:59,410 --> 00:05:02,840
Now once you jump into RDS,
that's where you get a chance to see

98
00:05:02,840 --> 00:05:06,010
any databases that you've
already hosted with Amazon.

99
00:05:06,010 --> 00:05:09,640
And you'll have the opportunity to
go in and start to create more.

100
00:05:09,640 --> 00:05:14,300
So once we get into the RDS dashboard, if
you've already got some database instances

101
00:05:14,300 --> 00:05:17,110
created, you'll see information
about them right up here at the top.

102
00:05:17,110 --> 00:05:19,970
If you don't have any created then
these will all just say zero,

103
00:05:19,970 --> 00:05:22,300
and you've gotta
Launch DB Instance down here.

104
00:05:22,300 --> 00:05:23,740
That's typically where we wanna start.

105
00:05:23,740 --> 00:05:27,040
I wanna create a database instance,
and this is the wizard that does it.

106
00:05:28,110 --> 00:05:31,580
When we launch it, it's gonna
ask the most important question,

107
00:05:31,580 --> 00:05:33,750
which is,
what type of database do you want?

108
00:05:33,750 --> 00:05:37,190
I mentioned we had MySQL,
PostSQL, Oracle, SQL, so

109
00:05:37,190 --> 00:05:39,180
you had a few different
ones you can choose from.

110
00:05:39,180 --> 00:05:41,180
MySQL is the community edition.

111
00:05:41,180 --> 00:05:43,890
That's the free database
server from Oracle.

112
00:05:43,890 --> 00:05:48,010
There is a paid version, but Amazon
doesn't directly support that just yet.

113
00:05:48,010 --> 00:05:50,000
They're talking about
doing that in the future.

114
00:05:50,000 --> 00:05:51,850
But you can drop down here to Oracle.

115
00:05:51,850 --> 00:05:54,860
And that's where you've got the full
Oracle enterprise database server.

116
00:05:54,860 --> 00:05:56,580
And you can pick one of those installs.

117
00:05:56,580 --> 00:05:59,860
You got PostgreSQL,
which is another free database solution.

118
00:05:59,860 --> 00:06:04,500
And then you got Microsoft SQL Server,
which has a free edition, The Express, and

119
00:06:04,500 --> 00:06:07,600
then the other ones are paid
versions that you can choose.

120
00:06:07,600 --> 00:06:10,930
Now if I wanna create one,
I'll create a SQL server here.

121
00:06:10,930 --> 00:06:12,920
And I'll go with the standard edition.

122
00:06:12,920 --> 00:06:16,240
So I'm gonna whip up a standard
edition server and get that created.

123
00:06:16,240 --> 00:06:20,540
Now when I do that,
this is a paid software product.

124
00:06:20,540 --> 00:06:22,650
Microsoft SQL, you have to license that.

125
00:06:22,650 --> 00:06:25,020
It's not open source,
you can't just choose to run it.

126
00:06:25,020 --> 00:06:29,530
So when I choose that, one of the question
it's gonna ask me on a later screen

127
00:06:29,530 --> 00:06:31,310
is how I'm gonna handle my licensing.

128
00:06:31,310 --> 00:06:32,720
And there's a few different models, but

129
00:06:32,720 --> 00:06:37,660
the primary models are where we bring our
own license, and that means that we've

130
00:06:37,660 --> 00:06:39,820
already got it licensed through
an enterprise agreement or

131
00:06:39,820 --> 00:06:43,640
something like that with Microsoft,
and so we cover the license ourselves.

132
00:06:43,640 --> 00:06:48,680
Or you can choose license provided
where Amazon provides the license, and

133
00:06:48,680 --> 00:06:52,320
your per hour rate for
running that server is gonna up.

134
00:06:52,320 --> 00:06:53,860
The just charge a little
more to cover the license.

135
00:06:54,870 --> 00:06:58,360
All right, on the next screen it's
gonna ask how I wanna deploy this.

136
00:06:58,360 --> 00:07:00,510
If you're just testing and practicing,

137
00:07:00,510 --> 00:07:04,350
then you'll choose this option down here
which says this instance is intended for

138
00:07:04,350 --> 00:07:07,750
use outside of production, or
under the free usage tier.

139
00:07:07,750 --> 00:07:10,550
This means you're gonna have
a single database server.

140
00:07:10,550 --> 00:07:15,890
Just one server running in one region,
one zone, and just sitting there, right?

141
00:07:15,890 --> 00:07:17,890
If there's a failure,
that database will go offline,

142
00:07:17,890 --> 00:07:20,600
and that's not what we want in production.

143
00:07:20,600 --> 00:07:25,530
The other option is to do
a multi-availability zone deployment

144
00:07:25,530 --> 00:07:30,273
with Provisioned IOPS Storage,
and what all of that means is

145
00:07:30,273 --> 00:07:35,750
Amazon's gonna give you a highly scalable,
highly redundant database deployment,

146
00:07:35,750 --> 00:07:38,330
and you don't have to worry
about the details, right?

147
00:07:38,330 --> 00:07:40,440
Multiple availability zones.

148
00:07:40,440 --> 00:07:43,680
If I deploy this server in
the Virginia region, right,

149
00:07:43,680 --> 00:07:45,193
which is eastern United States.

150
00:07:45,193 --> 00:07:46,719
So if I deployed in that region,

151
00:07:46,719 --> 00:07:49,498
there's four availability
zones inside of that region.

152
00:07:49,498 --> 00:07:54,237
That means in Virginia, Amazon has
four completely isolated data centers

153
00:07:54,237 --> 00:07:59,139
that have separate power, separate
networks, separate infrastructure.

154
00:07:59,139 --> 00:08:00,975
Completely separate data centers.

155
00:08:00,975 --> 00:08:03,179
If I choose Multi-AZ Deployment,

156
00:08:03,179 --> 00:08:07,373
It's gonna give me a SQL server in
one of those availability zones.

157
00:08:07,373 --> 00:08:08,534
And at a minimum,

158
00:08:08,534 --> 00:08:13,690
it's gonna create a read-only
replica in one of the other zones.

159
00:08:13,690 --> 00:08:17,580
And that means that if my primary fails
I can flip over that replica, and

160
00:08:17,580 --> 00:08:20,110
we can make that the primary and
off we go.

161
00:08:20,110 --> 00:08:21,620
We avoid downtime.

162
00:08:21,620 --> 00:08:23,940
They set all that up for you.

163
00:08:23,940 --> 00:08:25,670
If you've ever set this up
on a database yourself,

164
00:08:25,670 --> 00:08:28,900
it's kinda challenging to get
the replication set up and all that.

165
00:08:28,900 --> 00:08:30,620
They take care of it for us.

166
00:08:30,620 --> 00:08:33,460
And then Provisioned iOS per second.

167
00:08:33,460 --> 00:08:38,260
What they're saying here is we're
gonna handle managing the storage.

168
00:08:38,260 --> 00:08:40,150
I know I've mentioned this in
some of our other episodes, but

169
00:08:40,150 --> 00:08:44,250
when you do a database server, storage
is a big challenge, the input, output.

170
00:08:44,250 --> 00:08:47,350
When you write to the hard drive and
when you read from the hard drive.

171
00:08:47,350 --> 00:08:49,330
If you've got an old app database, right?

172
00:08:49,330 --> 00:08:53,550
Online analysis processing, that's
a database where you do a lot of reads.

173
00:08:53,550 --> 00:08:58,787
Think about if you go to Amazon shopping
site and you go a search for X-Files DVD,

174
00:08:58,787 --> 00:09:02,858
right, it's gonna query
a database looking for responses.

175
00:09:02,858 --> 00:09:04,220
It's not gonna change the database.

176
00:09:04,220 --> 00:09:06,720
It's just looking for data and
bringing it back out.

177
00:09:06,720 --> 00:09:09,900
That's all app and
that's a heavy read operation.

178
00:09:09,900 --> 00:09:12,580
But then when you go to actually buy
something, you're creating an order and

179
00:09:12,580 --> 00:09:15,550
that order is being written to their
sales database, that's a write.

180
00:09:15,550 --> 00:09:18,460
That's online transaction processing or
OLTP.

181
00:09:18,460 --> 00:09:21,760
So, either way,
you need a certain level of reads and

182
00:09:21,760 --> 00:09:24,910
a certain level of writes to
be performed on a drive, and

183
00:09:24,910 --> 00:09:29,400
if the drive starts to get backed up then
the server is slower for your users.

184
00:09:29,400 --> 00:09:30,800
And you don't want that, right?

185
00:09:30,800 --> 00:09:35,090
So, back in the days when we did
our own hosted SQL servers or

186
00:09:35,090 --> 00:09:37,460
database servers,
you'd have to spec out the drives.

187
00:09:37,460 --> 00:09:40,750
You'd have to say, all right, I want two
drives mirrored for the OS, mirrored for

188
00:09:40,750 --> 00:09:41,730
redundancy.

189
00:09:41,730 --> 00:09:44,620
You'd have two drives mirrored for
the page file.

190
00:09:44,620 --> 00:09:48,170
You'd have a couple of drives either
mirrored or in a five array for

191
00:09:48,170 --> 00:09:51,720
the transaction log files
to handle faster writes.

192
00:09:51,720 --> 00:09:56,480
And then you'd have a bigger array that
was array ten for your database files and

193
00:09:56,480 --> 00:09:57,880
that would be for the reads.

194
00:09:57,880 --> 00:10:00,098
Then see they spec out all this hardware.

195
00:10:00,098 --> 00:10:01,650
And then you have to monitor the input and

196
00:10:01,650 --> 00:10:04,510
output on it to make sure the hardware
is able to keep up with the traffic.

197
00:10:04,510 --> 00:10:05,680
It's a lot of work.

198
00:10:05,680 --> 00:10:08,560
Well here they'll take care of it for
us, it's Provisioned IOPS.

199
00:10:08,560 --> 00:10:10,760
And if my servers start to get busy,
I can always go in here and

200
00:10:10,760 --> 00:10:13,380
bump up the instance to get
more performance out of it.

201
00:10:13,380 --> 00:10:14,430
It's no big deal, right?

202
00:10:14,430 --> 00:10:16,120
It's all managed for us.

203
00:10:16,120 --> 00:10:17,420
So this is what we typically want.

204
00:10:18,550 --> 00:10:22,080
Now, there is no free usage tier when
it comes to the multi-easy deployment.

205
00:10:22,080 --> 00:10:24,610
So if you're just learning,
you are gonna incur costs.

206
00:10:24,610 --> 00:10:27,381
Just make sure you delete your
instances when you're done with them.

207
00:10:27,381 --> 00:10:30,757
So now we get to the nitty gritty details
of this instance, where we go through and

208
00:10:30,757 --> 00:10:34,480
specify a few of things that we need to
understand before we deploy this, right?

209
00:10:34,480 --> 00:10:36,940
So here's that licensing
that I've mentioned.

210
00:10:36,940 --> 00:10:40,500
Am I gonna bring my own license or
am I getting a license included?

211
00:10:40,500 --> 00:10:43,660
Well I have my own license, but
I can't remember it offhand.

212
00:10:43,660 --> 00:10:45,580
I don't have my keys with me.

213
00:10:45,580 --> 00:10:48,500
So all good new license included
that means Amazon's gonna take care

214
00:10:48,500 --> 00:10:49,350
of the license.

215
00:10:49,350 --> 00:10:52,120
And I'll just pay a little more for
this database while it runs.

216
00:10:52,120 --> 00:10:54,010
>> I can't believe you didn't
memorize your key, Don.

217
00:10:54,010 --> 00:10:56,940
>> Those 25-digit Microsoft keys,
they're fun.

218
00:10:56,940 --> 00:10:57,697
>> So shank.

219
00:10:57,697 --> 00:11:00,800
>> [LAUGH] All right, then I've got my

00:21:57,350 --> 00:21:58,980
I can fire up the SQL Management Studio.

449
00:21:58,980 --> 00:22:00,830
I can go up here to connect.

450
00:22:02,180 --> 00:22:03,890
I'll connect to a database engine.

451
00:22:03,890 --> 00:22:06,010
I'm gonna provide that server name.

452
00:22:06,010 --> 00:22:07,040
I'm gonna get rid of the port.

453
00:22:07,040 --> 00:22:09,800
Since I use the default port,
I don't need to provide it.

454
00:22:09,800 --> 00:22:11,350
And then I can give it the username and

455
00:22:11,350 --> 00:22:14,400
password that I provided
during the set up.

456
00:22:14,400 --> 00:22:16,750
And once we get connected,
it's going to reach out,

457
00:22:16,750 --> 00:22:18,720
it's going to connect to that server.

458
00:22:18,720 --> 00:22:20,150
There it goes.

459
00:22:20,150 --> 00:22:22,740
And now I can start to create databases.

460
00:22:22,740 --> 00:22:25,970
I've already created one database in your
sales DB but I can create other ones.

461
00:22:25,970 --> 00:22:29,490
Maybe I can create a marketing database,
so I'll get that one punched in here.

462
00:22:31,540 --> 00:22:33,420
And we start to get that set, and

463
00:22:33,420 --> 00:22:36,920
now I've got more than one database
in the same instance but that's fine.

464
00:22:36,920 --> 00:22:40,160
Now, it's up to me to determine whether or
not I should separate these guys out or

465
00:22:40,160 --> 00:22:41,020
keep them together.

466
00:22:41,020 --> 00:22:43,020
I could always create more instances.

467
00:22:43,020 --> 00:22:45,110
But now I've got my databases, and

468
00:22:45,110 --> 00:22:48,340
I work with them just like they
were hosted right here in house.

469
00:22:48,340 --> 00:22:50,900
It doesn't matter to me that
it's in the cloud versus here.

470
00:22:50,900 --> 00:22:53,240
I connect to it, and
I work with it with the tools that I know.

471
00:22:53,240 --> 00:22:54,580
So if I'm a database administrator,

472
00:22:54,580 --> 00:22:56,550
I don't have to worry about
that cloud stuff anymore.

473
00:22:56,550 --> 00:22:57,960
I just work in the tools I know.

474
00:22:59,140 --> 00:23:00,260
MySQL is the same way.

475
00:23:00,260 --> 00:23:01,950
I can fire up, like, my SQL work bench,

476
00:23:01,950 --> 00:23:04,350
which I've got floating
around here somewhere, here.

477
00:23:04,350 --> 00:23:06,230
And I'll connect to my MySQL instance.

478
00:23:06,230 --> 00:23:08,300
Now, when I set this up.

479
00:23:08,300 --> 00:23:11,890
Again, I just punched in that server name,
right, that I pulled right from

480
00:23:11,890 --> 00:23:17,330
the console and my SQL runs on 3306 by
default for its ports, I punch that in.

481
00:23:17,330 --> 00:23:20,780
So you just provide basic data and
then you connect up.

482
00:23:20,780 --> 00:23:22,630
And it's gonna reach out and
connect to that server and

483
00:23:22,630 --> 00:23:25,260
once I'm in, now I'm connected.

484
00:23:25,260 --> 00:23:28,440
I just start working with
it just like I'm used to.

485
00:23:28,440 --> 00:23:32,690
Nothing too crazy as far
as working with the system.

486
00:23:32,690 --> 00:23:35,950
I've already created a little
sales database down here, and

487
00:23:35,950 --> 00:23:39,090
I can go into my tables and
I can create a new table.

488
00:23:39,090 --> 00:23:40,740
And so this can be, like, sales receipts.

489
00:23:40,740 --> 00:23:45,860
And we start to add in our columns,
and all that other good stuff.

490
00:23:45,860 --> 00:23:47,170
Work with it like a normal database.

491
00:23:47,170 --> 00:23:48,170
>> Yeah, that's really awesome.

492
00:23:48,170 --> 00:23:52,100
I mean, for the fact that like,
I'm a developer, I need the database,

493
00:23:52,100 --> 00:23:54,990
I can just spin one of these
up very quickly, very easily.

494
00:23:54,990 --> 00:23:57,970
It didn't seem too difficult,
to be honest with you, and

495
00:23:57,970 --> 00:24:00,150
have that availability right then and
there, I can do that.

496
00:24:00,150 --> 00:24:04,445
I don't have to be a master of database
design or even the hardware, right?

497
00:24:04,445 --> 00:24:08,280
Cuz we come from the hardware area
where I gotta actually buy that stuff,

498
00:24:08,280 --> 00:24:10,410
I gotta implement it,
I gotta stick it in a server rack.

499
00:24:10,410 --> 00:24:14,030
I gotta connect it all to the network,
create firewall rules, all that business.

500
00:24:14,030 --> 00:24:16,220
Not here, there it's just super easy.

501
00:24:16,220 --> 00:24:18,028
This is really the way to go for database.

502
00:24:18,028 --> 00:24:20,630
>> Yeah, especially if you're
like an internet startup and

503
00:24:20,630 --> 00:24:24,311
you've hired your web developers cuz you
know your website is really important.

504
00:24:24,311 --> 00:24:28,220
You haven't hired any DBAs, you're not big
enough to have database administrator yet.

505
00:24:28,220 --> 00:24:30,220
You don't wanna deal
with that administration.

506
00:24:30,220 --> 00:24:31,670
Let Amazon take care of it for you.

507
00:24:31,670 --> 00:24:33,230
Host it right there, spins up.

508
00:24:33,230 --> 00:24:34,510
You don't have to worry about it.

509
00:24:34,510 --> 00:24:35,460
And if you have problems with it.

510
00:24:35,460 --> 00:24:36,440
The best part?

511
00:24:36,440 --> 00:24:38,000
Just get on the phone and call Amazon.

512
00:24:38,000 --> 00:24:39,580
Or do an email,
support ticket, or whatever.

513
00:24:39,580 --> 00:24:40,870
Hey, my database is running slow.

514
00:24:40,870 --> 00:24:41,420
Can you look at it?

515
00:24:41,420 --> 00:24:43,400
And they'll actually look at it and
they'll say well,

516
00:24:43,400 --> 00:24:44,600
you're exceeding your IO's.

517
00:24:44,600 --> 00:24:46,380
We need to bump you up to this.

518
00:24:46,380 --> 00:24:50,210
What we'd really recommend instead
of doing general purpose SSDE,

519
00:24:50,210 --> 00:24:53,260
move over to the provisioned IOPS,
you know.

520
00:24:53,260 --> 00:24:56,310
You've got that option and
they'll help you, they'll manage it.

521
00:24:56,310 --> 00:24:57,520
It really does make sense.

522
00:24:57,520 --> 00:25:02,640
Now, the cost for this is a little
more than setting up your own server.

523
00:25:02,640 --> 00:25:06,060
You normally have, like,
the EC2 instances that you spin up.

524
00:25:06,060 --> 00:25:09,050
Here you're paying more
because the management, right?

525
00:25:09,050 --> 00:25:13,450
So, for example, you might pay $0.08
an hour, or $0.20 an hour, or whatever.

526
00:25:13,450 --> 00:25:16,840
For an EC2 instance you might pay $0.30 or
$0.34 an hour for

527
00:25:16,840 --> 00:25:19,660
that database instance,
it's more expensive.

528
00:25:19,660 --> 00:25:22,710
But the tradeoff is you get management
out of it, you get support,

529
00:25:22,710 --> 00:25:27,720
you get redundancy, automated backups,
it really is a great, great service.

530
00:25:27,720 --> 00:25:31,680
>> Yeah, I wouldn't mind letting somebody
else handle that job, that's for sure.

531
00:25:31,680 --> 00:25:33,570
So you need a database, not a problem.

532
00:25:33,570 --> 00:25:34,910
Let me get that whipped up for

533
00:25:34,910 --> 00:25:37,810
you real quick and
not have to go through all that process.

534
00:25:37,810 --> 00:25:38,510
>> Absolutely.

535
00:25:38,510 --> 00:25:41,310
>> All right, Don,
have we covered the Amazon database?

536
00:25:41,310 --> 00:25:42,490
>> Yeah, that's basically it.

537
00:25:42,490 --> 00:25:44,170
>> Awesome.
It was great stuff.

538
00:25:44,170 --> 00:25:45,000
I really enjoyed it.

539
00:25:45,000 --> 00:25:46,360
I hope you guys did as well.

540
00:25:46,360 --> 00:25:49,620
That being said, I guess we've come to the
end of another great episode of ITProTV.

541
00:25:49,620 --> 00:25:51,830
I've been you're host Daniel Lowrie.

542
00:25:51,830 --> 00:25:52,490
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

543
00:25:52,490 --> 00:25:53,790
>> And we'll see you next time.

544
00:25:53,790 --> 00:26:00,020

episodes.title: Auto Scaling in EC2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,528
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,528 --> 00:00:13,961
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13,961 --> 00:00:15,860
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:15,860 --> 00:00:17,720
Here with me today is my
good friend Don Pezet.

5
00:00:17,720 --> 00:00:18,920
How are you doing today, Don?

6
00:00:18,920 --> 00:00:21,110
>> I'm doing great, Daniel, and
I'm excited about this episode.

7
00:00:21,110 --> 00:00:23,660
Because we get to talk about
one of the technologies that

8
00:00:23,660 --> 00:00:26,310
really makes the cloud useful.

9
00:00:26,310 --> 00:00:29,530
There's a lot of people out there that
still haven't moved any technologies into

10
00:00:29,530 --> 00:00:31,970
the cloud, and I can understand that.

11
00:00:31,970 --> 00:00:34,830
It's not really a necessity for everybody.

12
00:00:34,830 --> 00:00:36,400
Certain people need access to that.

13
00:00:36,400 --> 00:00:38,215
Certain people can really benefit from it.

14
00:00:38,215 --> 00:00:40,995
And one of the best ways to benefit

15
00:00:40,995 --> 00:00:43,865
is through use of a feature
called auto-scaling.

16
00:00:43,865 --> 00:00:46,385
And all the major cloud
providers provide this service.

17
00:00:46,385 --> 00:00:47,715
They give it different names, but

18
00:00:47,715 --> 00:00:50,285
most of them do actually
refer to it as auto-scaling.

19
00:00:50,285 --> 00:00:53,762
And it's the the ability
to instantaneously spin up

20
00:00:53,762 --> 00:00:57,212
new servers when you need them, and cut
out old servers when you don't need them.

21
00:00:57,212 --> 00:00:59,812
And it's really where you get
to truly take advantage of

22
00:00:59,812 --> 00:01:01,142
what the cloud has to offer.

23
00:01:01,142 --> 00:01:04,162
>> Yeah that is definitely a great
feature to be able to say,

24
00:01:04,162 --> 00:01:07,962
I can customize my servers and
everything on the fly.

25
00:01:07,962 --> 00:01:10,582
To be able to say well,
I don't need these servers right now.

26
00:01:10,582 --> 00:01:13,400
I mean just go ahead and decommission
them for as long as I need that.

27
00:01:13,400 --> 00:01:14,810
If I need them back, I spin them back up.

28
00:01:14,810 --> 00:01:16,600
I need new stuff, spin that up.

29
00:01:16,600 --> 00:01:17,430
I'm good to go.

30
00:01:17,430 --> 00:01:20,860
This is probably one of the biggest
selling points, I would say,

31
00:01:20,860 --> 00:01:21,960
about the cloud features.

32
00:01:21,960 --> 00:01:22,550
>> Yeah.

33
00:01:22,550 --> 00:01:25,550
So let's start with that concept of
Auto Scaling and how that works.

34
00:01:25,550 --> 00:01:29,450
Then we'll see how to actually implement
it in something like Amazon Web Services.

35
00:01:29,450 --> 00:01:31,700
So, in a normal data farm.

36
00:01:31,700 --> 00:01:33,950
Let's say you're building up a web farm,
right?

37
00:01:33,950 --> 00:01:36,140
You've got to have a website up for
your customers.

38
00:01:36,140 --> 00:01:39,780
And most people don't have
a standard linear usage number.

39
00:01:39,780 --> 00:01:43,870
Like, your servers don't run at 80%
percent CPU utilization all day long.

40
00:01:43,870 --> 00:01:45,478
Instead, they have peaks and valleys.

41
00:01:45,478 --> 00:01:48,723
So let me show you a diagram that I
made here that kind of represents

42
00:01:48,723 --> 00:01:51,090
what a website might normally experience.

43
00:01:51,090 --> 00:01:55,060
So here's midnight and
we go to 6 A.M. and noon and

44
00:01:55,060 --> 00:01:59,200
6 P.M., and apparently we have
multiple 0600 hours here.

45
00:01:59,200 --> 00:02:00,730
So that would be midnight again.

46
00:02:00,730 --> 00:02:04,040
So anyhow, we have a time
scale kind of laid out here.

47
00:02:04,040 --> 00:02:07,460
And traffic on our website
might peak at certain times,

48
00:02:07,460 --> 00:02:08,570
like right here around 5 AM.

49
00:02:08,570 --> 00:02:11,880
And that might plummet to
a really low utilization and

50
00:02:11,880 --> 00:02:13,840
then in the afternoon it peaks again.

51
00:02:13,840 --> 00:02:16,250
Your website may have
widely different numbers.

52
00:02:16,250 --> 00:02:18,240
But the odds are it looks
something like this,

53
00:02:18,240 --> 00:02:21,400
not just a straight line where you
have steady usage all day long.

54
00:02:21,400 --> 00:02:25,240
On a public Internet facing site,
you have people coming from all sorts

55
00:02:25,240 --> 00:02:27,960
of time zones, and
you'll have different usage levels.

56
00:02:27,960 --> 00:02:31,910
Well, if I knew that at peak times,

57
00:02:31,910 --> 00:02:36,149
I needed ten servers to be able to
support the load of my peak utilization.

58
00:02:37,390 --> 00:02:39,490
But when it's down here in a valley,

59
00:02:39,490 --> 00:02:43,630
I knew that I only needed two
servers to carry that load.

60
00:02:43,630 --> 00:02:48,050
If I'm going to build out my own web farm
with my own servers in my own building,

61
00:02:48,050 --> 00:02:50,070
how many servers do I have to buy?

62
00:02:50,070 --> 00:02:50,600
Gotta buy 10.

63
00:02:50,600 --> 00:02:53,590
You have to have 10 servers
to support your peak load.

64
00:02:53,590 --> 00:02:57,480
And that way when the site is busy
you can handle that throughput.

65
00:02:57,480 --> 00:02:59,080
But when the site gets slow,

66
00:02:59,080 --> 00:03:03,350
and you're down here where you only
really need two servers, what do you do?

67
00:03:03,350 --> 00:03:05,960
Well, you bought those ten servers.

68
00:03:05,960 --> 00:03:07,850
You've got the ten servers all the time.

69
00:03:07,850 --> 00:03:10,030
And so here in the valley,

70
00:03:10,030 --> 00:03:13,680
you got eight servers that are sitting
there doing nothing, they're just waiting.

71
00:03:13,680 --> 00:03:16,360
But you have to have them because
when you own your own equipment,

72
00:03:16,360 --> 00:03:18,420
when you buy your servers and
you and own them.

73
00:03:18,420 --> 00:03:22,340
You've gotta plan to support your peak
time, your highest load of traffic.

74
00:03:23,410 --> 00:03:26,840
With the cloud, we don't have to do that.

75
00:03:26,840 --> 00:03:29,190
With the cloud, we pay for what we use.

76
00:03:29,190 --> 00:03:32,480
We can say I need this
amount of servers at 6 AM,

77
00:03:32,480 --> 00:03:34,910
I need this other amount of servers or
2 AM.

78
00:03:34,910 --> 00:03:38,840
Well, can we predict when
our peak load is gonna be?

79
00:03:38,840 --> 00:03:41,150
A great example is would be like
if your website goes viral.

80
00:03:41,150 --> 00:03:46,845
So, so maybe Daniel creates a video of
him washing a car with an elephant.

81
00:03:46,845 --> 00:03:47,550
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, as you know,

82
00:03:47,550 --> 00:03:50,220
you got the elephant trunks spraying
the car down, it was really hilarious.

83
00:03:50,220 --> 00:03:51,210
Website goes viral, right?

84
00:03:51,210 --> 00:03:53,150
So, I'm getting tons of
hits on the website.

85
00:03:53,150 --> 00:03:55,850
Well, yesterday I might have
only need the three servers.

86
00:03:55,850 --> 00:03:56,610
And now today,

87
00:03:56,610 --> 00:04:01,210
I need 300 servers to be able to handle
all the people that are hitting that site.

88
00:04:01,210 --> 00:04:04,570
And if it were physical servers,
I'd go and buy them.

89
00:04:04,570 --> 00:04:06,020
And you wait for them to ship over and

90
00:04:06,020 --> 00:04:08,820
be delivered, and
get the OSs installed and set up.

91
00:04:08,820 --> 00:04:13,470
It's a huge delay in our ability
to respond to growing capacity

92
00:04:13,470 --> 00:04:14,450
in physical servers.

93
00:04:14,450 --> 00:04:15,610
>> Yeah.

94
00:04:15,610 --> 00:04:18,280
But with the cloud, I just dial it up.

95
00:04:18,280 --> 00:04:20,390
With the cloud we can do auto scaling.

96
00:04:20,390 --> 00:04:24,820
And we can say, when I'm at my peak time,
I only need 10 servers.

97
00:04:24,820 --> 00:04:27,110
And when I'm in a valley, go ahead and
delete eight of those servers.

98
00:04:27,110 --> 00:04:28,040
Just delete them outright.

99
00:04:28,040 --> 00:04:29,570
Throw them in the trash, right?

100
00:04:29,570 --> 00:04:31,900
I don't need those, I only need two.

101
00:04:31,900 --> 00:04:34,630
And now, I'm only paying for two.

102
00:04:34,630 --> 00:04:36,810
And then, as my site starts to get busy,
we can ramp up.

103
00:04:36,810 --> 00:04:41,170
Maybe I go to 7 servers and then we ramp
up to 10 servers to support the load.

104
00:04:41,170 --> 00:04:43,860
And we keep climbing just like that.

105
00:04:43,860 --> 00:04:47,970
So that's one of the big advantages
of doing something like auto scaling.

106
00:04:47,970 --> 00:04:51,680
You only have the amount of servers you
need at the time that you need them,

107
00:04:51,680 --> 00:04:53,510
and if your site goes viral, right?

108
00:04:53,510 --> 00:04:57,770
Let's say that, boy, that Daniel washing
the elephant commercial or whatever.

109
00:04:57,770 --> 00:05:03,530
Just really does become this
huge internet sensation and

110
00:05:03,530 --> 00:05:06,910
so our traffic,
my little lines gonna go crazy here.

111
00:05:06,910 --> 00:05:10,380
That internet traffic takes one
of these huge arc curves and

112
00:05:10,380 --> 00:05:13,450
just starts going straight
up through the roof.

113
00:05:13,450 --> 00:05:15,360
Well, we don't have to
worry about that either.

114
00:05:15,360 --> 00:05:18,116
So maybe normally my peak
time would be 10 servers, but

115
00:05:18,116 --> 00:05:20,290
with auto scaling I can set
it to say you know what?

116
00:05:20,290 --> 00:05:23,980
Go ahead and scale to 20 servers,
30 servers 300 servers.

117
00:05:23,980 --> 00:05:28,005
How ever many it is I need to be able to
support that load, you can set it up.

118
00:05:28,005 --> 00:05:29,775
>> Right.
>> Now, you can do this manually.

119
00:05:29,775 --> 00:05:32,175
You can go and manually tell
it how many servers you want.

120
00:05:32,175 --> 00:05:34,885
But what if it happens in the middle
of the night while you're asleep?

121
00:05:34,885 --> 00:05:36,295
We want this to be automatic.

122
00:05:36,295 --> 00:05:38,025
And that's what auto scaling is all about.

123
00:05:38,025 --> 00:05:41,105
Having the system automatically
monitor and grow and

124
00:05:41,105 --> 00:05:43,645
shrink your data farm based on your needs.

125
00:05:43,645 --> 00:05:45,725
>> Now, when they do the auto scaling,
you say,

126
00:05:45,725 --> 00:05:48,700
I want 30 servers, or I want 300 servers,
whatever the case may be.

127
00:05:48,700 --> 00:05:50,670
They also do that with
the pay rate as well.

128
00:05:50,670 --> 00:05:54,450
So you don't have to try to say, oh,
how much am I going to be paying for this?

129
00:05:54,450 --> 00:05:55,790
Or how much am I gonna be paying for that?

130
00:05:55,790 --> 00:05:58,990
Everything's auto setup, so
just adjust your bill as it's necessary.

131
00:05:58,990 --> 00:05:59,740
>> That's exactly right.

132
00:05:59,740 --> 00:06:03,170
Yeah, with physical servers, you gotta buy
them and have been there all the time.

133
00:06:03,170 --> 00:06:05,760
So that's a huge upfront cost and
then your run cost,

134
00:06:05,760 --> 00:06:07,200
of electricity and all that.

135
00:06:07,200 --> 00:06:10,190
With auto scaling you just set
your parameters, set your limits.

136
00:06:10,190 --> 00:06:12,530
And yeah, when you spit up the ten
servers, you gotta pay for it.

00:27:03,215 --> 00:27:07,255
So if I take a look at my auto
scaling group, here it is.

598
00:27:07,255 --> 00:27:12,130
Instance is zero, desired one,
minimum one, maximum ten.

599
00:27:12,130 --> 00:27:15,350
Okay so right now it knows
that it's got a problem.

600
00:27:15,350 --> 00:27:17,890
It's not that it has zero instances though
it's just that it takes a moment for

601
00:27:17,890 --> 00:27:18,900
it to spin those up.

602
00:27:18,900 --> 00:27:22,150
So it's spinning them up in the background
it won't show up here as healthy

603
00:27:22,150 --> 00:27:24,340
until it actually gets to that point.

604
00:27:24,340 --> 00:27:27,220
You can sit there and
hit refresh and there it goes.

605
00:27:27,220 --> 00:27:29,700
So now it's showing that one instance.

606
00:27:29,700 --> 00:27:32,620
If I jump up to my instances screen

607
00:27:32,620 --> 00:27:37,050
I can see up in here where I've got
a running instance right there.

608
00:27:37,050 --> 00:27:39,910
My other instance down here,
it's still there and

609
00:27:39,910 --> 00:27:42,450
stop right,
that's when I made the image from earlier.

610
00:27:42,450 --> 00:27:45,180
And I could delete that if I wanted to.

611
00:27:45,180 --> 00:27:48,450
I don't need it anymore but
I kind of want to keep it around.

612
00:27:48,450 --> 00:27:51,870
Going back to what Daniel said ,what
if I want to update the system,

613
00:27:51,870 --> 00:27:56,660
then I'm going to update this guy and
build a new AMI out of it and then attach

614
00:27:56,660 --> 00:27:59,880
that to my launch configurations so
that my new systems re- updated.

615
00:27:59,880 --> 00:28:04,010
So I'll probably keep that one around if
for no other reason than to have something

616
00:28:04,010 --> 00:28:07,880
I can update with but this is the guy
that in the load balancing cluster.

617
00:28:07,880 --> 00:28:11,790
This is the guy that is a part of the auto
scaling group, and as it gets busier,

618
00:28:11,790 --> 00:28:15,420
I'll start to see more of these instances
start to appear as it goes in and

619
00:28:15,420 --> 00:28:18,660
fills that need.

620
00:28:18,660 --> 00:28:20,380
Now what do my end user see?

621
00:28:20,380 --> 00:28:21,090
Nothing.

622
00:28:21,090 --> 00:28:23,120
My end users are being
directed to the load balancer.

623
00:28:23,120 --> 00:28:26,560
When they wanna browse through that
website, they go to load balancer address,

624
00:28:26,560 --> 00:28:28,870
which I never did pay attention
to when I recreate it.

625
00:28:28,870 --> 00:28:31,890
So if I pull it up here, here's the DNS
name for the load balancer that I made.

626
00:28:33,250 --> 00:28:35,990
So when they browse the web site,
they go to this load balancer.

627
00:28:35,990 --> 00:28:38,290
The load balancer, we set it so

628
00:28:38,290 --> 00:28:41,900
that all of our auto scaling notes
get put into it, and they hit that.

629
00:28:41,900 --> 00:28:44,740
And then the busier that gets,
the more nodes get built up behind it,

630
00:28:44,740 --> 00:28:46,610
but the end users just
see the load balancer.

631
00:28:46,610 --> 00:28:50,520
They don't know if you have one server or
a hundred servers or a thousand servers.

632
00:28:50,520 --> 00:28:51,370
It's invisible to them.

633
00:28:51,370 --> 00:28:52,950
They just see the low downs.

634
00:28:52,950 --> 00:28:54,060
>> And that's good for them.

635
00:28:54,060 --> 00:28:54,650
[LAUGH]
>> It is,

636
00:28:54,650 --> 00:28:55,590
it's good for us,
>> Yeah.

637
00:28:55,590 --> 00:28:56,620
>> It's really good for everybody.

638
00:28:56,620 --> 00:28:57,590
It's a win-win
>> Yeah.

639
00:28:57,590 --> 00:28:58,870
>> all across the board.

640
00:28:58,870 --> 00:29:00,450
And it's even a win-win for Amazon.

641
00:29:00,450 --> 00:29:02,550
I know you might be thinking
well that means I pay them less.

642
00:29:02,550 --> 00:29:06,320
Well when you're not using the servers
they become spot instances for

643
00:29:06,320 --> 00:29:09,150
other people or
they over-subscribe a piece of hardware.

644
00:29:09,150 --> 00:29:10,130
They can do that too.

645
00:29:10,130 --> 00:29:12,780
And so Amazon actually gets better
utilization out of their hardware because

646
00:29:12,780 --> 00:29:15,470
of this and it's all done on the backend.

647
00:29:15,470 --> 00:29:17,030
So that's auto scaling,

648
00:29:17,030 --> 00:29:21,480
now be aware that not everything can
auto scale, it's up to your application.

649
00:29:21,480 --> 00:29:25,340
Like writeable databases are really
hard to auto scale because

650
00:29:25,340 --> 00:29:27,970
how many writeable copies
that database can you have?

651
00:29:27,970 --> 00:29:29,630
And yeah, you gotta synchronize
between them and stuff.

652
00:29:29,630 --> 00:29:33,190
So there's some things that
don't auto scale well, but

653
00:29:33,190 --> 00:29:36,080
things like web servers,file
servers those guys,

654
00:29:36,080 --> 00:29:40,300
they all scale great, chuck them in there
really easy to get those up and running.

655
00:29:40,300 --> 00:29:43,490
>> Very cool this is definitely,
I'm seeing the light Don,

656
00:29:43,490 --> 00:29:47,110
a true believer that this auto
scaling is the way to go.

657
00:29:47,110 --> 00:29:48,940
You should be doing this.

658
00:29:48,940 --> 00:29:53,190
>> Yeah, especially if you're an internet
startup, if you're looking for

659
00:29:53,190 --> 00:29:56,410
that jump to fame, if you're doing
a viral marketing campaign and

660
00:29:56,410 --> 00:29:59,780
you know that you might be blasting
the amount of users overnight.

661
00:29:59,780 --> 00:30:01,763
Auto scaling will save your butt.

662
00:30:01,763 --> 00:30:03,080
[LAUGH] There's no way around that.

663
00:30:03,080 --> 00:30:05,530
>> Yeah, let's go viral.

664
00:30:05,530 --> 00:30:07,420
Have we covered the bases on this guy?

665
00:30:07,420 --> 00:30:08,410
>> Yeah.
>> Awesome.

666
00:30:08,410 --> 00:30:11,640
Well with that being said, I guess that's
all we have for our auto scaling show.

667
00:30:11,640 --> 00:30:13,560
I hope you guys learned a lot from it.

668
00:30:13,560 --> 00:30:14,780
Signing off for ITProTV.

669
00:30:14,780 --> 00:30:16,690
I've been your host Daniel Larry.

670
00:30:16,690 --> 00:30:17,290
>> And I'm Don Bizet.

671
00:30:17,290 --> 00:30:19,091
>> And we'll see you next time.

672
00:30:19,091 --> 00:30:24,790
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Using the AWS CLI
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,461
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,461 --> 00:00:11,682
All right everyone, greetings.

3
00:00:11,682 --> 00:00:14,251
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,251 --> 00:00:16,090
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:16,090 --> 00:00:18,570
Here with me today is my good friend and
colleague, Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18,570 --> 00:00:19,740
How are you doing today, Don?

7
00:00:19,740 --> 00:00:20,780
>> I am doing great, Daniel.

8
00:00:20,780 --> 00:00:22,550
We've got a great episode lined up for
us today.

9
00:00:22,550 --> 00:00:26,980
We're gonna be taking a look at the Amazon
Web Services Command Line Interface.

10
00:00:26,980 --> 00:00:27,580
The CLI.

11
00:00:27,580 --> 00:00:31,700
>> Yeah, the CLI is the mystical little
thing where you actually have to type and

12
00:00:31,700 --> 00:00:32,560
use the keyboard.

13
00:00:32,560 --> 00:00:33,580
That's always a good time.

14
00:00:33,580 --> 00:00:35,451
I know I enjoy using Linux and Cisco.

15
00:00:35,451 --> 00:00:38,631
Anytime I get a chance to work with those
types of devices, I really enjoy that.

16
00:00:38,631 --> 00:00:41,510
So, I'm interested in seeing
what Amazon has to offer.

17
00:00:41,510 --> 00:00:42,080
>> Yeah.

18
00:00:42,080 --> 00:00:46,100
Now, you might ask yourself,
we've seen the web interface for

19
00:00:46,100 --> 00:00:49,200
AWS and all the different features and
tools in there, why would I

20
00:00:49,200 --> 00:00:53,150
possibly want to use a command line
interface when we've got this nice web UI?

21
00:00:53,150 --> 00:00:55,840
And the answer is, well,
most of the time you will use the web UI.

22
00:00:55,840 --> 00:00:58,230
It's easy, it's simple,
you jump in there and you do it.

23
00:00:58,230 --> 00:01:02,200
But there's two main cases where
we're going to find we need that CLI.

24
00:01:02,200 --> 00:01:05,360
The first case is when we
want to configure something

25
00:01:05,360 --> 00:01:09,030
that isn't configurable in the web UI.

26
00:01:09,030 --> 00:01:12,890
When Amazon develops a new feature,
they typically develop the command line

27
00:01:12,890 --> 00:01:17,770
interface commands for it first and
then make the web UI for it second.

28
00:01:17,770 --> 00:01:20,930
So, when features like
auto-scaling originally launched.

29
00:01:20,930 --> 00:01:24,660
If you wanted to set up an auto-scaling
group, you had to do that through the CLI.

30
00:01:24,660 --> 00:01:28,600
And then it wasn't until a few months
later that they rolled out the web UI.

31
00:01:28,600 --> 00:01:30,560
So that you have that
access via the web page.

32
00:01:30,560 --> 00:01:32,860
So, if you watched our
auto-scaling episode,

33
00:01:32,860 --> 00:01:36,460
we configured that pretty much all through
the web UI, cuz you can do that now.

34
00:01:36,460 --> 00:01:37,750
But in the beginning you couldn't.

35
00:01:37,750 --> 00:01:40,530
So if you're trying to take advantage of
the latest and greatest features in AWS,

36
00:01:40,530 --> 00:01:44,780
oftentimes you'll find yourself
using that command line interface.

37
00:01:44,780 --> 00:01:46,472
The other reason is automation.

38
00:01:46,472 --> 00:01:49,898
Automation, it's something we all have
to tackle at some point or another,

39
00:01:49,898 --> 00:01:52,479
when we want to activities to
happen at a certain time, but

40
00:01:52,479 --> 00:01:53,970
we don't want to be there for it.

41
00:01:53,970 --> 00:01:56,020
Now a great example would be,

42
00:01:56,020 --> 00:02:00,350
maybe I wanna take a snapshot of a service
hard drive every night at 1:00 AM.

43
00:02:00,350 --> 00:02:01,673
Well, I don't want to wake up or

44
00:02:01,673 --> 00:02:05,012
stay up until 1:00 AM every night just
to take this snapshot and do it by hand.

45
00:02:05,012 --> 00:02:09,232
It'd be nice if I could automate that
to happen and just run at 1:00 AM.

46
00:02:09,232 --> 00:02:10,453
I don't even have to think about it.

47
00:02:10,453 --> 00:02:14,470
Well, you can't automate
clicking on a web page.

48
00:02:14,470 --> 00:02:16,500
I guess you can, it's not very easy to do.

49
00:02:16,500 --> 00:02:20,060
But what you can automate,
is running a command line script.

50
00:02:20,060 --> 00:02:23,930
So, you could write a script that
call the various AWS command line

51
00:02:23,930 --> 00:02:27,360
utilities to reach out and
take a snapshot of that drive.

52
00:02:27,360 --> 00:02:30,310
Now, 1:00 AM, your snapshot is made,
you don't have to worry about it.

53
00:02:30,310 --> 00:02:32,640
So those are the two big scenarios
where we see the command line

54
00:02:32,640 --> 00:02:34,120
user interface getting used.

55
00:02:34,120 --> 00:02:34,698
>> Yeah.

56
00:02:34,698 --> 00:02:38,225
Don, well, are you gonna show us
some AWS command line interface so

57
00:02:38,225 --> 00:02:42,038
that I can at least come off a little more
pretentious than I normally would be.

58
00:02:42,038 --> 00:02:45,073
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, suspender wearing Linux snob.

59
00:02:45,073 --> 00:02:46,035
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

60
00:02:46,035 --> 00:02:48,355
actually I mentioned Linux snob, right?

61
00:02:48,355 --> 00:02:50,800
It doesn't matter which
operating system you run.

62
00:02:50,800 --> 00:02:54,373
Amazon created the command line interface
to support all the operating systems.

63
00:02:54,373 --> 00:02:57,253
They wrote the CLI completely in Python.

64
00:02:57,253 --> 00:03:00,843
And that means that it can run on Windows,
Mac OS, Linux, doesn't matter.

65
00:03:00,843 --> 00:03:03,923
As long as you have the Python libraries
installed, you're in business.

66
00:03:03,923 --> 00:03:06,764
Well, if you're a Windows user,
it's really easy.

67
00:03:06,764 --> 00:03:10,385
You can go to the AWS webpage and
right there in the documentation,

68
00:03:10,385 --> 00:03:13,630
they have a nice little download link for
an MSI installer.

69
00:03:13,630 --> 00:03:15,130
They make it really easy for
the Windows users.

70
00:03:15,130 --> 00:03:16,680
Let me show you guys that page.

71
00:03:16,680 --> 00:03:19,950
This is the Installing AWS
Command Line Interface page.

72
00:03:19,950 --> 00:03:22,400
It's part of the AWS documentation.

73
00:03:22,400 --> 00:03:27,300
And for Windows, they actually
have CLI downloaders right here.

74
00:03:27,300 --> 00:03:30,850
Now, I usually use the 32-bit version for
Windows regardless of the OS.

75
00:03:30,850 --> 00:03:32,840
And that's because,
notice this little note here?

76
00:03:32,840 --> 00:03:36,430
How the 64-bit version doesn't work
with Windows Server 2008 bla, bla, bla?

77
00:03:36,430 --> 00:03:40,360
Every now and then there's issues
with the 64-bit CLI on Windows.

78
00:03:40,360 --> 00:03:42,980
And you don't really benefit
from it that much anyway.

79
00:03:42,980 --> 00:03:46,020
So, the 32-bit CLI is
what I normally do there.

80
00:03:46,020 --> 00:03:49,780
If you're running Linux or
if you're running Mac OS though,

81
00:03:49,780 --> 00:03:52,680
we don't have a nice little installer,
but we don't really need one.

82
00:03:52,680 --> 00:03:55,090
We can use Python to install it for us.

83
00:03:55,090 --> 00:03:58,490
So, for example, on Mac OS you
already have Python installed.

84
00:03:58,490 --> 00:04:00,940
And if you're on Linux, you more than
likely already have it installed.

85
00:04:00,940 --> 00:04:02,480
But if you don't,

86
00:04:02,480 --> 00:04:05,240
it's usually just a quick package
command away to get it installed.

87
00:04:05,240 --> 00:04:11,400
Like you might do a, sudo yum install
Python, on a CentOS Red Hat system.

88
00:04:11,400 --> 00:04:13,680
Usually, you'll find that it's already
installed, so you don't sweat it.

89
00:04:14,680 --> 00:04:17,240
Now, once we have Python installed.

90
00:04:17,240 --> 00:04:21,030
Then we can install the AWSCLI,
and it's super easy.

91
00:04:21,030 --> 00:04:25,126
Because Python has a package
manager built into it called Pip.

92
00:04:25,126 --> 00:04:28,410
And we can use Pip to install AWS.

93
00:04:28,410 --> 00:04:31,880
It's super simple, and you just run,
it's on here somewhere.

94
00:04:31,880 --> 00:04:36,177
We'll find the Pip command,
which is, there it is, right there.

95
00:04:36,177 --> 00:04:38,280
Pip install awscli.

96
00:04:39,400 --> 00:04:41,230
And as simple as that, it'll install.

97
00:04:41,230 --> 00:04:42,770
And if you're on a Linux or

98
00:04:42,770 --> 00:04:46,030
a Mac OS machine,
odds are that's all you have to install.

99
00:04:46,030 --> 00:04:46,690
You can check.

100
00:04:46,690 --> 00:04:51,484
I'm on a Mac and so I might start
by typing in Python --version.

101
00:04:52,490 --> 00:04:55,660
And that's just gonna let me know
if Python is installed or not.

102
00:04:55,660 --> 00:04:57,690
Your Mac will likely have
Python already on it.

103
00:04:57,690 --> 00:04:58,530
It should.

104
00:04:58,530 --> 00:05:03,080
If it doesn't, then it may have been
removed, or it might be an older version.

105
00:05:03,080 --> 00:05:05,920
Apple isn't the greatest at
offering the latest version of

106
00:05:05,920 --> 00:05:06,770
Python with their system.

107
00:05:06,770 --> 00:05:09,680
So, you might have to use
software like Homebrew or

108
00:05:09,680 --> 00:05:12,540
something to install
the updated Python libraries.

109
00:05:12,540 --> 00:05:14,737
But as long as you've got Python,
you'll have the pip command.

110
00:05:14,737 --> 00:05:18,929
And you can run Pip install awscli.

111
00:05:18,929 --> 00:05:22,200
And it'll reach out,

112
00:05:22,200 --> 00:05:24,990
it'll find that package information,
and there it goes installing.

113
00:05:26,460 --> 00:05:27,270
Simple as that.

114
00:05:27,270 --> 00:05:31,315
Once it's installed, you can run aws help,

115
00:05:31,315 --> 00:05:36,480
and you should get the help
documentation for that.

116
00:05:36,480 --> 00:05:37,860
I now have the AWS CLI right here.

117
00:05:40,040 --> 00:05:42,370
And it's just listing out
the various commands for me.

118
00:05:42,370 --> 00:05:46,180
So now I can run AWS,
followed by assorted commands, and

119
00:05:46,180 --> 00:05:48,250
I can start to work on my system.

120
00:05:48,250 --> 00:05:50,550
On a Windows machine,
I would've run that MSI installer.

121
00:05:50,550 --> 00:05:54,270
When it was done, just open up
a command prompt and run aws help.

122
00:05:54,270 --> 00:05:55,070
Same thing.

123
00:05:55,070 --> 00:05:59,385
On a Linux machine, pip install awscli,
and then the aws help command, and

124
00:05:59,385 --> 00:06:00,470
you're in there.

125
00:06:02,230 --> 00:06:06,900
Now, if you already have some
instances spun up in the Amazon cloud,

126
00:06:07,990 --> 00:06:09,640
any of the Amazon built images.

127
00:06:09,640 --> 00:06:13,138
So, if you use like the Amazon Linux AMI
or the Amazon Windows AMIs.

128
00:06:13,138 --> 00:06:18,210
When you deploy those instances, they
include the CLI on that machine for you.

129
00:06:18,210 --> 00:06:20,348
So, you don't have to install it,
it's already there.

130
00:06:20,348 --> 00:06:25,640
For example,
if I connect to an instance that I have.

131
00:06:25,640 --> 00:06:31,019
Oh shoot, here, let me find it,
instance to use.

132
00:06:31,019 --> 00:06:33,079
So, if I take a look at my EC2 instances.

133
00:06:33,079 --> 00:06:37,160
I've got one that I spun
up from a Linux AMI.

134
00:06:37,160 --> 00:06:40,840
This is just a regular Amazon Linux AMI,
nothing special about it.

135
00:06:40,840 --> 00:06:47,360
And if I connect to this host and
I connect this EC2 user.

136
00:06:47,360 --> 00:06:49,182
When I connect up to it,

137
00:06:49,182 --> 00:06:53,840
I'll see that it's already got
the AWS CLI installed on it.

138
00:06:53,840 --> 00:06:56,400
So, here I am, I'm remoted into that,
and you'll see it right there.

139
00:06:56,400 --> 00:06:58,590
Amazon Linux AMI.

140
00:06:58,590 --> 00:07:02,370
And if I run aws help.

141
00:07:02,370 --> 00:07:04,120
Sure enough, there's that command?

142
00:07:04,120 --> 00:07:05,170
So, if you've got a Windows or

143
00:07:05,170 --> 00:07:08,340
Linux box up there in the cloud,
it's already got the CLI ready for you.

144
00:07:08,340 --> 00:07:10,350
But if you wanna install
it on your own machine, or

145
00:07:10,350 --> 00:07:12,640
a server in your office,
easy enough to get it installed.

146
00:07:14,575 --> 00:07:16,797
>> I guess all that's left now is
doing a little configuration for

147
00:07:16,797 --> 00:07:17,535
it though, huh Don?

148
00:07:17,535 --> 00:07:20,355
>> Yeah, it does need to know
how to connect to your account.

149
00:07:21,385 --> 00:07:24,785
And the way we connect it to an account
is to provide it credentials.

150
00:07:24,785 --> 00:07:28,230
It's got to have the user credentials
to be able to access your system.

151
00:07:28,230 --> 00:07:30,680
As it is right now,
it doesn't actually work.

152
00:07:30,680 --> 00:07:32,300
It's here, right?

153
00:07:32,300 --> 00:07:34,712
But if I run aws.
