00:19:04,320 --> 00:19:05,800
I do normally do it the other way, right?

382
00:19:05,800 --> 00:19:07,980
Where the read only account is my default.

383
00:19:07,980 --> 00:19:10,200
Or often times,
I won't even configure the default.

384
00:19:10,200 --> 00:19:13,730
Because I just get used to doing the
--profiles, so I've always got it there.

385
00:19:13,730 --> 00:19:15,420
But if you got one account
you use all the time,

386
00:19:15,420 --> 00:19:17,133
it's nice to be able to
leave that little bit off.

387
00:19:17,133 --> 00:19:19,470
You know, leave that --profile stuff off.

388
00:19:19,470 --> 00:19:24,010
Now, I set this up under my
user account on this system.

389
00:19:24,010 --> 00:19:27,740
If I were to log out, and Daniel,
you logged in on my machine.

390
00:19:27,740 --> 00:19:29,660
Well, that was all set
up under my profile.

391
00:19:29,660 --> 00:19:32,110
So you'd have to go and
set up your own stuff.

392
00:19:32,110 --> 00:19:34,440
The AWS command line would
still be installed, but

393
00:19:34,440 --> 00:19:38,410
you'd have to go and
configure that with your credentials.

394
00:19:38,410 --> 00:19:41,850
>> And that's the right way to do things
that way if I make a change you'll

395
00:19:41,850 --> 00:19:44,170
see in the logs,
especially if I mess something up.

396
00:19:44,170 --> 00:19:48,130
Well Daniel, there he is kicking his
clumsy feet around on my AWS CLI.

397
00:19:48,130 --> 00:19:50,730
I'm gonna go and knock him a good one.

398
00:19:50,730 --> 00:19:51,720
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That is exactly how

399
00:19:51,720 --> 00:19:52,420
I'd say it, too.

400
00:19:52,420 --> 00:19:53,180
I'd say, it's uncanny.

401
00:19:53,180 --> 00:19:54,990
>> That was my Don impression.

402
00:19:54,990 --> 00:19:57,418
This happens a lot behind the scenes.

403
00:19:57,418 --> 00:20:01,970
>> [LAUGH] All right, I will mention one
other thing before we wrap this one up.

404
00:20:01,970 --> 00:20:05,380
Which is,
Python was the key requirement here.

405
00:20:05,380 --> 00:20:08,190
And on a Windows system you
don't have Python, but it's not

406
00:20:08,190 --> 00:20:12,030
a big deal because when you use that MSI
installer from Amazon, it installs it.

407
00:20:12,030 --> 00:20:15,120
It adds Python and
it gets that set up, really,

408
00:20:15,120 --> 00:20:17,070
that's the easiest to
install of all of them.

409
00:20:17,070 --> 00:20:19,540
On a Linux box,
it's simply a matter of adding it.

410
00:20:19,540 --> 00:20:23,760
And back here under the help document,
let me bring this back up,

411
00:20:23,760 --> 00:20:26,840
one of the things they
go into Is right here.

412
00:20:26,840 --> 00:20:30,770
So if you need Python,
here's the commands for installing it for

413
00:20:30,770 --> 00:20:34,905
Debian based systems, for Red Hat or
CentOS, and for SUSE Linux.

414
00:20:34,905 --> 00:20:38,660
There's the three different ways that
you can do that on a Linux system.

415
00:20:38,660 --> 00:20:42,740
On a Mac,
you've got Apple's Python they install.

416
00:20:42,740 --> 00:20:45,020
And if that's not good enough,

417
00:20:45,020 --> 00:20:47,890
then you really need to install
an updated Python library.

418
00:20:47,890 --> 00:20:51,730
And for that, I recommend
a little program called Homebrew.

419
00:20:51,730 --> 00:20:55,190
And let me just pull up
their page real quick.

420
00:20:55,190 --> 00:20:58,810
Homebrew is just a package manager
that you can install on top of OSX.

421
00:20:58,810 --> 00:21:01,080
I've used it for for a long time.

422
00:21:01,080 --> 00:21:02,210
It's really great.

423
00:21:02,210 --> 00:21:04,890
You just copy this one
little ruby command,

424
00:21:04,890 --> 00:21:09,050
because every mac as Ruby installed,
and you run that and it installs Brew.

425
00:21:09,050 --> 00:21:15,470
And once that's on there, all you have to
do is from your CLI, on your your Mac,

426
00:21:15,470 --> 00:21:21,400
you can to say, brew install python,
and that'll install it on the system.

427
00:21:21,400 --> 00:21:23,200
I've already got it installed,
so it'll tell me that.

428
00:21:23,200 --> 00:21:25,630
But it'll install on the system and
now you've got it.

429
00:21:25,630 --> 00:21:28,600
And you just follow that
up with pip install awscli,

430
00:21:28,600 --> 00:21:30,640
and you're in business, right.

431
00:21:30,640 --> 00:21:31,980
That'll get you there and
get you knocked out.

432
00:21:31,980 --> 00:21:34,670
So Mac, Linux, Windows,
you're covered, right.

433
00:21:34,670 --> 00:21:36,580
All the Python based systems.

434
00:21:36,580 --> 00:21:38,370
>> Very cool.
>> All right, well Daniel,

435
00:21:38,370 --> 00:21:40,600
I think that is all I've got
on the command line interface.

436
00:21:40,600 --> 00:21:44,630
I can't think of anything else to
mention offhand except there are a ton

437
00:21:44,630 --> 00:21:45,700
of AWS commands out there.

438
00:21:45,700 --> 00:21:48,070
We certainly don't have time
to go through all those, but

439
00:21:48,070 --> 00:21:51,160
check out that help documentation for
the service that you're working with.

440
00:21:51,160 --> 00:21:54,620
So, EC2 has its documentation,
Route53 has its, and so on.

441
00:21:54,620 --> 00:21:57,360
They've all got a different
set of command line utilities.

442
00:21:57,360 --> 00:21:59,250
>> Awesome, well, wise words from Mr.

443
00:21:59,250 --> 00:22:02,270
Don Pezet, so listen to what he's
telling you and take it to heart.

444
00:22:02,270 --> 00:22:07,440
That being said, I guess we've come to the
conclusion of another episode by ITProTV.

445
00:22:07,440 --> 00:22:09,150
I hope you guys have enjoyed it.

446
00:22:09,150 --> 00:22:12,460
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

447
00:22:12,460 --> 00:22:13,070
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

448
00:22:13,070 --> 00:22:14,215
>> And we'll see you next time.

449
00:22:14,215 --> 00:22:20,310
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Azure Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,571
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,571 --> 00:00:11,373
All right everyone.

3
00:00:11,373 --> 00:00:14,482
Greetings and welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,482 --> 00:00:18,172
I'll be your host Daniel Lowery here with
me today is my good friend Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18,172 --> 00:00:19,113
How you doing today, Don?

6
00:00:19,113 --> 00:00:22,762
>> I'm doing well, I'm excited because
today we're gonna be switching gears,

7
00:00:22,762 --> 00:00:25,551
we've been focusing on Amazon's
web servers up until now.

8
00:00:25,551 --> 00:00:29,640
But in this episode, we're gonna
start talking about Microsoft Azure.

9
00:00:29,640 --> 00:00:33,280
And Microsoft Azure, it's newer to the
market than Amazon Web Services has been.

10
00:00:33,280 --> 00:00:35,670
AWS has been out for a long time.

11
00:00:35,670 --> 00:00:41,120
Azure is Microsoft's foray into the hosted
data center solutions and boy, they

12
00:00:41,120 --> 00:00:44,500
have set out to make a top notch product
and they've done really well with that.

13
00:00:44,500 --> 00:00:46,800
So it's a robust design they've got.

14
00:00:46,800 --> 00:00:49,630
They've got numerous data centers around
the world a lot of the same stuff that we

15
00:00:49,630 --> 00:00:52,330
saw Amazon but
done in the Microsoft manner.

16
00:00:52,330 --> 00:00:55,540
It is still an evolving technology
they're adding more to it and

17
00:00:55,540 --> 00:00:59,940
what you'll find is that things, things
like the web interface might not be as

18
00:00:59,940 --> 00:01:02,350
full features what you have
with Amazon Web Services.

19
00:01:02,350 --> 00:01:03,560
But they're continuing to add to it.

20
00:01:03,560 --> 00:01:07,350
Lot of new features coming in there and
very price competitive with Amazon.

21
00:01:07,350 --> 00:01:10,850
So definitely one of the Cloud service
providers you want to look into.

22
00:01:10,850 --> 00:01:13,233
>> Yeah, if anything about
a Microsoft you'll know is that,

23
00:01:13,233 --> 00:01:16,344
if something is making money, they're
gonna put their fingers in that pot.

24
00:01:16,344 --> 00:01:16,911
>> [LAUGH]
>> So and

25
00:01:16,911 --> 00:01:19,490
actually I think they've done
a really good job with Azure.

26
00:01:19,490 --> 00:01:20,630
I really like the interface.

27
00:01:20,630 --> 00:01:21,840
I like the way it works.

28
00:01:21,840 --> 00:01:23,090
It's very user friendly.

29
00:01:23,090 --> 00:01:24,140
>> Yeah, absolutely.

30
00:01:24,140 --> 00:01:26,060
So let's talk a little bit
about their infrastructure and

31
00:01:26,060 --> 00:01:28,080
kind of what Microsoft
brings to the table.

32
00:01:28,080 --> 00:01:30,620
Well the main thing Microsoft
brings to the table is that they

33
00:01:30,620 --> 00:01:33,630
are one of the main operating
system benders in the world.

34
00:01:33,630 --> 00:01:37,560
Microsoft Windows is the most common
operating system in the world.

35
00:01:37,560 --> 00:01:41,010
So for them to virtualize it, they're
not virtualizing other people's stuff,

36
00:01:41,010 --> 00:01:43,810
they're virtualizing their own and
they can do a great job with that.

37
00:01:43,810 --> 00:01:48,731
Now, they do provide Linux of the arms
also so they're not just Windows.

38
00:01:48,731 --> 00:01:50,094
A lot of people pigeonhole that like,

39
00:01:50,094 --> 00:01:52,550
well I don't use Azure cuz I
don't use Windows servers.

40
00:01:52,550 --> 00:01:53,210
You don't have to.

41
00:01:53,210 --> 00:01:55,430
You can bring your Linux servers,
you can do all of that.

42
00:01:55,430 --> 00:01:58,061
It runs just fine,
just like on EC2 and Rack Space and

43
00:01:58,061 --> 00:02:00,052
the other providers that are out there.

44
00:02:00,052 --> 00:02:02,530
All right,
let's talk about their infrastructure.

45
00:02:02,530 --> 00:02:07,160
To provide the Azure hosted data centers,
Microsoft went ahead and

46
00:02:07,160 --> 00:02:09,110
created 17 data centers around the world.

47
00:02:09,110 --> 00:02:13,047
Now, they use their terms a little bit
different for this stuff than with Amazon

48
00:02:13,047 --> 00:02:16,012
with Amazon you have regions
which are their data centers.

49
00:02:16,012 --> 00:02:20,689
And you have zones within a region that
are basically like independent networks

50
00:02:20,689 --> 00:02:26,170
that separate things out and usually have
two, maybe three zones in each region.

51
00:02:26,170 --> 00:02:28,505
Microsoft doesn't technically have zones,

52
00:02:28,505 --> 00:02:30,650
cuz they follow a slightly
different model.

53
00:02:30,650 --> 00:02:35,610
Inside each data center, the data center
itself is compartmentalized into these,

54
00:02:35,610 --> 00:02:37,320
they call them fault domains.

55
00:02:37,320 --> 00:02:41,840
And there'll be hundreds of fault domain,
sometimes the inside of one data center.

56
00:02:41,840 --> 00:02:44,270
So they don't bother with
that zone terminology.

57
00:02:44,270 --> 00:02:46,180
And so you'll see them use
that term interchangeably.

58
00:02:46,180 --> 00:02:47,840
They'll say region, they'll say zone.

59
00:02:47,840 --> 00:02:49,243
It's basically the same thing for them.

60
00:02:49,243 --> 00:02:51,935
So they have 17 regions around the world,
and

61
00:02:51,935 --> 00:02:56,390
I've got their as your regions page
pulled up here does kind of show you.

62
00:02:56,390 --> 00:02:58,220
They give these like white circles here.

63
00:02:58,220 --> 00:03:00,720
Each one of these is one
of their regions and

64
00:03:00,720 --> 00:03:04,618
a region is a fully
autonomous data center.

65
00:03:04,618 --> 00:03:08,690
So it's gonna have servers and other
resources that are all kind of spread out.

66
00:03:08,690 --> 00:03:12,260
You'll see they have two down here in
Australia, down in Southeast Asia,

67
00:03:12,260 --> 00:03:16,260
China, Japan, over in Europe,
several here in the United States,

68
00:03:16,260 --> 00:03:18,940
as well as in Brazil and South America.

69
00:03:18,940 --> 00:03:22,740
So data centers all over to
make sure that you can get

70
00:03:22,740 --> 00:03:27,840
the maximum redundancy possible as well as
to get your data close to your customers.

71
00:03:27,840 --> 00:03:31,550
You might be in an American company but
you have a lot of customers in Australia.

72
00:03:31,550 --> 00:03:33,860
Or you might be a British company and

73
00:03:33,860 --> 00:03:35,810
you've got a lot of
customers over in China.

74
00:03:35,810 --> 00:03:38,140
So you want that data to be
close to your customers so

75
00:03:38,140 --> 00:03:40,610
that they can get reliable and
quick access to it.

76
00:03:41,630 --> 00:03:45,910
Now Microsoft, they list out a whole bunch
of stuff here, but they break down each of

77
00:03:45,910 --> 00:03:48,910
those regions because it is important
to a little bit more about some of it.

78
00:03:48,910 --> 00:03:51,090
For example their Virginia region.

79
00:03:51,090 --> 00:03:53,770
There's two regions in the same place.

80
00:03:53,770 --> 00:03:55,980
There's the East US and East US two.

81
00:03:55,980 --> 00:03:58,830
They're two completely
separate facilities,

82
00:03:58,830 --> 00:04:02,110
completely separate power, network,
staff, everything complete.

83
00:04:02,110 --> 00:04:05,930
They might as well be in two separate
cities as independent as they are and

84
00:04:05,930 --> 00:04:07,330
they do that again for redundancy.

85
00:04:07,330 --> 00:04:10,830
If one data center has an issue,
the other takes over.

86
00:04:10,830 --> 00:04:14,560
But you don't have to rely on multiple
regions in the same location like this.

87
00:04:14,560 --> 00:04:15,290
You can spread it out.

88
00:04:15,290 --> 00:04:19,640
You can have one in Iowa, Virginia,
Illinois, so there's ones all

89
00:04:19,640 --> 00:04:23,190
over the place that you can choose based
on where you want your data to reside.

90
00:04:24,240 --> 00:04:25,900
Now, they do have some
specialized regions.

91
00:04:25,900 --> 00:04:29,720
Notice there's like, U.S government Iowa,
U.S government Virginia.

92
00:04:29,720 --> 00:04:32,790
Those are ones that are reserved for
use by the United States government.

93
00:04:32,790 --> 00:04:35,710
The U.S government said hey,
if we're going to host stuff in the Cloud,

94
00:04:35,710 --> 00:04:38,630
we've got to be able to guarantee
that our servers are safe and

95
00:04:38,630 --> 00:04:40,150
isolated from your other customers.

96
00:04:40,150 --> 00:04:42,480
So they created some
dedicated data centers.

97
00:04:42,480 --> 00:04:45,310
So just because there are 17 data centers

98
00:04:45,310 --> 00:04:47,680
doesn't mean that you have
access to all of them.

99
00:04:47,680 --> 00:04:50,920
Oftentimes, you'll find you only
have access to maybe nine or

100
00:04:50,920 --> 00:04:53,880
ten and
a lot of times that's based on capacity.

101
00:04:53,880 --> 00:04:56,930
Others might be a full capacity so
you can't add new servers there.

102
00:04:56,930 --> 00:04:58,970
It might be because of
other certain policies.

103
00:04:58,970 --> 00:05:00,600
The Australian ones are like that.

104
00:05:00,600 --> 00:05:04,520
For example, if I wanted to spin up a
server right now, unless I have a billing

105
00:05:04,520 --> 00:05:08,400
address in Australia they won't let me
spin up instances down in Australia.

106
00:05:08,400 --> 00:05:11,943
And the reason is that the data is pretty
expensive for them they want to service

107
00:05:11,943 --> 00:05:15,281
the local customer first, before they
open it up to the rest of the world.

108
00:05:15,281 --> 00:05:17,558
And in time, they will open that
to the rest of the world and

109
00:05:17,558 --> 00:05:19,010
you'll see that become available.

110
00:05:20,220 --> 00:05:23,790
So lots of different data centers
that are spread out there.

111
00:05:23,790 --> 00:05:26,950
Now, when we talk about a data center.

112
00:05:26,950 --> 00:05:28,210
What are we talking about?

113
00:05:28,210 --> 00:05:30,990
Well it's the primary advantage of Cloud.

114
00:05:30,990 --> 00:05:34,710
When you go to the Cloud, you're
basically outsourcing some of your stuff.

115
00:05:34,710 --> 00:05:39,369
If you're saying, I'm tired of maintaining
my old hardware, paying the electric bill,

116
00:05:39,369 --> 00:05:42,530
trying to keep my servers up and
running, taking my backups.

117
00:05:42,530 --> 00:05:43,750
I'm tired of all that.

118
00:05:43,750 --> 00:05:45,830
I want somebody else to take it over for
me.

119
00:05:45,830 --> 00:05:47,090
And that's what Microsoft is doing.

120
00:05:47,090 --> 00:05:50,100
Microsoft, it's not a guarantee but

121
00:05:50,100 --> 00:05:52,725
they more than likely have more
money than the company you work for.

122
00:05:52,725 --> 00:05:54,677
>> [LAUGH]
>> For a company like ours,

123
00:05:54,677 --> 00:05:55,972
that's not even close.

124
00:05:55,972 --> 00:05:56,793
>> It's given.

125
00:05:56,793 --> 00:05:58,070
[LAUGH]
>> But maybe you work for

126
00:05:58,070 --> 00:06:00,590
one of the big oil manufacturers,
I don't know.

127
00:06:00,590 --> 00:06:03,490
But they've got a lot of resources
that most of us don't, and

128
00:06:03,490 --> 00:06:07,050
so when they build a data
center it's impressive.

129
00:06:07,050 --> 00:06:09,561
And a lot of people don't realize
how impressive these things are.

130
00:06:09,561 --> 00:06:13,600
So I wanna show you guys that
I've got a little slide show.

131
00:06:13,600 --> 00:06:18,575
Microsoft has a guided tour on their
data center webpage that you can go and

132
00:06:18,575 --> 00:06:19,950
view, it's a ten minute video.

133
00:06:19,950 --> 00:06:23,171
I went ahead and grabbed some screenshots
out of it just to kind of show you.

134
00:06:23,171 --> 00:06:27,500
When you host your servers in Microsoft
Azure, what those data centers are?

135
00:06:27,500 --> 00:06:29,390
Are these are these warehouses.

136
00:06:29,390 --> 00:06:31,950
And in the warehouses
they have these boxes,

137
00:06:31,950 --> 00:06:36,220
they're almost like truck trailers
that are stacked full of servers.

138
00:06:36,220 --> 00:06:38,130
And this pictures from
inside of one of those.

139
00:06:38,130 --> 00:06:41,950
And what you'll see here
are literally thousands of servers

140
00:06:41,950 --> 00:06:45,510
in one of these containers,
they can fit up to 2400 servers,

141
00:06:45,510 --> 00:06:48,640
2400 servers jammed in
one of these trailers.

142
00:06:48,640 --> 00:06:51,030
And that trailer is rigged for
air conditioning,

143
00:06:51,030 --> 00:06:55,410
water cooling, electric,
network, internet bandwidth.

144
00:06:55,410 --> 00:06:57,160
All of that is hooked up.

145
00:06:57,160 --> 00:06:58,230
I mentioned water.

146
00:06:58,230 --> 00:06:59,960
It's all water cooled.

147
00:06:59,960 --> 00:07:03,010
It's so many servers that they can't
properly condition it with normal

148
00:07:03,010 --> 00:07:03,830
air conditioning.

149
00:07:03,830 --> 00:07:06,870
So they use water cooling to get all
the heat out of that trailer and

150
00:07:06,870 --> 00:07:09,190
out into the data center itself.

151
00:07:09,190 --> 00:07:12,420
Then they have regular air conditioners
inside of the data center.

152
00:07:12,420 --> 00:07:16,750
Now, when I say regular air conditioners,
I'm talking about these.

153
00:07:16,750 --> 00:07:18,470
Now, that's not what we have in our homes.

154
00:07:18,470 --> 00:07:21,600
These are our commercial grade
chillers that are designed to

155
00:07:21,600 --> 00:07:23,190
cool large data center.

156
00:07:23,190 --> 00:07:26,640
This is not something that most of
our companies have or that we could

157
00:07:26,640 --> 00:07:30,190
afford to put in a lot of cases but
Microsoft can and they already have.

158
00:07:30,190 --> 00:07:31,890
So when you use their Cloud service,

159
00:07:31,890 --> 00:07:33,660
you're getting access to
all of this hardware.

160

00:26:15,050 --> 00:26:17,380
It has no install candidate, great.

560
00:26:17,380 --> 00:26:17,880
Well.
>> [LAUGH]

561
00:26:17,880 --> 00:26:18,946
>> [LAUGH] Oh, I see it's meshed

562
00:26:18,946 --> 00:26:20,158
all these other things.
Oh,

563
00:26:20,158 --> 00:26:22,125
they called it apache2, lame.
So

564
00:26:22,125 --> 00:26:22,683
anyhow.
[LAUGH]

565
00:26:22,683 --> 00:26:23,183
>> [LAUGH]

566
00:26:23,183 --> 00:26:24,010
>> There we go.

567
00:26:24,010 --> 00:26:25,891
So, we can go and
start installing the software, and pow,

568
00:26:25,891 --> 00:26:26,690
now I'm on a web server.

569
00:26:26,690 --> 00:26:30,790
So we get these servers up and running,
just like they're here in house with us,

570
00:26:30,790 --> 00:26:32,202
but now they're out there in the cloud.

571
00:26:32,202 --> 00:26:36,010
I'm not gonna bother connecting to
the SharePoint one, but it's the same one.

572
00:26:36,010 --> 00:26:37,940
You remote desktop into it, and

573
00:26:37,940 --> 00:26:40,750
you'll need to fire up the SharePoint
configuration just to be able to go in and

574
00:26:40,750 --> 00:26:43,120
name things, set your domain name,
and all that.

575
00:26:43,120 --> 00:26:46,240
But as far as getting servers up and
running, that's it right there.

576
00:26:46,240 --> 00:26:49,000
It's as easy as a couple of clicks,
and you're in business.

577
00:26:49,000 --> 00:26:52,060
>> Yeah, they did a really good job
of making this pretty user-friendly,

578
00:26:52,060 --> 00:26:54,270
very intuitive interface
>> I liked it a lot.

579
00:26:54,270 --> 00:26:57,370
Hopefully, all you guys out
there watching do as well.

580
00:26:57,370 --> 00:27:00,430
So Don, I think we've covered
how to actually create

581
00:27:00,430 --> 00:27:02,210
a virtual server using Azure.

582
00:27:02,210 --> 00:27:03,550
Have we missed anything?

583
00:27:03,550 --> 00:27:07,020
>> We haven't missed anything, but we have
barely scraped the tip of the iceberg.

584
00:27:07,020 --> 00:27:09,360
There's a lot more we can do with
this stuff, so stay tuned for

585
00:27:09,360 --> 00:27:11,900
our other episodes as we move
into the advanced features.

586
00:27:11,900 --> 00:27:14,070
But as far as getting a server up and
running, that covers it.

587
00:27:14,070 --> 00:27:15,330
>> Yeah, it should be good to go.

588
00:27:15,330 --> 00:27:18,540
That being said, I guess we've come
to the end of another great episode.

589
00:27:18,540 --> 00:27:20,060
Hopefully, you guys have enjoyed it.

590
00:27:20,060 --> 00:27:22,630
That being said,
it is time to sign off for ITProTV.

591
00:27:22,630 --> 00:27:24,750
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

592
00:27:24,750 --> 00:27:25,460
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

593
00:27:25,460 --> 00:27:26,688

594

episodes.title: Additional Server Options
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,036 --> 00:00:10,372
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,372 --> 00:00:12,020
All right.
Greetings, everyone.

3
00:00:12,020 --> 00:00:14,950
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,950 --> 00:00:16,340
I'll be your host Daniel Lowry.

5
00:00:16,340 --> 00:00:20,150
Here with me, well is Don Pezet,
my mentor, my master.

6
00:00:20,150 --> 00:00:22,760
Help me out with this
day we're having today.

7
00:00:22,760 --> 00:00:23,400
How you doing?

8
00:00:23,400 --> 00:00:25,260
>> I am doing great,
excited to be on the show again.

9
00:00:25,260 --> 00:00:28,080
And what we're gonna be doing today,
is taking a look at some

10
00:00:28,080 --> 00:00:32,010
of the advanced options we can
configure when we create a VM in Azure.

11
00:00:32,010 --> 00:00:34,880
Now on a previous episode, we showed
you guys how to create servers, right?

12
00:00:34,880 --> 00:00:38,590
You whip up VMs dynamically, and
all that, and it was kinda neat.

13
00:00:38,590 --> 00:00:41,810
Set some basic options,
remote it into them and so on.

14
00:00:41,810 --> 00:00:44,680
But once the server's up,
for the most part,

15
00:00:44,680 --> 00:00:46,670
you just manage it like
a normal server right?

16
00:00:46,670 --> 00:00:48,630
And off you go and that's it.

17
00:00:48,630 --> 00:00:51,960
But, there's a few advanced
features inside of Azure,

18
00:00:51,960 --> 00:00:54,600
that center around
redundancy in availability,

19
00:00:54,600 --> 00:00:58,050
that we can really take advantage of,
to make our environment even better.

20
00:00:58,050 --> 00:01:01,310
One of the coolest things about using
a service like the Azure cloud,

21
00:01:01,310 --> 00:01:06,330
is that Microsoft has state of the art,
multibillion.

22
00:01:06,330 --> 00:01:07,233
Well, maybe not billion.

23
00:01:07,233 --> 00:01:09,469
>> [LAUGH]
>> Definitely multimillion dollar

24
00:01:09,469 --> 00:01:12,630
data centers,
that you're piggy backing off of, right?

25
00:01:12,630 --> 00:01:15,500
So your company might not have the budget
to build out these massive data centers on

26
00:01:15,500 --> 00:01:17,160
every continent on the planet,

27
00:01:17,160 --> 00:01:19,790
and multiple ones in
different geographic regions.

28
00:01:19,790 --> 00:01:22,910
But Microsoft does, and we can take
advantage of that, and we can use it, and

29
00:01:22,910 --> 00:01:26,230
it really does serve us a lot of benefit.

30
00:01:26,230 --> 00:01:27,860
Especially if you're small or
medium business, but

31
00:01:27,860 --> 00:01:30,810
even an enterprise can really
take advantage of this.

32
00:01:30,810 --> 00:01:34,920
Thing is, you don't get the full
benefit of it by default.

33
00:01:34,920 --> 00:01:38,490
When you whip up a server,
that server exists in one data center,

34
00:01:38,490 --> 00:01:39,850
running on one piece of hardware.

35
00:01:39,850 --> 00:01:41,050
And if that hardware fails,

36
00:01:41,050 --> 00:01:43,590
sure you can restart on another
piece of hardware, great.

37
00:01:43,590 --> 00:01:46,140
But could fail,
your system could go offline,

38
00:01:46,140 --> 00:01:48,420
and then you got an outage
you have to deal with.

39
00:01:48,420 --> 00:01:50,060
Well Microsoft has the tools for

40
00:01:50,060 --> 00:01:52,410
us to get around that,
we just have to take advantage of it.

41
00:01:52,410 --> 00:01:55,260
>> Awesome, so where do we find these
tools, and how can we use them?

42
00:01:55,260 --> 00:01:56,840
That's obviously the first question.

43
00:01:56,840 --> 00:02:00,550
>> Well some of them, we actually saw,
when we were creating and

44
00:02:00,550 --> 00:02:02,316
deploying a server, and
we just kinda ignored them.

45
00:02:02,316 --> 00:02:02,914
[LAUGH] The two.

46
00:02:02,914 --> 00:02:05,420
>> [LAUGH]
>> The two that I really want to

47
00:02:05,420 --> 00:02:06,440
talk about.

48
00:02:06,440 --> 00:02:08,830
We've got a few neat things.

49
00:02:08,830 --> 00:02:16,700
So inside of Azure, we can create
what are called availability sets.

50
00:02:16,700 --> 00:02:19,820
And we can create load balancing sets.

51
00:02:19,820 --> 00:02:22,100
Now let's start with
the availability ones.

52
00:02:22,100 --> 00:02:24,130
When you bring up a virtual machine,

53
00:02:24,130 --> 00:02:26,888
it's actually running on a piece
of hardware in a data somewhere.

54
00:02:26,888 --> 00:02:31,420
So whatever region you chose, you know,
that data center is where your

55
00:02:31,420 --> 00:02:36,020
VM's running, It's running on a physical
server in a rack at their location.

56
00:02:36,020 --> 00:02:38,430
There might be other customers
running in that same physical server.

57
00:02:38,430 --> 00:02:41,190
But you are running on one server.

58
00:02:41,190 --> 00:02:43,490
Well, that one servers running hyper-v.

59
00:02:43,490 --> 00:02:44,730
That means it's running Windows.

60
00:02:44,730 --> 00:02:48,455
And that And that means, at a minimum
it gets updates at least once a month.

61
00:02:48,455 --> 00:02:50,145
And it needs to reboot.

62
00:02:50,145 --> 00:02:51,615
Right?
What happens when it reboots?

63
00:02:51,615 --> 00:02:53,395
Does your server go offline?

64
00:02:53,395 --> 00:02:54,495
Actually it doesn't.

65
00:02:54,495 --> 00:02:58,605
And that's because Microsoft plans for
that, with the use of availability sets.

66
00:02:58,605 --> 00:03:00,895
Also, what happens if that hardware fails?

67
00:03:00,895 --> 00:03:02,425
Well, normally if the hardware fails,

68
00:03:02,425 --> 00:03:06,470
Microsoft would jump your storage over
to another system and bring it back up.

69
00:03:06,470 --> 00:03:07,650
But you have an outage.

70
00:03:07,650 --> 00:03:10,010
When that first server failed,
you lost what was in ram, and

71
00:03:10,010 --> 00:03:11,030
your server spun back up.

72
00:03:11,030 --> 00:03:14,230
So your outage ends up being however
long it takes your server to reboot,

73
00:03:14,230 --> 00:03:17,420
maybe a minute, maybe two minutes,
whatever, to come back up and running.

74
00:03:17,420 --> 00:03:19,100
But you did have an outage.

75
00:03:19,100 --> 00:03:20,640
Now Microsoft took care of it.

76
00:03:20,640 --> 00:03:23,380
They fixed the hardware outage,
they switched you over to another machine.

77
00:03:23,380 --> 00:03:26,480
You don't worry about that,
but you had an outage.

78
00:03:26,480 --> 00:03:28,760
So we can plan for that.

79
00:03:28,760 --> 00:03:31,340
We can take advantage of that
underlying infrastructure,

80
00:03:31,340 --> 00:03:35,300
and really get true stability and
availability, all right?

81
00:03:35,300 --> 00:03:38,290
Now, to better understand that,
let me show you an article that Microsoft

82
00:03:38,290 --> 00:03:42,760
pushed out, that is called, manage
the availability of virtual machines.

83
00:03:42,760 --> 00:03:45,000
And the reason I like this article is,

84
00:03:45,000 --> 00:03:48,360
they show a little bit of what
Microsoft does behind the scenes, okay?

85
00:03:48,360 --> 00:03:55,740
Behind the scenes, on the servers running
at the Microsoft Azure data centers.

86
00:03:55,740 --> 00:03:59,700
They divide their servers up into
what are called fault domains and

87
00:03:59,700 --> 00:04:01,910
update domains, okay?

88
00:04:01,910 --> 00:04:07,380
Fault domains are physical servers
divided up, in a way that if there

89
00:04:07,380 --> 00:04:11,690
is a failure, only VMs running in that
particular fault domain, are affected.

90
00:04:11,690 --> 00:04:12,390
All right?

91
00:04:12,390 --> 00:04:17,250
Fault domains center around power and
network, all right?.

92
00:04:17,250 --> 00:04:20,400
Now, a fault domain like
fault domain zero here,

93
00:04:20,400 --> 00:04:25,230
is usually comprised of one or
more physical servers.

94
00:04:25,230 --> 00:04:27,780
So these are all physical
servers right here.

95
00:04:27,780 --> 00:04:28,380
Okay?

96
00:04:28,380 --> 00:04:31,480
So fault domain zero,
has four servers in it right now.

97
00:04:31,480 --> 00:04:32,860
These four physical servers.

98
00:04:32,860 --> 00:04:37,710
These four servers share the same power
source, and they share the same network.

99
00:04:37,710 --> 00:04:41,640
If the network fails, or the power fails,
all four of these guys go down.

100
00:04:41,640 --> 00:04:47,590
So when we deploy a VM,
our VM is entirely in one fault domain.

101
00:04:47,590 --> 00:04:50,880
Wouldn't it be nice if our VM existed
in more than one fault domain?

102
00:04:50,880 --> 00:04:54,150
Well, every time you deploy a VM,

103
00:04:54,150 --> 00:04:58,900
Microsoft is spreading it across
five fault domains, all right?

104
00:04:58,900 --> 00:05:01,040
So if you create five VM's,

105
00:05:01,040 --> 00:05:05,560
you'll have one VM in each of
five different fault domains.

106
00:05:05,560 --> 00:05:10,730
If you create six VM's, the sixth one
goes in the very first fault domain.

107
00:05:10,730 --> 00:05:13,600
So now you have two VM's in
the first fault domain, and

108
00:05:13,600 --> 00:05:15,650
one in each of the remaining
fault domains.

109
00:05:15,650 --> 00:05:17,160
So they're doing it on the backend.

110
00:05:17,160 --> 00:05:18,490
Most people don't even know this happens.

111
00:05:18,490 --> 00:05:21,090
It's invisible, it's in the backend,
and that's that.

112
00:05:21,090 --> 00:05:25,340
But Microsoft is spreading your
servers across five fault domains.

113
00:05:25,340 --> 00:05:28,590
And those five fault domains
all have independent network,

114
00:05:28,590 --> 00:05:29,850
all the way to the Internet.

115
00:05:29,850 --> 00:05:33,070
And independent power all
the way to the power company.

116
00:05:33,070 --> 00:05:37,060
So these fault domains are almost like
entire data centers, in and of themselves.

117
00:05:37,060 --> 00:05:39,760
And I know in this diagram they
show like four servers in there.

118
00:05:39,760 --> 00:05:42,980
But the reality is there could be
hundreds of servers in Fault Domain 0,

119
00:05:42,980 --> 00:05:44,740
and Fault Domain 1 and Fault Domain 2.

120
00:05:44,740 --> 00:05:48,320
And as you deploy VMs, it's just
automatically being spread across that.

121
00:05:48,320 --> 00:05:50,600
So solution number one to our problem.

122
00:05:50,600 --> 00:05:54,160
If hardware fails and
I wanna avoid downtime, how do I fix that?

123
00:05:54,160 --> 00:05:55,450
You deploy more VMs.

124
00:05:55,450 --> 00:05:56,160
Right?

125
00:05:56,160 --> 00:05:57,890
If I have a web server.

126
00:05:57,890 --> 00:05:59,480
I should have two web servers.

127
00:05:59,480 --> 00:06:02,770
If I have two web servers,
I know one will be in a fault domain, and

128
00:06:02,770 --> 00:06:05,120
the other will be in
a different fault domain.

129
00:06:05,120 --> 00:06:08,180
Now they're in two different fault
domains, and so I know if one fails,

130
00:06:08,180 --> 00:06:10,750
the other's still up, all right?

131
00:06:10,750 --> 00:06:13,740
The other thing is the update domain.

132
00:06:13,740 --> 00:06:16,650
Each of these servers are running hyper-v.

133
00:06:16,650 --> 00:06:18,870
Updates come out at least once a month,
right?

134
00:06:18,870 --> 00:06:22,160
And when that happens,
a lot of the updates require a reboot.

135
00:06:22,160 --> 00:06:24,620
So if they have to reboot a server.

136
00:06:24,620 --> 00:06:26,540
How do you keep your VMs up?

137
00:06:26,540 --> 00:06:30,110
Well when Microsoft goes to reboot
a server, they do a live migration.

138
00:06:30,110 --> 00:06:32,800
They move your VMs from
one server to another.

139
00:06:32,800 --> 00:06:35,980
They empty the server out, and
then they update it and reboot it.

140
00:06:35,980 --> 00:06:37,020
Then they move the VMs back.

141
00:06:38,050 --> 00:06:40,250
So this happens all the time,
and you don't even notice.

142
00:06:40,250 --> 00:06:43,630
It could be happening right now,
and I wouldn't notice, right?

143
00:06:43,630 --> 00:06:45,730
But there is a little bit
of a performance hit,

144
00:06:45,730 --> 00:06:48,740
while live migrations are happening and
things of that nature.

145
00:06:48,740 --> 00:06:50,430
So what Microsoft does is,

146
00:06:50,430 --> 00:06:55,520
they divide your VMs inside of
a fault domain, into update domains.

147
00:06:55,520 --> 00:07:00,640
Now your VMs will be spread across
just to update domains, right?

148
00:07:00,640 --> 00:07:05,170
All the servers in here will be divided
up, and when they push an update out,

149
00:07:05,170 --> 00:07:08,750
they'll reboot one update domain first.

150
00:07:08,750 --> 00:07:12,740
And then they'll reboot the other update
domain, after the first one is done.

151
00:07:12,740 --> 00:07:15,330
So it's not like they'll ever have a
chance where they reboot all their servers

152
00:07:15,330 --> 00:07:17,360
at once, that would cause an outage.

153
00:07:17,360 --> 00:07:20,059
So this is a way that Microsoft
prevents that outage from happening.

154
00:07:21,190 --> 00:07:23,550
Right.
Now all of what I've talked about,

155
00:07:23,550 --> 00:07:26,710
is invisible behind the scenes,
we never see it.

156
00:07:26,710 --> 00:07:29,160
But if I have two web servers, and

157
00:07:29,160 --> 00:07:32,800
I wanna make sure they're in different
fault domains, how do I do that?

158
00:07:32,800 --> 00:07:35,470
If I have ten VMs, there's a chance that

159
00:07:35,470 --> 00:07:38,225
both of my web servers could be in
the same fault domain, isn't there?

160
00:07:38,225 --> 00:07:38,980
>> Mm-hm.

161
00:07:38,980 --> 00:07:41,580
So if I want to ensure they're separated,

162
00:07:41,580 --> 00:07:44,630
that's where I need to create
what's called an availability set.

163
00:07:44,630 --> 00:07:46,860
An availability set is
an optional setting,

164
00:07:46,860 --> 00:07:48,730
that we can define when
we're creating a VM.

165
00:07:48,730 --> 00:07:50,040
And we can set it after the fact, too.

166
00:07:50,040 --> 00:07:52,690
It's not like we're screwed
if we forget to set it.

167
00:07:52,690 --> 00:07:53,361
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] And you can't

168
00:07:53,361 --> 00:07:53,921
go back and do it.

169
00:07:53,921 --> 00:07:56,030
We can always change that later on.

170
00:07:56,030 --> 00:07:58,142
So if we want to see that in action.

171
00:07:58,142 --> 00:08:00,591
If I go back here to my Azure screen.

172
00:08:00,591 --> 00:08:02,976
And I'll just whip up a new VM to
show you guys in the wizard, and

173
00:08:02,976 --> 00:08:05,590
then we'll modify these other
ones that I already have.

174
00:08:05,590 --> 00:08:08,060
So, I'm gonna create a third web server.

175
00:08:08,060 --> 00:08:13,310
So when I go to create this server,
I'll do a Windows Server one.

176
00:08:13,310 --> 00:08:15,030
We'll do itprotv-web03.

177
00:08:15,030 --> 00:08:17,400
We'll just do a small server.

178
00:08:17,400 --> 00:08:19,450
Give it a username and password.

179
00:08:21,790 --> 00:08:26,095
So we get that set up and
I'll put this in east US.

180
00:08:26,095 --> 00:08:28,465
But that's another way to get
good availability, right.

181
00:08:28,465 --> 00:08:30,673
So stick these web servers
in different regions.

182
00:08:30,673 --> 00:08:33,730
If I have one in east US and one in Japan.

183
00:08:33,730 --> 00:08:36,940
Well the entire east US data center
could go down I still have that note

184
00:08:36,940 --> 00:08:37,640
over in Japan.

185
00:08:37,640 --> 00:08:39,103
That's an easy way to do it.

186
00:08:39,103 --> 00:08:41,492
All right,
I'll create that virtual machine.

187
00:08:41,492 --> 00:08:46,960
Now when I created that, did it ask
anything about an availability set?

188
00:08:46,960 --> 00:08:50,230
No, we don't see that and
that's because I did the quick create.

189
00:08:50,230 --> 00:08:52,940
With quick create it
just assumes information.

190
00:08:52,940 --> 00:08:55,160
It makes those settings and
it does them for us.

191
00:08:55,160 --> 00:09:00,180
If I go back to do a new VM, and
this time, I do, from Gallery, right?

192
00:09:00,180 --> 00:09:01,230
And I pick it in here.

193
00:09:01,230 --> 00:09:04,140
I'm just gonna do a Windows Server
2012 R2 Data Center, right?

194
00:09:04,140 --> 00:09:07,200
The same basic thing that I
just picked with Quick Create.

195
00:09:07,200 --> 00:09:09,100
Now, I get the menu items, though.

196
00:09:09,100 --> 00:09:11,490
And as we go through these menu items.

197
00:09:11,490 --> 00:09:13,370
It's not too much different, right?

198
00:09:13,370 --> 00:09:16,980

00:20:08,320 --> 00:20:10,350
you're not in the weeds,
you can just continue.

432
00:20:10,350 --> 00:20:13,300
It'll just jump right over to there and
it keeps that downtime.

433
00:20:13,300 --> 00:20:16,290
Cuz I know downtime,
even at a small percentage,

434
00:20:16,290 --> 00:20:20,010
I think 99.98% of the time,
you have uptime.

435
00:20:20,010 --> 00:20:24,000
That really does equate to quite
a bit of time where it's not online.

436
00:20:25,190 --> 00:20:29,360
>> Yeah, and it's easy to think of these
cloud providers as being infallible but

437
00:20:29,360 --> 00:20:31,110
they've all had downtime.

438
00:20:31,110 --> 00:20:33,460
Microsoft's Azure had downtime before.

439
00:20:33,460 --> 00:20:35,460
Amazon's AWS has had downtime.

440
00:20:35,460 --> 00:20:39,240
It happens, and it's usually
related to something crazy like

441
00:20:39,240 --> 00:20:43,140
BGP routing tables on the Internet and
not related to power or

442
00:20:43,140 --> 00:20:47,480
network, internal network or
air conditioning or something like that.

443
00:20:47,480 --> 00:20:48,950
They think that's all planned out, so

444
00:20:48,950 --> 00:20:51,020
there are some things that
are beyond their control.

445
00:20:51,020 --> 00:20:55,100
Having servers in more than one region,
having servers and availability sets like

446
00:20:55,100 --> 00:20:58,700
this, these are all just little steps we
can take to better protect our system.

447
00:21:00,480 --> 00:21:03,930
But otherwise those are just two of
the big things that we want to get set up.

448
00:21:03,930 --> 00:21:08,450
Daniel, I know you mentioned about
notifying it if something is down.

449
00:21:08,450 --> 00:21:13,960
Just to cover that real quickly on each
VM when you go into a virtual machine and

450
00:21:13,960 --> 00:21:17,610
you go into its configure screen, right
where we see things like the availability

451
00:21:17,610 --> 00:21:21,750
set, down beneath that you'll see
monitoring, and that's where we can set

452
00:21:21,750 --> 00:21:24,590
up to monitor the end points to make
sure that they're up and healthy.

453
00:21:24,590 --> 00:21:29,280
So if I come in here and
give this one a name, I'll call it HTTP.

454
00:21:29,280 --> 00:21:33,050
It's going to monitor that server,
and then I can set the test locations,

455
00:21:33,050 --> 00:21:33,880
who it's going to test from.

456
00:21:33,880 --> 00:21:36,900
So I'll test this one from Chicago and
Dublin, right?

457
00:21:36,900 --> 00:21:39,230
It's nice to get intercontinental views.

458
00:21:39,230 --> 00:21:44,920
And so that's going to check and now that
will be able to send me notifications and

459
00:21:44,920 --> 00:21:49,370
let me know if this node is down or
up or healthy or whatever.

460
00:21:49,370 --> 00:21:52,920
I'll be able to stay up to date on
that and actually get notifications.

461
00:21:52,920 --> 00:21:55,470
So it's an extra little step that
you may or may not need to do.

462
00:21:55,470 --> 00:21:57,140
Depending you might not
want notifications.

463
00:21:57,140 --> 00:22:00,070
>> Yeah, then there's those out
there that love notifications.

464
00:22:00,070 --> 00:22:04,490
I know where I used to work, we'd get so
many of them that it was mind numbing.

465
00:22:04,490 --> 00:22:05,470
You'd be like oh.

466
00:22:05,470 --> 00:22:06,970
I don't really need this information.

467
00:22:06,970 --> 00:22:09,310
But our boss at the time just loved them.

468
00:22:09,310 --> 00:22:11,920
He loved any kind.
Anytime you could set a notification,

469
00:22:11,920 --> 00:22:12,862
we were getting it.

470
00:22:12,862 --> 00:22:14,220
[LAUGH]
>> Yep.

471
00:22:14,220 --> 00:22:16,600
Well, Daniel, that's really about it.

472
00:22:16,600 --> 00:22:20,900
Just remember that it is a rare day that
you don't configure availability sets and

473
00:22:20,900 --> 00:22:22,460
load balancing sets together.

474
00:22:22,460 --> 00:22:23,690
You don't have to, though.

475
00:22:23,690 --> 00:22:26,040
You might have a SQL database and

476
00:22:26,040 --> 00:22:28,640
just a replica of it that you're
not load balancing on but

477
00:22:28,640 --> 00:22:33,020
you just want them in different
availability, in different fault domains.

478
00:22:33,020 --> 00:22:34,930
And so
you use availability sets there, too.

479
00:22:34,930 --> 00:22:37,390
There's plenty of places were
you might use them individually.

480
00:22:37,390 --> 00:22:39,050
Typically it is done together.

481
00:22:39,050 --> 00:22:39,810
>> Awesome.

482
00:22:39,810 --> 00:22:43,130
Well I guess that brings us to the end
of another great episode of ITProTV.

483
00:22:43,130 --> 00:22:44,770
Hopefully, you guys have enjoyed it.

484
00:22:44,770 --> 00:22:47,020
That being said it is time to sign off.

485
00:22:47,020 --> 00:22:48,340
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

486
00:22:48,340 --> 00:22:49,350
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

487
00:22:49,350 --> 00:22:51,985
>> And we'll see you next time.

488
00:22:51,985 --> 00:22:56,900
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Storing Data in Azure
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,199 --> 00:00:10,492
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10,492 --> 00:00:11,857
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:11,857 --> 00:00:14,370
And welcome to another great
episode episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:14,370 --> 00:00:18,180
I'll be your host, Daniel Lowrie, and here
with me today is my good friend Don Pezet.

5
00:00:18,180 --> 00:00:19,130
How are you doing today, Don?

6
00:00:19,130 --> 00:00:20,220
>> I am doing great.

7
00:00:20,220 --> 00:00:22,790
Ready to jump right back into
the world of Microsoft Azure.

8
00:00:22,790 --> 00:00:29,370
Today we're gonna be taking a look at
a slightly different technology, storage.

9
00:00:29,370 --> 00:00:29,870
>> No.
>> What?

10
00:00:29,870 --> 00:00:30,375
>> Storage?

11
00:00:30,375 --> 00:00:30,900
[LAUGH] >> Just storage.
So

12
00:00:30,900 --> 00:00:34,320
when you talk about virtual machines and
SQL servers,

13
00:00:34,320 --> 00:00:36,770
databases, all this high data stuff.

14
00:00:36,770 --> 00:00:38,800
Sometimes we forget about the easy ones.

15
00:00:38,800 --> 00:00:43,140
Things like storage, just sticking a file
in the cloud so people can download it.

16
00:00:43,140 --> 00:00:44,610
It's one of the easier topics,

17
00:00:44,610 --> 00:00:47,200
but it is one of the functions
that we have inside of Azure.

18
00:00:47,200 --> 00:00:49,100
It's one that a lot of
people take advantage of.

19
00:00:49,100 --> 00:00:51,450
It's very inexpensive,
it's a great resource.

20
00:00:51,450 --> 00:00:52,730
So we're gonna look at how to use that.

21
00:00:52,730 --> 00:00:53,960
How to get our data thrown out there, and

22
00:00:53,960 --> 00:00:55,910
take advantage of what
Microsoft has to offer.

23
00:00:55,910 --> 00:00:58,930
>> Now I was gonna say Don,
this is probably something that most

24
00:00:58,930 --> 00:01:03,010
people actually use on a day to day basis,
and don't probably realize it.

25
00:01:03,010 --> 00:01:04,410
>> Oh yeah absolutely.

26
00:01:04,410 --> 00:01:07,280
Well I mean if you're watching
this video right now,

27
00:01:07,280 --> 00:01:10,910
the odds are it's probably coming
from cloud storage somewhere.

28
00:01:10,910 --> 00:01:14,400
And it might be Azure,
it might be AWS, or somewhere else.

29
00:01:14,400 --> 00:01:15,870
But cloud storage is
a great way to do that.

30
00:01:15,870 --> 00:01:18,150
And there's a few main reasons why.

31
00:01:18,150 --> 00:01:21,470
For example, let's say that I had a file,
just a PDF document,

32
00:01:21,470 --> 00:01:23,430
and I wanted to give it to you, Daniel.

33
00:01:23,430 --> 00:01:27,750
Well, the old school was, I'll just
attach it to an email and send it to you.

34
00:01:27,750 --> 00:01:29,230
But what if the file's really big?

35
00:01:29,230 --> 00:01:32,430
It's not gonna fit on an email anymore, so
I need some other way to get it to you.

36
00:01:32,430 --> 00:01:34,610
I could trust some third party providers.

37
00:01:34,610 --> 00:01:36,770
I could try Dropbox or whatever.

38
00:01:36,770 --> 00:01:39,620
But if I'm a company, and
I'm gonna have thousands or

39
00:01:39,620 --> 00:01:41,550
tens of thousands of people
downloading this resource,

40
00:01:41,550 --> 00:01:46,080
this file, I don't want to rely
on Dropbox, some other company.

41
00:01:46,080 --> 00:01:48,490
I wanna be able to
control that data myself.

42
00:01:48,490 --> 00:01:51,940
And I want it to be white labelled so
that people don't see the brand.

43
00:01:51,940 --> 00:01:54,820
You know, if you download from Dropbox,
you see Dropbox page and all that.

44
00:01:54,820 --> 00:01:56,980
I want it to look like
it's coming from me.

45
00:01:56,980 --> 00:01:59,490
So, what I can do is I can take my files,
and

46
00:01:59,490 --> 00:02:02,450
I can store them in Windows Azure or
Microsoft Azure.

47
00:02:02,450 --> 00:02:05,870
I can store them in Amazon S3 or
somewhere like that.

48
00:02:05,870 --> 00:02:07,300
And when people go to download the files,

49
00:02:07,300 --> 00:02:10,530
you know they're on my website,
they click through the various links.

50
00:02:10,530 --> 00:02:13,120
And when they go to download file it
comes from one of those cloud providers.

51
00:02:13,120 --> 00:02:14,580
Now if they're on my website,

52
00:02:14,580 --> 00:02:17,350
I could just have them download
the file from my website right.

53
00:02:17,350 --> 00:02:21,850
But the problem there is my website might
be stored in one data center in the US.

54
00:02:22,920 --> 00:02:25,440
and I've got clients that went
to download this file and

55
00:02:25,440 --> 00:02:27,970
they're in Australia, or
Europe, or South America.

56
00:02:27,970 --> 00:02:30,030
And they're gonna get slower downloads.

57
00:02:30,030 --> 00:02:34,310
So wouldn't it be nice if we could
upload that file somewhere and

58
00:02:34,310 --> 00:02:35,810
have it geolocated?

59
00:02:35,810 --> 00:02:38,650
Have it where if you're in Australia and
you go to download this file,

60
00:02:38,650 --> 00:02:39,840
you're getting it in Australia.

61
00:02:39,840 --> 00:02:42,310
That it's being pulled from
somewhere local to you.

62
00:02:42,310 --> 00:02:44,060
That it's highly redundant storage.

63
00:02:44,060 --> 00:02:46,710
In case there's a failure
the data gets preserved.

64
00:02:46,710 --> 00:02:49,690
That's what using the storage
services in Azure can do for us.

65
00:02:49,690 --> 00:02:54,690
Microsoft has a ton of power tucked in
this, so it looks really simple at first.

66
00:02:54,690 --> 00:02:56,420
Just file storage.

67
00:02:56,420 --> 00:02:58,800
But it is a really powerful thing,
and we do use it a lot.

68
00:03:00,210 --> 00:03:02,560
All right, so let's take a look
at Azure's services for this.

69
00:03:02,560 --> 00:03:06,550
So, I'm logged in here on my laptop
into my Azure management portal, and

70
00:03:06,550 --> 00:03:09,570
as I browse down the left side of stuff.

71
00:03:09,570 --> 00:03:11,990
We see things like virtual machines and

72
00:03:11,990 --> 00:03:15,010
SQL databases that we
cover in other episodes.

73
00:03:15,010 --> 00:03:16,810
And then right here we've got storage.

74
00:03:18,130 --> 00:03:20,650
All right?
Now, when you go into storage,

75
00:03:20,650 --> 00:03:24,900
what you're gonna do is you're gonna come
in here and create a new storage account.

76
00:03:24,900 --> 00:03:27,970
You can create multiple storage accounts
to isolate, and separate your data.

77
00:03:27,970 --> 00:03:29,580
And there's various reasons for that.

78
00:03:29,580 --> 00:03:31,430
I might have some data that
I want to be private and

79
00:03:31,430 --> 00:03:32,720
some data that I want to have public.

80
00:03:32,720 --> 00:03:34,430
And so there's different ways
that we can divide that.

81
00:03:35,430 --> 00:03:37,510
Now, when we go to create our storage,

82
00:03:37,510 --> 00:03:40,820
we're gonna see that there's actually two
different ways to provide the storage.

83
00:03:40,820 --> 00:03:43,800
The way that we normally think
of is what's called a container.

84
00:03:43,800 --> 00:03:45,880
Our files get stuck in a container, and

85
00:03:45,880 --> 00:03:47,940
people can download the data
from the container.

86
00:03:47,940 --> 00:03:53,400
It's like a shared folder on a hard drive,
or a file share on a server, an FTP site.

87
00:03:53,400 --> 00:03:56,020
Any of the different ways that you
might have moved files in the past,

88
00:03:56,020 --> 00:03:57,070
that's what a container is.

89
00:03:58,470 --> 00:04:01,020
A table is the other option.

90
00:04:01,020 --> 00:04:02,030
And you might look at that and

91
00:04:02,030 --> 00:04:05,140
say, well what the heck is
a table in terms of files?

92
00:04:05,140 --> 00:04:07,860
Well, a table is actually
talking about a database.

93
00:04:07,860 --> 00:04:10,740
That Microsoft can store
your files in a database

94
00:04:10,740 --> 00:04:12,720
instead of just in a raw container.

95
00:04:12,720 --> 00:04:14,020
Now for most of us, that's a bad thing.

96
00:04:14,020 --> 00:04:15,340
We don't want that.

97
00:04:15,340 --> 00:04:20,650
But if you have millions of files,
It can be difficult to quickly locate and

98
00:04:20,650 --> 00:04:23,330
retrieve the proper file and
return that to somebody.

99
00:04:23,330 --> 00:04:28,020
So, one way to get around that is
to store those files in a database.

100
00:04:28,020 --> 00:04:31,650
And when you do that it's in a table,
and each file has an ID attached to it.

101
00:04:31,650 --> 00:04:34,260
And you can query for
that ID and do quick retrieval.

102
00:04:34,260 --> 00:04:36,220
Microsoft did a demo of this years ago.

103
00:04:36,220 --> 00:04:38,690
Where they took their
Microsoft Maps product,

104
00:04:38,690 --> 00:04:40,630
and it's changed names over the years.

105
00:04:40,630 --> 00:04:41,920
I don't know what it's called anymore.

106
00:04:41,920 --> 00:04:44,300
But whatever Microsoft Maps' service is.

107
00:04:44,300 --> 00:04:48,200
Cuz it was Expedia maps or
something, oh, whatever.

108
00:04:48,200 --> 00:04:52,130
But what they did is they took
the satellite imagery of the Earth.

109
00:04:52,130 --> 00:04:56,040
So they'd have these plates that
were images of say, a square mile.

110
00:04:56,040 --> 00:04:59,790
Well, the Earth is 26,000 miles around.

111
00:04:59,790 --> 00:05:03,770
It's hundreds of thousands, if not
millions of square miles in surface.

112
00:05:03,770 --> 00:05:05,400
That's a lot of images.

113
00:05:05,400 --> 00:05:06,860
So they threw them all in a database.

114
00:05:06,860 --> 00:05:09,720
And they indexed them based
on longitude and latitude.

115
00:05:09,720 --> 00:05:12,260
And so when you wanted to
retrieve satellite imagery for

116
00:05:12,260 --> 00:05:15,300
a city, you did a query based
on latitude and longitude.

117
00:05:15,300 --> 00:05:18,580
And it returned whatever image you had
stored in the database right there.

118
00:05:18,580 --> 00:05:21,000
Quick, fast, and easy.

119
00:05:21,000 --> 00:05:26,080
So if you're dealing with huge amounts of
data, you'll want to store it in a table.

120
00:05:26,080 --> 00:05:28,470
But if you're just dealing
with individual files,

121
00:05:28,470 --> 00:05:30,410
things that you want a simple URL for
people to access.

122
00:05:30,410 --> 00:05:32,630
You're gonna store those
in what are called a BLOB.

123
00:05:32,630 --> 00:05:36,220
A BLOB is where it's just a file
stored right in a container and

124
00:05:36,220 --> 00:05:37,400
people can download it.

125
00:05:37,400 --> 00:05:39,480
And that's what most of us are gonna use.

126
00:05:39,480 --> 00:05:41,770
In the web UI, we can work with blobs,

127
00:05:41,770 --> 00:05:44,510
we can work with containers,
we can't work with tables.

128
00:05:44,510 --> 00:05:46,510
We'll see the tables,
we'll know they're there, but

129
00:05:46,510 --> 00:05:49,580
you really have to use the Azure API
to create those and work in them.

130
00:05:49,580 --> 00:05:52,440
So that's a pretty advanced one,
it's really designed for developers.

131
00:05:53,440 --> 00:05:56,400
But if I just need to get some
files online, I need to come in and

132
00:05:56,400 --> 00:05:58,340
create a storage account.

133
00:05:58,340 --> 00:06:00,270
So we go to storage over here
in our management screen,

134
00:06:00,270 --> 00:06:01,890
and we hit our little New button.

135
00:06:01,890 --> 00:06:05,250
And you'll see I've got new
data service for storage.

136
00:06:05,250 --> 00:06:06,490
And I don't have a lot of choices here.

137
00:06:06,490 --> 00:06:08,480
I really just have Quick Create, right?

138
00:06:08,480 --> 00:06:11,010
It's gonna create a storage account for
me.

139
00:06:11,010 --> 00:06:12,960
And I just need to give it a name.

140
00:06:12,960 --> 00:06:15,700
The name is going to be the URL.

141
00:06:15,700 --> 00:06:18,480
And you can put capital letters in here if
you want, but at the end of the day it's

142
00:06:18,480 --> 00:06:21,410
gonna make them all lowercase, so
you might as well just type all lowercase.

143
00:06:21,410 --> 00:06:27,420
And it's gonna create a web address with
whatever you type here.core.windows.net.

144
00:06:27,420 --> 00:06:29,800
That's gonna be the address for
this account.

145
00:06:29,800 --> 00:06:34,240
So, if I create an account
called ITProTV-files.

146
00:06:34,240 --> 00:06:35,620
Oops, it doesn't like my hyphen.

147
00:06:35,620 --> 00:06:36,680
Let me get rid of the hyphen.

148
00:06:36,680 --> 00:06:38,530
There, ITProTVfiles.

149
00:06:38,530 --> 00:06:43,154
Then what I'm gonna have at the end of
the day is ITProTVfiles.core.windows.net.

150
00:06:44,200 --> 00:06:46,790
And then I can pick the affinity group.

151
00:06:46,790 --> 00:06:48,720
This is where it's gonna be located, and

152
00:06:48,720 --> 00:06:51,890
you'll see several of the different data
centers that are available to my account.

153
00:06:51,890 --> 00:06:54,010
Your account might have
access to other ones.

154
00:06:54,010 --> 00:06:57,590
For example if you look in here, notice I
don't have any Australian data centers.

155
00:06:57,590 --> 00:06:59,960
Right now Microsoft limits those
to just people in Australia.

156
00:06:59,960 --> 00:07:01,330
So if you are Australian,

157
00:07:01,330 --> 00:07:03,920
you'll see a couple extra data
centers here that I don't get.

158
00:07:03,920 --> 00:07:06,500
But you'll see the ones
that are available to you.

159
00:07:06,500 --> 00:07:08,040
I'll pick East US for mine.

160
00:07:09,090 --> 00:07:10,610
And then the replication.

161
00:07:10,610 --> 00:07:12,470
Replication is important.

162
00:07:12,470 --> 00:07:15,860
You'll see we've got four
options in here to pick from.

163
00:07:15,860 --> 00:07:17,440
And each one is a little bit different.

164
00:07:17,440 --> 00:07:19,420
So let me run down the list.

165
00:07:19,420 --> 00:07:21,410
Locally redundant is the first one.

166
00:07:21,410 --> 00:07:25,880
This is actually the weakest level of
redundancy that's available to me here.

167
00:07:25,880 --> 00:07:27,320
With locally redundant,

168
00:07:27,320 --> 00:07:31,390
it means that Microsoft is gonna
maintain at least two copies of my data.

169
00:07:31,390 --> 00:07:34,300
Right there in the same data center.

170
00:07:34,300 --> 00:07:36,410
In that same region and that's it.

171
00:07:36,410 --> 00:07:39,130
So, if one copy of my data
gets damaged somehow,

172
00:07:39,130 --> 00:07:41,650
like a failed hard drive,
they've got a second copy.

173
00:07:41,650 --> 00:07:42,690
So we're covered.

174
00:07:42,690 --> 00:07:44,200
That's a pretty good one.

175
00:07:44,200 --> 00:07:46,520

00:18:10,710 --> 00:18:13,240
But it's all still in beta,

408
00:18:13,240 --> 00:18:16,450
Under the current system,
there's two ways to get files in.

00:18:25,420 --> 00:18:26,470

00:18:26,470 --> 00:18:27,640
All right,

if you got terabytes of data, that's
way faster than trying to upload it.

414
00:18:31,860 --> 00:18:34,970

intends for this to be used for for

415
00:18:34,970 --> 00:18:38,210

416
00:18:38,210 --> 00:18:41,840

00:19:05,710 --> 00:19:07,470

00:19:07,470 --> 00:19:08,970
And then I just come in here and

428
00:19:15,750 --> 00:19:17,140
That's one way.

429
00:19:17,140 --> 00:19:19,180
But what if I need the files

430

you can load files up there and

00:20:17,830 --> 00:20:20,690

00:20:20,690 --> 00:20:22,480

00:20:26,730 --> 00:20:27,940

00:22:38,830 --> 00:22:39,780
I was filling in the nickname.

I need to fill in the actual server.

And so it's correcting that URL for

00:22:44,560 --> 00:22:48,780

501
00:22:48,780 --> 00:22:52,450
For the username, well,
my username was itprotvfiles.

502
00:22:52,450 --> 00:22:53,010
All right.

503
00:22:53,010 --> 00:22:54,000
So I can specify that.

00:22:54,000 --> 00:22:55,860
Now, it hasn't asked for my key yet.

It'll ask for

So, now I've got that defined.

Here's my entry for itprotvfiles.

Remember, I said think

Well here they are, and I see them

00:23:52,540 --> 00:23:54,750
There they are, datacenter1.png,
datacenter2.png.

00:23:54,750 --> 00:23:59,461
They're uploaded, and

Now the cool part of all this

So if I go back to my Azure screen,

00:24:27,000 --> 00:24:32,350

00:24:40,350 --> 00:24:43,895
But now I can get this out, and
anybody who browses to that address,

00:24:43,895 --> 00:24:50,280
ITProTVfiles.blob.core.windows.net/public-
documents/datacenter-1.png.

00:24:50,280 --> 00:24:53,740
When they browse to it,
there's that image.

00:24:53,740 --> 00:24:57,620

00:24:57,620 --> 00:24:59,600

00:24:59,600 --> 00:25:02,160
They're ready and

00:25:02,160 --> 00:25:07,210
And Microsoft, they've got just a little

Tons of bandwidth compared to us, so

00:25:11,933 --> 00:25:15,740

00:25:15,740 --> 00:25:18,400
We just pay for

00:25:18,400 --> 00:25:20,690
With Azure storage,

00:25:25,190 --> 00:25:26,920
And then after that you pay for

560
00:25:29,270 --> 00:25:32,240
But they've got the capacity
to handle that, and

561
00:25:32,240 --> 00:25:34,450
we're leveraging that with Azure storage.

562
00:25:34,450 --> 00:25:37,270
>> Now Don, what would be the advantage or
disadvantage or

00:25:37,270 --> 00:25:40,900
difference or whatever you want to call it
>> between doing something like this or

00:25:40,900 --> 00:25:44,880

making a file server?

565
00:25:44,880 --> 00:25:46,500
>> So you certainly could do that, right?

566
00:25:46,500 --> 00:25:49,530
I can spin up a Windows box or
a Linux box, make my own file server.

567
00:25:49,530 --> 00:25:50,200
Right?

568
00:25:50,200 --> 00:25:52,890
But then I'm responsible for
maintaining the operating system.

569
00:25:52,890 --> 00:25:55,360
I gotta do patches and updates.

570
00:25:55,360 --> 00:25:57,478
I've got to handle my own redundancy.

571
00:25:57,478 --> 00:26:00,460
If I wanna copy between zones or whatever
I've got to spin up a server in another

572
00:26:00,460 --> 00:26:04,730
zone or replicate it, with this,
Microsoft does it all for me, right?

573
00:26:04,730 --> 00:26:06,430
And the other thing is,
when I spin up that server,

574
00:26:06,430 --> 00:26:08,920
I've got a provisional hard
drive that's a certain size.

575
00:26:08,920 --> 00:26:12,042
So I might have five gigs of files but
I go ahead and

576
00:26:12,042 --> 00:26:17,210
provision a 64 gig hard drive because

577
00:26:17,210 --> 00:26:19,710
Well I'm paying for that 64 gigs today.

578
00:26:19,710 --> 00:26:23,210
But if I use the Azure File Service,
I just pay for the files that I upload.

579
00:26:23,210 --> 00:26:25,385
If I'm only using five gigs,
I only use five gigs.

580
00:26:25,385 --> 00:26:26,260
But there's no limit.

581
00:26:26,260 --> 00:26:28,350
I can add as much as I want to it, and

582
00:26:28,350 --> 00:26:30,900
I never have to worry about
resizing a hard disk, right?

583
00:26:30,900 --> 00:26:33,555
That's the stuff that we get when
we use the Azure File Service.

584
00:26:33,555 --> 00:26:34,380
It's really cool stuff.

585
00:26:34,380 --> 00:26:35,750
>> Very cool stuff.

586
00:26:35,750 --> 00:26:39,580
All right, well, Don, it sounds like this
is definitely some beneficial stuff that

00:26:39,580 --> 00:26:42,570
we might wanna use, or
anybody might wanna use for that matter.

588
00:26:42,570 --> 00:26:43,720
Very awesome.

Anything else we can cover on this?

>> Yeah, I mean, the thing of it is,
there's a lot more of the back end as far

Azure storage, that's pretty much it.

So those are the things we need to know.

00:26:55,740 --> 00:26:56,350
>> Awesome.
Well,

00:26:56,350 --> 00:27:00,080

495
00:22:54,535 --> 00:22:57,325
So now I can jump into sales DB and

00:23:07,950 --> 00:23:11,420

00:23:11,420 --> 00:23:12,180
At this point,

00:23:12,180 --> 00:23:16,160
when I work with it, it's no different

00:23:16,160 --> 00:23:18,080
It's hosted in Azure, but

00:23:18,080 --> 00:23:21,480
I work with it the same as if it

00:23:21,480 --> 00:23:22,630
That's the glory of the cloud, right?

00:23:22,630 --> 00:23:25,150
We don't have to work
differently than we're used to.

00:23:25,150 --> 00:23:27,338
We just set it up a little different.

00:23:27,338 --> 00:23:31,040

It does protect yourself there, so

Definitely a part of running

00:25:22,830 --> 00:25:26,050

the whole server area,

00:25:46,635 --> 00:25:50,175
It's time consuming, it's difficult to

00:01:54,969 --> 00:01:59,757

00:02:04,030 --> 00:02:07,508

00:02:07,508 --> 00:02:10,748

00:02:10,748 --> 00:02:12,113

48
00:02:12,113 --> 00:02:16,087

49
00:02:16,087 --> 00:02:16,927
Microsoft Powershell.

50
00:02:16,927 --> 00:02:18,568
It's their shell environment.

51
00:02:18,568 --> 00:02:19,148
They love it.

52
00:02:19,148 --> 00:02:20,687
They do a lot of development in it.

53
00:02:20,687 --> 00:02:24,588
That's the primary command
line interface for Azure.

00:02:24,588 --> 00:02:27,887

Mac OS?

55
00:02:27,887 --> 00:02:29,528
You can't run the Power Shell, right?

56
00:02:29,528 --> 00:02:33,248
And so in that scenario,
you can't use the Power Shell commandlet,

57
00:02:33,248 --> 00:02:35,248
so instead you need a different CLI.

58
00:02:35,248 --> 00:02:39,527
So Microsoft created another CLI,
it's just called the Azure CLI,

59
00:02:39,527 --> 00:02:43,749

on Linux and it runs just fine.

60
00:02:43,749 --> 00:02:45,268
So you've got options, right?

61
00:02:45,268 --> 00:02:47,245
There's various ways that
we can go about this.

62
00:02:47,245 --> 00:02:49,593
But let's start with
that PowerShell one and

00:02:49,593 --> 00:02:52,945

64
00:02:52,945 --> 00:02:56,043
All right now, the Power Shell,
if you're running Windows 8 or

65
00:02:56,043 --> 00:02:57,745
Windows Server 2012, right?

00:02:57,745 --> 00:03:00,945
Those are the two main operating systems
that are out for Microsoft right now.

00:03:00,945 --> 00:03:03,593
They've got the Power Shell installed and
active by default, so

00:03:03,593 --> 00:03:05,145
you've already got the Power Shell.

69
00:03:05,145 --> 00:03:08,885
If you're running Windows 7, well,
it's got Power Shell by default, too.

70
00:03:08,885 --> 00:03:10,900
If you're running Windows Vista or
earlier,

71
00:03:10,900 --> 00:03:14,413
you might need to install it or at least
activate the feature, but most Microsoft

72
00:03:14,413 --> 00:03:17,686
operating systems that are under
support have the Power Shell available.

73
00:03:17,686 --> 00:03:18,926
So that's kind of step one.

74
00:03:18,926 --> 00:03:22,345
You've got to have the Power Shell

00:03:22,345 --> 00:03:26,205

00:03:26,205 --> 00:03:28,245
The Azure commands are not

Let me show you here on

00:03:30,785 --> 00:03:35,255
So this is Windows 8, and
if I fire up my Power Shell, so

00:03:35,255 --> 00:03:40,025
I'll just launch that and
I'm going to do a get-command.

80
00:03:40,025 --> 00:03:41,465

00:03:41,465 --> 00:03:44,605

00:03:44,605 --> 00:03:47,225

00:03:47,225 --> 00:03:50,425
Not a single Azure command comes back for
me here.

84
00:03:50,425 --> 00:03:51,426
There's nothing.

85
00:03:51,426 --> 00:03:54,003
So I need to add those
commandlets into the system, and

86
00:03:54,003 --> 00:03:55,745
then we'll be able to run with that.

87
00:03:55,745 --> 00:03:58,345
So that's kind of step two.

88

00:04:01,776 --> 00:04:02,285

90
00:04:02,285 --> 00:04:05,645
The Power Shell requires
.NET Framework 4.5.

00:04:05,645 --> 00:04:09,405

00:04:09,405 --> 00:04:14,162

00:04:14,162 --> 00:04:16,625

00:04:16,625 --> 00:04:20,465

00:04:24,509 --> 00:04:27,759

00:04:27,759 --> 00:04:32,073

Turn Windows Features On or Off.

00:04:34,889 --> 00:04:37,627

00:04:37,627 --> 00:04:40,668

00:04:40,668 --> 00:04:43,275

00:04:43,275 --> 00:04:46,748

00:04:46,748 --> 00:04:48,629

00:04:48,629 --> 00:04:52,009

00:05:16,846 --> 00:05:20,248

00:05:23,988 --> 00:05:27,008

00:05:27,008 --> 00:05:30,515

00:05:30,515 --> 00:05:32,788
